questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. He feels well. He was born at 38 weeks' gestation and weighed 2766 g (6 lb 2 oz). He now weighs 14 kg (31 lb). There is no personal or family history of serious illness. His immunizations are up-to-date. He is at 60th percentile for height and 55th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. The lungs are clear to auscultation. A grade 3/6 systolic ejection murmur is heard at the left upper sternal border and a grade 2/6 mid-diastolic murmur is heard at the left lower sternal border. S2 is widely split and does not vary with respiration. The abdomen is soft and nontender; there is no organomegaly. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A patent ductus arteriosus is often discovered incidentally in asymptomatic children. However, cardiac auscultation would usually show a loud continuous machine-like murmur (due to the constant left-to-right shunt) that is best heard in the left infraclavicular region.

B) INCORRECT:

A systolic murmur at the left upper sternal border may be a benign flow murmur. While benign (innocent) systolic murmurs are a common finding in children, they are usually soft (grade ≤ 2). The patient's findings of a diastolic murmur and a fixed split S2 are also not consistent with a benign murmur and warrant further investigation.

C) CORRECT:

This child presents with typical auscultation findings of an atrial septal defect (ASD) with the fixed (no change with respiration), widely split S2 being the most specific. Right ventricular volume overload due to the left-to-right shunt across the ASD causes a delayed closure of the pulmonary valve relative to the aortic valve. Since the right and left sides of the heart communicate, the pressure difference that normally exists during respiration evens out; therefore, the duration of the split does not change with inspiration or expiration. The increased blood flow through the right side of the heart also causes a pulmonary flow murmur, which explains the patient's systolic ejection murmur at the left upper sternal border. Some patients with ASD can also have a soft, mid-diastolic murmur at the left lower sternal border secondary to increased flow across the tricuspid valve.

D) INCORRECT:

While a mid-diastolic murmur may be appreciated in patients with a ventricular septal defect (VSD) as a result of increased flow through the mitral valve, this murmur would usually be best heard at the cardiac apex (mitral area) rather than the left lower sternal border (tricuspid area). The classic auscultatory finding at the left lower sternal border in patients with a VSD would be a harsh holosystolic murmur.

E) INCORRECT:

Isolated pulmonary valve stenosis can cause a systolic ejection murmur at the left upper sternal border and a wide S2 split but would not explain the mid-diastolic murmur at the left lower sternal border or the fixed split in S2 (i.e., no variation with respiration).

F) INCORRECT:

Coarctation of the aorta usually presents a systolic ejection murmur in the paravertebral region due to blood flow through the aortic narrowing. It would not explain the fixed split in S2 or the mid-diastolic murmur at the left lower sternal border.
questions.hint: This patient presents with a congenital heart defect that may lead to paradoxical embolism and stroke if not surgically corrected.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of difficulty walking and cold feet for the past 2 months. His parents report that he tires quickly from walking. The patient was born at 37 weeks' gestation and has met all developmental milestones. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. He is at the 50th percentile for height and 40th percentile for weight. His temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 119/min, respirations are 32/min, and blood pressure is 140/85 mm Hg in the right arm. A grade 2/6 systolic murmur is heard in the left paravertebral region. At this time, further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Low tissue oxygenation in the legs

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Rib notching can be seen on x-ray in patients with CoA, if compensatory collateral blood flow involves the intercostal vessels. The vessels may dilate to bypass the left ventricular outflow tract obstruction. While this patient may eventually develop visible rib notching, it is generally a sign of chronic disease and usually is not apparent in children before 5 years of age.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view)

Focal indentation of the distal aortic arch is seen at the location of aortic coarctation (illustration). An additional finding is inferior rib notching (Roesler sign; examples indicated by arrowheads), which is produced by dilated intercostal arteries.

The figure-3 sign of coarctation (indicated by red line) is seen in this patient. It is produced by prestenotic dilatation of the aortic arch and left subclavian artery in combination with post-stenotic dilatation of the descending aorta. The presence of bilateral rib notching indicates that the coarctation is distal to the origin of both subclavian arteries.

B) CORRECT:

CoA is most commonly located at the aortic isthmus, resulting in increased blood flow to the upper body and decreased blood flow to the lower body. Patients with noncritical CoA (i.e., mild-to-moderate CoA) typically present later in life (e.g., during childhood) with features of upper body hyperperfusion (e.g., high blood pressure in the upper extremities) and features of lower body hypoperfusion (e.g., cold feet, claudication upon exertion, brachial-femoral delay). In noncritical CoA, the left ventricular outflow obstruction leads to myocardial hypertrophy and increased collateral blood flow (e.g., to the intercostal arteries); rib notching occurs as a consequence of the collateral circulation between the internal thoracic and intercostal arteries and is usually a late finding (typically after 5 years of age).

Doppler echocardiography is the confirmatory test of choice and should be performed in all patients with suspected CoA. It can identify the location and extent of the stenosis and show concurrent anomalies, such as a bicuspid aortic valve (present in ∼ 60% of patients).
Image Description:

(1) Hypoplasia of aorta can lead to hypertension (↑ BP) in the head and upper limbs as well as poststenotic hypoperfusion. In patent ductus arteriosus, this can be compensated by a right-to-left-shunt of blood from the pulmonary arteries into the aorta, resulting in the flow of mixed blood with decreased oxygen saturation (↓ SaO2) to the general circulation.

(2) After closure of the ductus arteriosus, the right-to-left shunt is absent (~ SaO2) and there is hypoperfusion (↓ BP) of the abdominal organs and lower extremities with oxygenated blood.

C) INCORRECT:

Interarm differences in blood pressure can be a finding of CoA in the rare case that the narrowing is proximal to the left subclavian artery. In such patients, blood pressure in the right arm would be higher than in the left arm. In most infants and children with aortic coarctation, we would instead expect differences in blood pressure between the upper and the lower extremities.
Image Description:

(1) Stenosis distal to the left subclavian artery results in hypertension (↑ BP) in the upper extremities and the head, and hypotension (↓ BP) in the lower extremities and abdomen.

(2) If coarctation involves the origin of the left subclavian artery, BP in the right arm and head will be higher than in the left arm, lower extremities, and abdomen.

D) INCORRECT:

A right ventricular outflow tract obstruction (RVOTO) is typically seen in patients with tetralogy of Fallot. While patients with tetralogy of Fallot can also have a systolic ejection murmur, it is usually best heard at the left sternal border, rather than the left paravertebral region, as is the case in this patient. Furthermore, such patients usually present with (mild) cyanosis and intermittent hypoxic episodes that improve with squatting, none of which is present in this patient. CoA is characterized by a fixed supravalvular left ventricular outflow tract obstruction.

E) INCORRECT:

Low tissue oxygenation in the legs is typically seen in patients with ductal-dependent CoA (i.e., critical CoA and concomitant patent ductus arteriosus). These patients typically have differential cyanosis, as deoxygenated blood flows across the patent ductus arteriosus into the postductal systemic circulation. This patient most likely has noncritical, non-ductal-dependent CoA as there is no history of differential cyanosis. In patients with noncritical CoA, the blood flow to the lower extremities, although reduced, is typically enough to maintain normal arterial oxygen saturation and, therefore, tissue oxygenation. Additionally, the oxygen extraction fraction may increase to compensate for the hypoperfusion, contributing to normal tissue oxygenation.
questions.hint: Cold feet and potential lower-extremity claudication with physical exertion combined with high blood pressure in the upper extremities and a left paravertebral systolic murmur should raise concern for coarctation of the aorta (CoA).

questions.text: An obese 37-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 2 hours after the onset of weakness in her left arm and leg. She fell from the stairs the day prior but did not have any loss of consciousness or nausea after the fall. She travels to Asia regularly on business; her last trip was 4 days ago. She has no history of serious illness. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive. Her temperature is 37.8°C (100°F), pulse is 113/min and regular, and blood pressure is 162/90 mm Hg. Examination shows decreased muscle strength on the left side. Deep tendon reflexes are 4+ on the left. Babinski sign is present on the left. The right lower leg is swollen, erythematous, and tender to palpation. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ventricular septal defects (VSD) are the most common congenital heart defect and may cause paradoxical embolism. However, VSDs typically self-resolve during childhood or are surgically repaired. VSDs make up ∼ 10% of adult congenital heart defects.

B) INCORRECT:

Carotid dissection can occur at any age and is a common cause of stroke in young patients (∼ 20% of cases). Cervical artery dissection classically manifests with headache and neck pain following exertion (e.g., exercise, sexual intercourse, or even sneezing). This patient's lack of headache or neck pain in the presence of symptoms suggesting DVT makes another etiology more likely.

C) INCORRECT:

Atrial fibrillation (AF) is a very common cause of thromboembolic stroke in elderly individuals and those with heart disease (e.g., heart failure). Although a single normal heart rhythm on physical examination does not rule out paroxysmal AF, this patient's age and absence of heart disease mean that she is at low risk for AF.

D) INCORRECT:

Mitral valve vegetations are seen in infective endocarditis (IE), which may embolize to the brain and cause a stroke. Although IE can manifest with low-grade fever and tachycardia, this patient does not have other typical findings, such as a new-onset heart murmur and extracardiac symptoms (e.g., splinter hemorrhages, Janeway lesions). Moreover, IE is unlikely in patients without risk factors, e.g., recent dental procedure, IV drug use, active untreated bacterial infection.

E) CORRECT:

A right-to-left cardiac shunt (e.g., patent foramen ovale or atrial septal defect) allows paradoxical emboli originating from the venous system to pass directly from the right atrium into the left atrium, from which point they may enter the cerebral arterial system. In a young patient, stroke symptoms (e.g., unilateral weakness, hyperreflexia, facial droop) and signs of DVT should raise concern for paradoxical embolism. This patient should have an immediate stroke workup (e.g., noncontrast head CT, possible thrombolysis). Furthermore, ultrasonography should be performed to confirm DVT. Because paradoxical embolism is a diagnosis of exclusion, all other causes must be excluded after the patient has been stabilized. Given the risk of pulmonary embolism and recurrent cerebral emboli, this patient should be started on anticoagulant therapy once cerebral hemorrhage is ruled out.

Suspected patent foramen ovale should be confirmed with echocardiography so that it can be surgically or percutaneously closed to prevent recurrent emboli.
Image Description:

In the presence of a patent foramen ovale, transient increases in right atrial pressure (e.g., when coughing) can allow emboli from the venous system to pass from the right atrium to the left atrium. From there, they can enter systemic arterial circulation and cause arterial embolism (e.g., stroke).

F) INCORRECT:

Long bone fractures (particularly of the femur) can cause fat embolism. Fat embolism typically manifests with respiratory distress and a classic (but often absent) petechial chest rash as well as neurological symptoms (e.g., focal deficits as in this patient). While this patient had a recent fall, she has no indication of a femoral fracture such as bruising, deformity, or swelling of the thigh and her tender and swollen lower leg is more likely due to deep vein thrombosis.

G) INCORRECT:

Primary cardiac tumors (e.g., atrial myxoma) are extremely rare (incidence < 0.1% of the population), and can sometimes embolize, causing stroke. Most patients with primary cardiac tumors experience symptoms of heart failure (e.g., dyspnea, edema) due to the tumor obstructing blood flow. Additionally, patients often experience constitutional symptoms (e.g., fever, weight loss). While this patient has stroke and fever, she lacks signs of heart failure. Her unilateral leg abnormalities are more suggestive of DVT.
questions.hint: This patient has swelling, erythema, and tenderness of the right lower extremity. These features, in conjunction with a history of obesity, long-distance travel, and oral contraceptive use, indicate a high risk of deep vein thrombosis (DVT; Wells DVT score ≈ 3). In addition, this patient presents with clinical features of a right-sided stroke, suggesting a paradoxical embolism.

questions.text: A previously healthy 1-month-old boy is brought to the physician for a 10-day history of poor feeding. He struggles to breathe and sweats while feeding. He was born at 38 weeks' gestation following spontaneous vaginal delivery. His mother received no prenatal care. He was 51 cm (20 in) in length and weighed 3660 g (8 lb 1 oz) at birth. Apgar scores were 8 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. Examination following delivery showed no abnormalities, and he was discharged at the age of 2 days. Today, he is at the 20th percentile for length and 10th percentile for weight. His temperature is 36°C (96.8°F), pulse is 190/min, respirations are 60/min, and blood pressure is 70/50 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96% and breathing appears labored. Examination shows no cyanosis, but a grade 2/6 holosystolic murmur is heard at the left lower sternal border. ECG shows left-axis deviation. Chest x-ray shows an enlarged left atrium and ventricle and increased pulmonary vascular markings. Doppler echocardiography confirms the presence of an intracardiac shunt. The development of this patient's current symptoms is most likely a result of which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The closure of the ductus arteriosus leads to worsening of symptoms in patients with ductal-dependent congenital heart defects (e.g., transposition of the great vessels, hypoplastic left heart syndrome), and these conditions are typically more severe; they manifest with cyanosis soon after birth. A VSD is not a ductal-dependent congenital heart defect. The ductus arteriosus closes within 2 days of birth in children without ductal-dependant congenital heart defects.

B) INCORRECT:

An increase in systemic vascular resistance is rarely seen in neonates. If present, it is usually due to vascular pathologies, such as renal vein thrombosis or umbilical artery thrombosis, neither of which are seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Left ventricular outflow tract obstruction (LVOTO) can be caused by the presence of an underdeveloped aortic valve or congenital aortic coarctation, and manifest with left ventricular hypertrophy and heart failure. However, a murmur due to LVOTO typically has a systolic ejection character and is usually heard at the upper sternal borders (with possible radiation to the carotid region) or the interscapular region. The patient's murmur and the finding of an intracardiac shunt indicate a different cause for his symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

Persistent pulmonary hypertension in a patient with a VSD (which is initially a left-to-right shunt) could cause a shunt reversal (Eisenmenger reaction). However, Eisenmenger reaction is associated with cyanosis and right ventricular hypertrophy, and typically only occurs after a left-to-right shunt has persisted for an extended amount of time. The patient's age and the presence of only left ventricular hypertrophy indicate that the heart failure is triggered by a physiological adaptation that occurs during the first few weeks of life.

E) CORRECT:

Pulmonary vascular resistance (PVR) is high in utero and decreases over the first few weeks of life. The progressive decrease in PVR and subsequent decrease in right ventricular pressure lead to increased left-to-right blood flow across the VSD. The enhanced shunting increases the overall volume of blood in pulmonary circulation, which causes increased lung perfusion (as evidenced by increased pulmonary vascular markings), increased pulmonary venous return to the left atrium, and left ventricular volume overload (resulting in left ventricular hypertrophy as evidenced on this patient's ECG and chest x-ray). These changes can lead to heart failure without cyanosis within the first few weeks to months of life, as seen in this child.

If the VSD is not repaired and pulmonary blood flow continues to be high, vascular remodeling in later stages will cause PVR to increase again, resulting first in right ventricular hypertrophy and persistent pulmonary hypertension and, eventually, shunt reversal (Eisenmenger syndrome) resulting in heart failure with cyanosis.
Image Description:

A defect in the ventricular septum leads to a left-to-right shunt, the volume of which is dependent on the size of the defect. Blood flows from the left ventricle to the right ventricle (white arrow) along the pressure gradient (1). This leads to increased RV and LV preload (due to increased end-diastolic volume), ventricular hypertrophy and dilation (double-headed white arrows), and pulmonary hypertension resulting from excessive pulmonary blood flow (2). In end-stage disease, the pressure gradient is reversed because of Eisenmenger syndrome (shunt reversal), leading to the flow of mixed blood to the systemic circulation (white arrow) and subsequent cyanosis (3).

Blue: structures that contain deoxygenated blood; Red: structures that contain oxygenated blood; Purple: structures that contain mixed blood
questions.hint: Heart failure manifests with dyspnea, easy fatigability, and in children, sweating while feeding and failure to thrive. A faint holosystolic murmur heard at the left lower sternal border is consistent with a large ventricular septal defect (VSD).

questions.text: A 4-week-old male newborn is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. He was born at 40 weeks' gestation and weighed 3300 g (7 lb 4 oz). He now weighs 4300 g (9 lbs 1 oz). There is no family history of serious illness. He is at the 50th percentile for length and weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a grade 3/6 harsh holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border and a soft mid-diastolic murmur over the cardiac apex. The lungs are clear to auscultation. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's clinical findings?

choices.text: Left-to-right shunt through the atrial septum
Right-to-left shunt through the atrial septum
Left-to-right shunt through the ventricular septum
Right-to-left shunt through the ventricular septum

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A left-to-right shunt through the atrial septum can be seen in patients with an atrial septal defect (ASD). Patients with ASD are typically asymptomatic for years and diagnosed when an incidental systolic murmur is heard. However, an ASD typically causes a systolic ejection murmur that is best heard at the left upper sternal border (due to increased pulmonary flow) and a widely split and fixed second heart sound.
Image Description:

An atrial septal defect causes blood to flow from the left to the right atrium (left-to-right shunt; white arrow), resulting in volume overload of the right atrium and ventricle (1). As a result, there is dilation and compensatory hypertrophy (double-headed white arrows) of the right atrium and ventricle (2). In the late stages, Eisenmenger syndrome with shunt reversal (right-to-left shunt; white arrow) and cyanosis can occur (3).

Blue: structures that contain deoxygenated blood; Red: structures that contain oxygenated blood; Purple: structures that contain mixed blood

B) INCORRECT:

A right-to-left shunt through the atrial septum can be seen in patients with tricuspid valve atresia (TVA) and total anomalous pulmonary venous return (TAPVR). In both conditions, a right-to-left shunt through an atrial septal defect (ASD) is necessary to pump blood to the left side of the heart and, consequently, the systemic circulation. Patients with TVA or TAPVR present with cyanosis in the first few days of life. This patient's lack of cyanosis rules out both of these diagnoses.

A right-to-left shunt through the atrial septum can also be seen in patients with Eisenmenger syndrome secondary to an isolated ASD. However, Eisenmenger syndrome develops only after an extended amount of time (usually a few years) and manifests with cyanosis and features of heart failure.

C) CORRECT:

A ventricular septal defect (VSD) causes a left-to-right shunt through the ventricular septum. Most VSDs manifest in infancy as a holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border. The size of the defect is inversely proportional to the intensity of the murmur (i.e., small defects are associated with louder murmurs, while large defects may not have an associated murmur). A mid-diastolic murmur can also sometimes be heard with moderate or large VSDs due to increased flow across the mitral valve secondary to the left-to-right shunt.

After a few years, a VSD can lead to pulmonary hypertension and a shunt reversal (Eisenmenger syndrome) resulting in heart failure with cyanosis. With shunt reversal, the murmur of the VSD may disappear.
Image Description:

A defect in the ventricular septum leads to a left-to-right shunt, the volume of which is dependent on the size of the defect. Blood flows from the left ventricle to the right ventricle (white arrow) along the pressure gradient (1). This leads to increased RV and LV preload (due to increased end-diastolic volume), ventricular hypertrophy and dilation (double-headed white arrows), and pulmonary hypertension resulting from excessive pulmonary blood flow (2). In end-stage disease, the pressure gradient is reversed because of Eisenmenger syndrome (shunt reversal), leading to the flow of mixed blood to the systemic circulation (white arrow) and subsequent cyanosis (3).

Blue: structures that contain deoxygenated blood; Red: structures that contain oxygenated blood; Purple: structures that contain mixed blood

D) INCORRECT:

Right ventricular outflow tract obstruction (RVOTO) secondary to pulmonary infundibular stenosis can be seen in patients with tetralogy of Fallot (TOF). Patients with RVOTO would have a systolic ejection murmur at the left upper sternal border and it would be unlikely for a patient with TOF to present without a history of cyanotic spells.
Image Description:

Tetralogy of Fallot is the simultaneous occurrence of:
(a) Pulmonary stenosis
(b) Right ventricular hypertrophy
(c) Ventricular septal defect (VSD)
(d) An overriding aorta (above the VSD)

The hemodynamic effects depend on the extent of right ventricular outflow tract obstruction. With mild obstruction (1), a left-to-right shunt is more pronounced and there is mild cyanosis. With severe obstruction (2), a right-to-left shunt is more pronounced, which results in severe cyanosis. Pulmonary circulation may be supplied via a patent ductus arteriosus.

E) INCORRECT:

A right-to-left shunt through the ventricular septum can occur in patients with tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) who have severe right ventricular outflow tract obstruction (RVOTO). In such a scenario, the path of least resistance is through the ventricular septal defect (VSD), and not through the pulmonary valve. Patients with RVOTO would have a systolic ejection murmur at the left upper sternal border and it would be unlikely for a patient with TOF to present without a history of cyanotic spells.

A right-to-left shunt through the ventricular septum can also be seen in patients with Eisenmenger syndrome secondary to an isolated VSD. However, Eisenmenger syndrome develops only after an extended amount of time (usually a few years) and manifests with cyanosis and features of heart failure.

F) INCORRECT:

Left ventricular outflow tract obstruction (LVOTO) can be caused by the presence of an underdeveloped aortic valve or congenital aortic coarctation. However, patients with congenital LVOTO usually present soon after birth with features of heart failure. In addition, a murmur due to LVOTO typically has a systolic ejection character and is best heard at the upper sternal borders (with possible radiation to the carotid region) or the interscapular region.
questions.hint: This child's heart murmurs point to the most commonly diagnosed congenital heart defect in newborns.

questions.text: A 2-week-old newborn is brought to the physician for a follow-up examination. He was born at term and the pregnancy was uncomplicated. His mother says he has been feeding well and passing adequate amounts of urine. He appears healthy. He is at the 60th percentile for length and 40th percentile for weight. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 130/min, respirations are 49/min and blood pressure is 62/40 mm Hg. A grade 5/6 holosystolic murmur is heard over the left lower sternal border and a thrill is present at the same location. Echocardiography shows a 3-mm membranous ventricular septal defect. There is no evidence of ventricular enlargement and Doppler assessment of pulmonary artery pressure shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Antibiotic prophylaxis against infective endocarditis (e.g., using amoxicillin) is only indicated for patients who are about to undergo certain high-risk procedures (e.g., tooth extraction) and have certain high-risk cardiac features such as a history of recent CHD repair (within the past 6 months), a residual defect after repair of the CHD, or an unrepaired cyanotic CHD. As per current guidelines, patients with unrepaired noncyanotic CHDs such as VSD do not require antibiotic prophylaxis against infective endocarditis.

B) INCORRECT:

Surgical closure of VSDs before the age of 2 years is indicated for patients who have persistent heart failure symptoms or develop certain echocardiographic findings (e.g., left ventricular dilation, reversible pulmonary hypertension). This patient is asymptomatic and has no signs of complications. The patients who are most likely to develop complications and therefore require early surgical closure have medium or large VSDs; these VSDs manifest with softer murmurs and are typically not associated with a cardiac thrill.

C) INCORRECT:

Prostaglandin E1 (PGE1) therapy is used to maintain a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) and is indicated for duct-dependent CHDs (e.g., pulmonary atresia, transposition of the great vessels, hypoplastic left heart syndrome). Patients with duct-dependent CHDs typically present with cyanosis and/or shock within 24 hours of birth, in contrast to this asymptomatic neonate. This patient has a VSD, which causes a left-to-right shunt, as would a PDA. Treatment with PGE1 could actually worsen this patient's shunting and cause heart failure.

D) CORRECT:

Small VSDs typically close spontaneously without complication, so asymptomatic patients should be reevaluated at 6 months of age for spontaneous closure. If the patient remains asymptomatic at a 6-month follow-up but their murmur persists, reevaluation at 1 year of age is indicated. Asymptomatic patients should subsequently be reevaluated every 2 years.

If symptoms of heart failure (e.g., tachypnea, distress during feeding, failure to thrive) arise, patients should be referred for evaluation and medical therapy (diuretics, immunoprophylaxis, nutritional support). Surgical closure is indicated for patients who remain symptomatic despite medical therapy or develop certain echocardiographic findings (e.g., left ventricular dilation, reversible pulmonary hypertension).

E) INCORRECT:

Indomethacin is used to induce closure of a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), which can be asymptomatic but would manifest with a characteristic machine-like continuous murmur on cardiac auscultation. This patient's auscultatory and echocardiographic findings indicate a different diagnosis, for which indomethacin therapy is not indicated.

F) INCORRECT:

Cardiac catheterization was commonly used in the past to confirm chamber pressures in the workup of VSDs. However, Doppler echocardiography has largely replaced catheterization in the initial workup of VSD, as it provides almost all of the same information without the associated risks of an invasive procedure.

In a patient with a VSD, cardiac catheterization would be indicated prior to surgical repair if pulmonary hypertension were suspected based on clinical (e.g., loud P2) or echocardiographic findings. Cardiac catheterization is done to measure the reactivity of pulmonary vasculature to vasodilators because irreversible pulmonary artery hypertension is a contraindication to closure of the VSD.

G) INCORRECT:

Closure of the VSD with an Amplatzer® device via cardiac catheterization is generally reserved for patients with a residual VSD after surgical closure, patients with contraindications for surgical closure (e.g., swiss-cheese septum, poorly accessible muscular VSDs), and for older children with small, restrictive muscular VSDs with significant left-to-right flow. Transcatheter closure is contraindicated in patients with membranous VSDs (which are the most common type of VSDs) because of the high risk of heart block after the procedure.
questions.hint: Echocardiography confirms the diagnosis of a ventricular septal defect (VSD), which is the most common congenital heart defect (CHD) and causes a holosystolic murmur best heard over the left lower sternal border. Small VSDs (diameter ≤ 3 mm) cause less left-to-right shunting but result in louder murmurs when compared to medium or large VSDs.

questions.text: A 19-month-old girl is brought for a well-child examination. She was born at term and has been healthy. On physical examination, the child is alert and active. Her temperature is 37.3 °C (99.1 °F), pulse is 102/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 102/54 mm Hg. She is at the 75th percentile for height and 80th percentile for weight. Cardiac examination shows a normal S1 and a split S2 during inspiration. A grade 2/6 soft mid-systolic murmur is heard maximally at the lower left sternal border. A contrast echocardiogram is performed and reveals a mild transient right-to-left interatrial shunt that becomes apparent when the child coughs. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Percutaneous closure of a PFO is only necessary when ischemic infarction has occurred due to a presumed paradoxical embolism in a patient with confirmed PFO. Typically, endovascular closure is performed in patients with recurrent ischemic events despite medical therapy and patients in whom long-term anticoagulation is contraindicated. Since this patient does not present with clinical manifestations of paradoxical embolism, percutaneous closure is not indicated.

B) CORRECT:

This patient's mild, asymptomatic PFO requires no further diagnostic procedure, follow-up, or treatment. A persistent foramen ovale occurs in approx. 25–30% of the general population and, since most patients are asymptomatic, is typically an incidental finding. A diagnostic workup (i.e., contrast echocardiography) and treatment (e.g., anticoagulation, closure of the defect) only become necessary if paradoxical embolism occurs. While this patient has a soft-mid systolic murmur that may be just an innocent heart murmur, she is well without signs of paradoxical embolism (e.g., stroke symptoms).

A split S2 during inspiration is physiological. If the S2 splitting is fixed (persistently audible on auscultation during inspiration and expiration), there might be an underlying right ventricular overload (e.g., large atrial septal defects). PFOs are usually hemodynamically irrelevant and so do not cause fixed S2 splitting.

C) INCORRECT:

Warfarin therapy is indicated in patients with a PFO and paradoxical embolism. After an embolic event, treatment is either initiated with antiplatelet therapy alone (e.g., aspirin) or, in high-risk individuals, in combination with warfarin (e.g., patients with a PFO with major shunt, recurrent cryptogenic TIA or stroke, DVT, and pulmonary embolism). Since this patient does not present with clinical manifestations of paradoxical embolism, anticoagulation is not indicated.

D) INCORRECT:

Aspirin therapy is indicated in patients with a PFO and paradoxical embolism (e.g., stroke). After an embolic event, treatment is either initiated with antiplatelet therapy alone (i.e., aspirin) or combined with warfarin in high-risk individuals (e.g., patients with a PFO with major shunt, recurrent cryptogenic TIA or stroke, DVT, or pulmonary embolism). Since this patient does not present with clinical manifestations of paradoxical embolism, antiplatelet therapy is not indicated.

E) INCORRECT:

Surgical closure permanently seals the PFO and is indicated in large PFOs > 2.5 cm or if percutaneous closure was previously unsuccessful. Since this patient is asymptomatic and only has a mild, transient defect, surgery is not indicated. In addition, the risks associated with surgery are greater than that of complications of PFO (e.g., paradoxical embolism) occurring.

F) INCORRECT:

Follow-up with serial echocardiography may be indicated for some patients with atrial septal defects to monitor defect size and evaluate shunting. However, for patients with PFO, given the high likelihood of spontaneous closure during childhood and adolescence and the low likelihood of complications, monitoring with serial echocardiography does not have any benefit according to the currently available evidence.
questions.hint: A right-to-left interatrial shunt (made apparent by a saline bubble study on echocardiography) that opens during coughing is diagnostic of patent foramen ovale (PFO). During coughing, right-to-left shunting of blood can occur through this defect because of the transiently increased pressure in the pulmonary circulation (and consequently increased right atrial pressure).

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of increasing shortness of breath for the past 2 days. He is at 30th percentile for height and at 25th percentile for weight. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 144/min, respirations are 40/min, and blood pressure is 80/44 mm Hg. Bilateral crackles are heard at the lung bases. Cardiac examination discloses a grade 3/6 holosystolic murmur best heard over the left lower sternal border and a grade 1/6 middiastolic murmur at the cardiac apex. Without treatment, this patient is at greatest risk of developing which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The congenital heart defect most likely to cause cerebral aneurysms is coarctation of the aorta. This defect would cause a systolic ejection murmur over the left paravertebral region and/or a continuous murmur below the left clavicula and between the shoulder blades.

B) CORRECT:

A VSD is an acyanotic congenital heart defect that initially has a left-to-right shunt. However, as blood flows through the defect into the right ventricle, blood flow through the pulmonary vasculature increases as well and over time results in increased pulmonary resistance and, ultimately, Eisenmenger reaction (shunt reversal). In this event, the defect becomes cyanotic and the peripheral oxygen saturation decreases. The body responds to chronic hypoxemia by increased erythropoietin production and a subsequent increase in red blood cells, i.e. polycythemia.

C) INCORRECT:

The left-to-right shunting of blood in VSD can, over time, lead to pulmonary vascular remodeling and increased vascular resistance, resulting in pulmonary rather than systemic hypertension.

D) INCORRECT:

A long-standing, uncorrected VSD will eventually result in an Eisenmenger reaction (shunt reversal), in which case, thrombocytopenia, not thrombocytosis, may occur. The cause for thrombocytopenia is unknown, but it is possibly because megakaryocytes bypass pulmonary vasculature, where they would normally be fragmented into platelets.

E) INCORRECT:

Congenital heart defects associated with an increased risk of myocardial ischemia are typically those that involve coronary artery abnormalities (e.g., anomalous course or origin, involving fistulas) or result in decreased coronary perfusion (e.g., in a large PDA, the retrograde blood flow to the left ventricle can decrease diastolic pressure in the proximal aorta and thereby decrease coronary perfusion). Even though a long-standing, uncorrected VSD can also lead to decreased blood pressure, there are no reports of this increasing the risk of myocardial ischemia.
questions.hint: A holosystolic murmur (indicating flow through the defect) and the middiastolic murmur (increased flow through the mitral valve during diastole) suggests ventricular septal defect (VSD), the most common type of congenital heart defect.

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl is brought to the cardiologist because of sweating and respiratory distress while eating. She is at the 30th percentile for height and 15th percentile for weight. Echocardiography shows a defect in the membranous portion of the interventricular septum and a moderately decreased left ventricular ejection fraction. Physical examination is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Systolic murmur that increases with hand clenching
Wide, fixed splitting of the second heart sound
Systolic murmur that increases with forced exhalation against a closed glottis
Diastolic murmur preceded by opening snap
Continuous murmur that is loudest at the second heart sound

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Hand clenching increases systemic vascular resistance and afterload, which causes left-to-right shunting of blood and makes the systolic murmur in VSD more audible. Small VSDs may cause a loud systolic murmur with palpable thrill due to the large pressure differential between the left and right ventricles, while large VSDs are typically less obvious on auscultation. If left untreated, VSDs can lead to pulmonary hypertension and heart failure.
Image Description:

Holosystolic murmur (often referred to as “pansystolic murmur” in the case of a ventricular septal defect)

B) INCORRECT:

A wide, fixed (i.e., does not change with respiration) splitting of the second heart sound is characteristic of atrial septal defect (ASD). It occurs due to right ventricular overload and subsequent delay in pulmonary valve closure. Fixed splitting of the second heart sound is not a common feature of VSD.

C) INCORRECT:

A systolic murmur that increases with forced exhalation against a closed glottis (Valsalva maneuver) is characteristic of hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM). The Valsalva maneuver reduces both preload and left ventricular afterload, which would exacerbate the subaortic stenosis in HOCM but reduce the left-to-right shunt of blood in VSD. The Valsalva maneuver would therefore decrease this patient's murmur intensity.

D) INCORRECT:

A diastolic murmur preceded by an opening snap at the apex is characteristic of mitral stenosis (MS). The opening snap occurs when leaflet motion suddenly stops during diastole after the stenosed valve has opened fully. While a short, mid-diastolic murmur can sometimes be heard in VSD due to increased blood flow across the mitral valve, an opening snap would not be expected.

E) INCORRECT:

A continuous murmur that becomes louder at the second heart sound is characteristic of patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). The murmur is best appreciated in the left infraclavicular region and results from the constant flow of blood from the high pressure aorta to the low pressure pulmonary artery. VSD is characterized by a different finding on auscultation.
Image Description:

Continuous systolic and diastolic heart murmur (machinery murmur)
questions.hint: Examination findings for a symptomatic ventricular septal defect (VSD) in a patient this age will reflect shunting of blood from the left to right ventricle.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his father, who is concerned because his son has been less interested in playing soccer with him recently. They used to play every weekend, but his son has started to tire easily and has complained of pain in the lower legs while running around on the soccer field. The boy has no personal or family history of serious illness. Cardiac examination shows a systolic ejection murmur best heard over the left sternal border that radiates to the left paravertebral region. Chest x-rays show erosions of the posterior aspects of the 6th to 8th ribs. If left untreated, this patient is at greatest risk for developing which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

An increased risk of intracranial hemorrhage is present in patients with untreated aortic coarctation because of brachiocephalic hypertension. Moreover, aortic coarctation is associated with intracranial aneurysm formation (due to hypertension and/or genetic risk factors), which increases the risk of hemorrhage due to aneurysm rupture. Other complications of aortic coarctation include aortic arch aneurysm and dissection, coronary artery disease, ischemic stroke, endocarditis, left ventricular hypertrophy, and heart failure.

B) INCORRECT:

Central cyanosis is seen in patients with congenital heart defects that lead to right-to-left shunting, such as tetralogy of Fallot and transposition of the great vessels. It is not typically seen in aortic coarctation, which is considered an acyanotic heart defect. Cyanotic heart defects usually become evident in the newborn period, often manifesting with acute, life-threatening episodes of cyanosis. If left untreated, most defects are fatal within the first year of life.

C) INCORRECT:

Paradoxical embolism is a possible complication of shunts that allow a thrombus to pass from venous to arterial circulation, such as patent foramen ovale and atrial septal defect (ASD). Since both of these conditions are usually asymptomatic, intermittent claudication would not be expected. Moreover, unlike this patient's murmur, ASD manifests with a mid-systolic pulmonary flow or ejection murmur accompanied by wide, fixed splitting of S2.

D) INCORRECT:

Risk factors for abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) include smoking, advanced age, atherosclerosis, and systemic arterial hypertension. Although aortic coarctation leads to brachiocephalic hypertension, the risk of AAA is not increased because blood flow in the vessels distal to the constriction at the aortic isthmus is actually decreased. Rather, increased blood flow proximal to the constriction increases the risk of dilation of the aortic arch (thoracic aorta). AAA is rare in children and when it occurs, it is usually due to an underlying connective tissue disease (e.g., Ehler-Danlos syndrome).

E) INCORRECT:

Left ventricular outflow tract obstruction caused by aortic coarctation results in compensatory left ventricular hypertrophy and arterial hypertension, either of which can eventually result in left-sided heart failure. Although right-sided heart failure can occur secondary to left-sided heart failure, this patient is at a higher risk of a different complication.
questions.hint: Intermittent leg pain on exertion (intermittent claudication) suggests lower extremity arterial insufficiency. The systolic ejection murmur described is likely due to aortic narrowing, and the erosions of the ribs suggest collateral circulation through the intercostal arteries (rib notching). Together, these findings indicate aortic coarctation.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of a 6-month history of progressive fatigue and worsening shortness of breath on exertion. The parents report that the boy “has always tired out a bit more easily than other kids.” The family recently immigrated to the United States from rural Bolivia. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96% on both index fingers. Cardiac examination shows a right parasternal heave on palpation and a pronounced S2 on auscultation. Pulses in the upper and lower extremities are synchronous bilaterally. There is mild bluish discoloration and bulbous enlargement of the distal toes bilaterally. Echocardiography is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Single overriding great vessel arising from the heart
Anomalous shunting of blood through a defect in atrial septum
Persistent blood flow between the pulmonary artery and descending aorta
Positioning of the ascending aorta directly over a ventricular septal defect
Abnormal narrowing of the aorta at the aortic isthmus

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A single overriding great vessel is called a persistent truncus arteriosus. This single arterial trunk arising from the heart provides mixed blood to the pulmonary arteries and the systemic circulation. Pulses may be accentuated and bounding; however, oxygen saturation would be decreased in all extremities. Furthermore, if it is not diagnosed prenatally, it will typically present perinatally with symptoms of global cyanosis and heart failure, while this adolescent patient only has differential cyanosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Atrial septal defects (ASD) are often asymptomatic. In adults, larger defects may lead to a distinct left-to-right shunt, which can result in right heart failure, supraventricular arrhythmias, and pulmonary hypertension, and ultimately lead to an Eisenmenger reaction and global cyanosis. Differential cyanosis would not be seen.
Image Description:

An atrial septal defect causes blood to flow from the left to the right atrium (left-to-right shunt; white arrow), resulting in volume overload of the right atrium and ventricle (1). As a result, there is dilation and compensatory hypertrophy (double-headed white arrows) of the right atrium and ventricle (2). In the late stages, Eisenmenger syndrome with shunt reversal (right-to-left shunt; white arrow) and cyanosis can occur (3).

Blue: structures that contain deoxygenated blood; Red: structures that contain oxygenated blood; Purple: structures that contain mixed blood

C) CORRECT:

Failure of the ductus arteriosus to completely close postnatally allows blood to flow from the descending aorta back to the pulmonary artery (left-to-right shunt). In a large patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), this leads to volume overload of the right ventricle and the lung circuit. This increased blood flow causes pulmonary hypertension and irreversible remodeling of small pulmonary vessels, which may eventually lead to an Eisenmenger reaction (shunt reversal). This patient's palpable right parasternal heave and pronounced S2 are evidence of increased right heart strain. In patients with a large PDA, the features of differential cyanosis occur once shunt reversal develops. Because the ductus is located on the descending aorta distal to the origin of the left subclavian artery, reversal of the shunt results in deoxygenated blood reaching only the lower body. Due to the rise in pulmonary pressure, the characteristic continuous machine-like murmur heard in patients with PDA eventually disappears.

Infants with PDA usually receive an infusion of indomethacin to induce closure of the duct, while in older children symptomatic PDAs are typically closed surgically or via percutaneous catheter occlusion. The presence of an Eisenmenger reaction is, however, a contraindication to a PDA closure.
Image Description:

In patent ductus arteriosus, there is a left-to-right shunt, with blood flowing from the aorta to the pulmonary arteries during both systole and diastole (1). This shunt leads to volume overload (recirculation) of the blood within the pulmonary vessels, the left atrium, and left ventricle (2). Eventually, because of the increased blood flow to the pulmonary circulation, pulmonary hypertension may develop as well as Eisenmenger syndrome, which involves a shunt reversal. The left-to-right-shunt without cyanosis becomes a right-to-left shunt with cyanosis (3).

Blue: structures that contain deoxygenated blood; Red: structures that contain oxygenated blood; Pink: structures that contain mixed blood

D) INCORRECT:

Positioning of the ascending aorta directly over a ventricular septal defect is seen in tetralogy of Fallot. The other features of this cardiac abnormality are pulmonary stenosis and right ventricular hypertrophy. It is typically symptomatic in infancy and presents with tet spells and mild cyanosis in all extremities.
Image Description:

Tetralogy of Fallot is the simultaneous occurrence of:
(a) Pulmonary stenosis
(b) Right ventricular hypertrophy
(c) Ventricular septal defect (VSD)
(d) An overriding aorta (above the VSD)

The hemodynamic effects depend on the extent of right ventricular outflow tract obstruction. With mild obstruction (1), a left-to-right shunt is more pronounced and there is mild cyanosis. With severe obstruction (2), a right-to-left shunt is more pronounced, which results in severe cyanosis. Pulmonary circulation may be supplied via a patent ductus arteriosus.

E) INCORRECT:

Abnormal narrowing at the aortic isthmus is consistent with coarctation of the aorta (CoA), which would cause differential cyanosis if the CoA is severe (i.e., a ductal-dependent congenital heart defect) but this differential cyanosis would be evident from the neonatal period. In addition, patients with CoA have a brachio-femoral pulse delay rather than synchronous pulses. The symptoms of a mild CoA can begin later in life but in such a scenario, differential cyanosis would not be expected. Instead, patients present with features of brachiocephalic hypertension (e.g., headaches, epistaxis), lower extremity arterial insufficiency (manifesting with claudication and cool skin with faint or unpalpable pulses, but no cyanosis), and evidence of compensatory collateral arteries (e.g., continuous murmur over the back).
Image Description:

(1) Hypoplasia of aorta can lead to hypertension (↑ BP) in the head and upper limbs as well as poststenotic hypoperfusion. In patent ductus arteriosus, this can be compensated by a right-to-left-shunt of blood from the pulmonary arteries into the aorta, resulting in the flow of mixed blood with decreased oxygen saturation (↓ SaO2) to the general circulation.

(2) After closure of the ductus arteriosus, the right-to-left shunt is absent (~ SaO2) and there is hypoperfusion (↓ BP) of the abdominal organs and lower extremities with oxygenated blood.
questions.hint: The patient presents with lower extremity cyanosis and clubbing with preserved upper extremity oxygenation (a finding known as differential cyanosis) and symptoms of heart failure.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of recurrent nosebleeds and fatigue for the past 2 months. He also frequently complains his head hurts. The patient has met all motoric milestones for his age but does not like to run because his legs start to hurt if he does. He is at the 40th percentile for both height and weight. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 125/min, respirations are 32/min, and blood pressure in the right arm is 130/85 mm Hg. A grade 2/6 systolic murmur is heard in the left paravertebral region. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Notching of the ribs, an x-ray finding in patients with coarctation of the aorta, results from compensatory collateral blood flow involving the intercostal vessels. Those vessels may dilate to bypass the left ventricular outflow tract obstruction. Although this patient may eventually develop visible rib notching, it is generally a sign of chronic disease and usually does not become apparent in children before the age of 5 years.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view)

Focal indentation of the distal aortic arch is seen at the location of aortic coarctation (illustration). An additional finding is inferior rib notching (Roesler sign; examples indicated by arrowheads), which is produced by dilated intercostal arteries.

The figure-3 sign of coarctation (indicated by red line) is seen in this patient. It is produced by prestenotic dilatation of the aortic arch and left subclavian artery in combination with post-stenotic dilatation of the descending aorta. The presence of bilateral rib notching indicates that the coarctation is distal to the origin of both subclavian arteries.

B) INCORRECT:

Interarm differences in tissue oxygenation and blood pressure can be a finding of coarctation of the aorta in the rare case that the narrowing is proximal to the left subclavian artery. In such patients, blood pressure in the right arm would be markedly higher than in the left arm and oxygen saturation would be lower in the left arm. However, coarctation of the aorta most commonly presents with differences in blood pressure between the upper and the lower extremities.

C) INCORRECT:

Congenital pulmonary valve stenosis is a characteristic feature of tetralogy of Fallot. A systolic ejection murmur can be present and is usually best heard at the left sternal border, rather than the left paravertebral region. Patients usually present with (mild) cyanosis and intermittent hypoxic episodes that improve with squatting, none of which are seen here. Coarctation of the aorta is characterized by an outflow obstruction of the left ventricle.

D) INCORRECT:

Left-axis deviation and increased R wave amplitude in V5–V6 on ECG are signs of left ventricular hypertrophy. While myocardial hypertrophy is one of the compensatory mechanisms to counter the aortic narrowing in patients with coarctation of the aorta, such as this 3-year-old boy, the changes in ECG vary with age and degree of stenosis, and it usually takes several years before the hypertrophy becomes apparent. In older children and adults, ECG may show signs of left ventricular hypertrophy in the left precordial leads (e.g., positive Sokolow-Lyon criteria).

E) CORRECT:

In patients with CoA, delayed or even absent lower extremity pulses are expected distal to the stenotic portion of the aorta. Since the post-stenotic blood supply is limited, the resulting lower-extremity hypoxia becomes evident, especially during exertion, which is a strong sign of intermittent claudication, as in this patient.

Doppler echocardiography is the confirmatory test of choice and can identify the location and extent of the stenosis.
questions.hint: This patient's general fatigue, hypertension, low-grade systolic ejection murmur, lower-extremity claudication, headaches, and recurrent epistaxis together suggest coarctation of the aorta (CoA).

questions.text: A previously healthy 35-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of sudden weakness of her right arm and leg that started 3 hours ago. She returned from a business trip to Europe 3 days ago. She has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 10 years. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive. Her temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 115/min and regular, and blood pressure is 155/85 mm Hg. Examination shows decreased muscle strength on the entire right side. Deep tendon reflexes are 4+ on the right. Babinski sign is present on the right. The left lower leg is swollen, erythematous, and tender to palpation. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Paradoxical emboli can pass through any right-to-left shunt, but a patent foramen ovale (PFO) is the most common route. A PFO is considered an abnormal anatomical variant of the heart and is present in ∼ 25% of the general population. In addition to a stroke workup (i.e., noncontrast head CT, possible thrombolysis, etc.), this patient should also undergo compression ultrasonography to confirm DVT. Because of the risk of pulmonary embolism and recurrent cerebral emboli, this patient should be started on anticoagulant therapy once cerebral hemorrhage is ruled out and undergo echocardiography to evaluate for surgical closure of the PFO.
Image Description:

In the presence of a patent foramen ovale, transient increases in right atrial pressure (e.g., when coughing) can allow emboli from the venous system to pass from the right atrium to the left atrium. From there, they can enter systemic arterial circulation and cause arterial embolism (e.g., stroke).

B) INCORRECT:

Primary cardiac tumors (e.g., atrial myxoma) are extremely rare (incidence < 0.1%), and can sometimes embolize, causing stroke. Most patients with primary cardiac tumors do not initially present with stroke, but experience symptoms of heart failure (e.g., dyspnea, edema) due to the tumor obstructing blood flow. Additionally, patients often experience constitutional symptoms (e.g., fever, weight loss). While this patient has stroke and fever, she lacks signs of heart failure. Her unilateral leg abnormalities are more suggestive of DVT.

C) INCORRECT:

Embolism of septic vegetations from infective endocarditis (IE) that go to the brain can cause stroke. Patients with IE can also present with fever and tachycardia. However, IE is unlikely in patients without major risk factors for the disease (e.g., recent dental procedure, IV drug abuse, active untreated bacterial infection). This patient's warm, swollen leg could be confused with cellulitis, which would increase her risk of IE, but without a possible entry point for pathogens as in this case, a noninfectious diagnosis is more likely.

D) INCORRECT:

Ventricular septal defects are the most common pediatric septal defect and can cause paradoxical embolism, which has likely occurred in this patient. However, most VSDs self-resolve during childhood (and the majority of others are surgically repaired). VSDs make up ∼ 10% of congenital heart defects found in adults.

E) INCORRECT:

Atrial fibrillation is a very common cause of thromboembolic stroke in older adults and those with heart disease (e.g., heart failure). This patient is at low risk for atrial fibrillation because of her age and lack of heart disease. Also, her heart rhythm was normal on examination, which decreases the likelihood of atrial fibrillation (but does not rule it out).

F) INCORRECT:

Carotid dissection can occur at any age and is a common cause of stroke in young patients (∼ 20% of cases). Cervical artery dissection classically presents with headache and neck pain following exertion (e.g., exercise, sexual intercourse, or even sneezing). This patient's lack of headache or neck pain in the presence of symptoms suggesting DVT make another etiology more likely.
questions.hint: This patient has multiple risk factors for deep venous thrombosis (DVT), including a history of immobilization (business trip by plane), smoking, and oral contraceptive use. Now, she presents with clinical features of a left-sided stroke (e.g., right-sided weakness, hyperreflexia, positive Babinski), which in a young patient with signs of DVT (swollen, tender, erythematous left leg) should raise concern for paradoxical embolism.

questions.text: An otherwise healthy 15-year-old boy comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. He feels well and is doing well in school. He has no history of serious illness. Vital signs are within normal limits. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac auscultation shows no murmur, but a wide-split S2 that does not change with respiration. If left untreated, this patient is at increased risk for which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) typically manifests with a systolic ejection murmur caused by left ventricular outflow tract obstruction (LVOT). Hypertrophic myocardium, fibrosis, and disarrangement of cardiac myocytes predispose to potentially lethal ventricular arrhythmias, which can lead to sudden cardiac death, usually during or after physical activity. If severe enough (and then likely symptomatic), HCM can also lead to the paradoxical splitting of S2, in which the aortic valve closes later than the pulmonary valve (P2, then A2). In an otherwise healthy patient, there is a more likely anatomic cause that explains the fixed, wide splitting of S2 in which the pulmonary valve closes later than the aortic valve (A2, then P2).

B) INCORRECT:

Cerebral aneurysms are associated with coarctation of the aorta. Coarctation can manifest with a systolic ejection murmur over the left paravertebral area due to blood flowing through the aortic narrowing and/or a continuous murmur from collateral vessels heard between the shoulder blades. It does not manifest with a fixed, wide splitting of S2. Coarctation of the aorta may also be accompanied by other symptoms, such as hypertension, lower extremity cyanosis, lower extremity claudication, cold feet, dyspnea on exertion, or chest pain.

C) INCORRECT:

Left ventricular hypertrophy is a common consequence of volume overload or increased pressures in the left ventricle (e.g., aortic regurgitation, aortic stenosis). ASD (seen here), PFO, and VSD increase the volume in the right ventricle and subsequently lead to right ventricular hypertrophy. In the case of large septal defects, untreated chronic volume overload in the right heart leads to severe hypertrophy and pressure reversal (Eisenmenger syndrome), which then shunts deoxygenated blood to the left ventricle, leading to cyanosis.

D) CORRECT:

Paradoxical embolism is associated with ASDs, patent foramen ovale, and ventricular septal defects (VSD), which allows right-sided thromboemboli to enter the left-sided circulation by bypassing the pulmonary circulation. An ASD causes wide splitting of S2 that is fixed (does not change with respiration) due to increased volume within the pulmonary circulation. A VSD can manifest with a holosystolic murmur.
Image Description:

In the presence of a patent foramen ovale, transient increases in right atrial pressure (e.g., when coughing) can allow emboli from the venous system to pass from the right atrium to the left atrium. From there, they can enter systemic arterial circulation and cause arterial embolism (e.g., stroke).

E) INCORRECT:

Congenital heart defects (e.g., ventricular septal defect, pulmonary stenosis) and predamaged heart valves (e.g., aortic stenosis, mitral valve regurgitation) can predispose to infective endocarditis. However, this risk is negligible in ASDs and PFOs.
questions.hint: This patient's auscultation findings are likely caused by an atrial septal defect (ASD).

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy with a history of recurrent respiratory infections is brought to the physician for a follow-up examination. His height and weight are both at the 20th percentile. Crackles are heard in both lower lung fields. Cardiac auscultation shows a grade 3/6 holosystolic murmur over the left lower sternal border and a diastolic rumble heard best at the apex. If left untreated, this patient is most likely to develop which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Congenital heart defects associated with an increased risk of myocardial ischemia are typically those that involve coronary artery abnormalities (e.g., anomalous course or origin, involving fistulas) or result in decreased coronary perfusion (e.g., in a large PDA, the retrograde blood flow to the left ventricle can decrease diastolic pressure in the proximal aorta and thereby decrease coronary perfusion). Although a long-standing, uncorrected VSD can also lead to decreased blood pressure, there is no evidence that it increases the risk of myocardial ischemia.

B) INCORRECT:

Acyanotic heart defects, such as VSDs, are not a known cause of increased platelet counts. A long-standing, uncorrected VSD will eventually result in Eisenmenger syndrome with subsequent shunt reversal. In this case, thrombocytopenia, not thrombocytosis may occur. Thrombocytopenia due to Eisenmenger syndrome is thought to result from megakaryocytes bypassing the pulmonary vasculature where they would normally be fragmented into platelets.

C) INCORRECT:

Secondary hypertension can result from congenital heart defects such as coarctation of the aorta. All aortic branches proximal to the coarctation receive increased blood flow, ultimately resulting in intimal-medial thickening and increased vascular stiffness. In a 2-year-old child, symptomatic coarctation would most likely present with chest pain, cold feet, and lower-extremity claudication on physical exertion, none of which are seen in this patient. Furthermore, auscultation would reveal a systolic ejection murmur over the left paravertebral region and/or a continuous murmur below the left clavicula and between the shoulder blades.

D) INCORRECT:

Aortic dissection is a dangerous complication of untreated coarctation of the aorta in adults. Chronic hypertension proximal to the area of coarctation increases intraluminal pressure and subsequently weakens the arterial wall, potentially resulting in aortic dissection. Symptomatic coarctation in a 2-year-old child would most likely present with chest pain, cold feet, and lower-extremity claudication on physical exertion, none of which are seen in this patient. Furthermore, auscultation would reveal a systolic ejection murmur over the left paravertebral region and/or a continuous murmur below the left clavicula and between the shoulder blades.

E) CORRECT:

Digital clubbing is a sign of chronic hypoxemia, which is a complication of an untreated VSD. VSDs are acyanotic congenital heart defects that manifest as a left-to-right shunt. An untreated VSD can lead to chronic volume overload of the right ventricle (RV) and subsequently increased blood flow through the pulmonary vasculature. This increased flow causes irreversible remodeling of the small pulmonary vessels, leading to increased pulmonary vascular resistance and RV hypertrophy. RV pressure increases until it exceeds left ventricular (LV) pressure, at which point the shunt is reversed. This shunt reversal is known as Eisenmenger syndrome. Cyanosis and consequently, chronic tissue hypoxia, leads to the development of digital clubbing.

Chronic tissue hypoxia and megakaryocyte fragmentation are primary factors involved in the pathogenesis of digital clubbing. In Eisenmenger syndrome, blood can completely bypass the pulmonary vasculature, allowing whole megakaryocytes into the systemic circulation. Once these intact cells reach distal capillaries in the hands and feet, they impact and subsequently fragment. This fragmentation causes the release of platelet-derived growth factor and vascular endothelial growth factor, inducing angiogenesis and local mesenchymal growth and proliferation, which clinically manifests as digital clubbing.
Image Description:

There is enlargement of the distal phalanges, and the nail curvatures are increased.

F) INCORRECT:

Chronic kidney disease (CKD) can result from a variety of conditions, including advanced left heart failure. In individuals with low cardiac output, advanced left heart failure may lead to decreased renal perfusion, decreased venous congestion, and eventually CKD. Chronic, untreated VSD, which is seen in this patient, causes constant volume overload of the right ventricle (RV) and subsequent RV damage. Advanced stages of RV failure manifest with hepatomegaly and peripheral edema.
questions.hint: The presence of a holosystolic murmur (indicating flow through the defect) and a diastolic rumble (increased flow through the mitral valve during diastole) suggests a ventricular septal defect (VSD), the most common type of congenital heart defect. VSDs are associated with frequent respiratory infections secondary to congestion of the pulmonary vessels.

questions.text: A 2300-g (5.07-lb) male newborn is delivered at term to a 39-year-old woman. Examination shows a sloping forehead, a flat nasal bridge, increased interocular distance, low-set ears, a protruding tongue, a single palmar crease and an increased gap between the first and second toe. There are small white and brown spots in the periphery of both irises. The abdomen is distended. An x-ray of the abdomen shows two large air-filled spaces in the upper quadrant. This patient's condition is most likely associated with which of the following cardiac anomalies?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A patent ductus arteriosus is most commonly associated with prematurity, fetal alcohol syndrome, birth at high altitude, or congenital rubella infection. Although it occurs in approx. 5% of patients with Down syndrome, it is not the most common congenital cardiac anomaly seen in this condition.
Image Description:

In patent ductus arteriosus, there is a left-to-right shunt, with blood flowing from the aorta to the pulmonary arteries during both systole and diastole (1). This shunt leads to volume overload (recirculation) of the blood within the pulmonary vessels, the left atrium, and left ventricle (2). Eventually, because of the increased blood flow to the pulmonary circulation, pulmonary hypertension may develop as well as Eisenmenger syndrome, which involves a shunt reversal. The left-to-right-shunt without cyanosis becomes a right-to-left shunt with cyanosis (3).

Blue: structures that contain deoxygenated blood; Red: structures that contain oxygenated blood; Pink: structures that contain mixed blood

B) INCORRECT:

Atrial septal defects (ASDs) are among the most common congenital heart defects and are commonly associated with fetal alcohol syndrome and trisomy 21. Although ASD occurs in approx. 15% of patients with Down syndrome, it is not the most common congenital cardiac anomaly seen in this condition.
Image Description:

An atrial septal defect causes blood to flow from the left to the right atrium (left-to-right shunt; white arrow), resulting in volume overload of the right atrium and ventricle (1). As a result, there is dilation and compensatory hypertrophy (double-headed white arrows) of the right atrium and ventricle (2). In the late stages, Eisenmenger syndrome with shunt reversal (right-to-left shunt; white arrow) and cyanosis can occur (3).

Blue: structures that contain deoxygenated blood; Red: structures that contain oxygenated blood; Purple: structures that contain mixed blood

C) CORRECT:

Atrioventricular septal defects (AVSD; also referred to as endocardial cushion defects) are the most common congenital heart defects in patients with Down syndrome, occurring in about 40% of newborns with trisomy 21. AVSDs are usually diagnosed in the prenatal period, and discovery of an AVSD should warrant prompt genetic testing, as there is a strong association with trisomy 21. Down syndrome is diagnosed in approx. 40–50% of children with AVSD.

D) INCORRECT:

Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) is the most common cause of cyanotic heart disease in children. Most cases arise sporadically, but approx. 15% of patients with TOF have an underlying genetic syndrome (such as Down syndrome or DiGeorge syndrome). Although it occurs in approx. 5% of patients with Down syndrome, it is not the most common congenital cardiac anomaly seen in this condition.
Image Description:

Tetralogy of Fallot is the simultaneous occurrence of:
(a) Pulmonary stenosis
(b) Right ventricular hypertrophy
(c) Ventricular septal defect (VSD)
(d) An overriding aorta (above the VSD)

The hemodynamic effects depend on the extent of right ventricular outflow tract obstruction. With mild obstruction (1), a left-to-right shunt is more pronounced and there is mild cyanosis. With severe obstruction (2), a right-to-left shunt is more pronounced, which results in severe cyanosis. Pulmonary circulation may be supplied via a patent ductus arteriosus.

E) INCORRECT:

Ventricular septal defects (VSDs) account for approx. 50% of all congenital heart defects, making them the most common cause of congenital heart disease overall. They are commonly associated with fetal alcohol syndrome, intrauterine infections, and many genetic syndromes (including trisomy 13, trisomy 18, and trisomy 21). Although VSD occurs in approx. 30% of patients with Down syndrome, it is not the most common congenital cardiac anomaly seen in this condition.
Image Description:

A defect in the ventricular septum leads to a left-to-right shunt, the volume of which is dependent on the size of the defect. Blood flows from the left ventricle to the right ventricle (white arrow) along the pressure gradient (1). This leads to increased RV and LV preload (due to increased end-diastolic volume), ventricular hypertrophy and dilation (double-headed white arrows), and pulmonary hypertension resulting from excessive pulmonary blood flow (2). In end-stage disease, the pressure gradient is reversed because of Eisenmenger syndrome (shunt reversal), leading to the flow of mixed blood to the systemic circulation (white arrow) and subsequent cyanosis (3).

Blue: structures that contain deoxygenated blood; Red: structures that contain oxygenated blood; Purple: structures that contain mixed blood
questions.hint: The characteristic morphological features, Brushfield spots in the eye, and the “double bubble” sign on abdominal x-ray (indicating duodenal atresia) are all suggestive of trisomy 21 (Down syndrome).

questions.text:
A 2-week-old newborn is brought to the physician because of worsening feeding difficulty since birth. Examination shows a grade 2/6 harsh holosystolic murmur, heard most clearly at the left lower sternal border, and a soft mid-diastolic rumble over the cardiac apex. Echocardiography shows shunting of blood through the ventricular septum during systole. The patient undergoes surgery for closure of the defect. Which of the following sets of changes are expected after successful repair of this cardiac defect?



Left atrial pressure
Left ventricular pressure
Right ventricular pressure



A
↓
↑
no change


B
↓
↑
↓


C
↑
↑
↑


D
↓
↓
↓


E
↑
↑
↓
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Mitral stenosis (MS) causes a left atrial outflow obstruction. The left atrium has to contract against the partially closed mitral valve, which results in an increased left atrial pressure. Once repaired, left atrial outflow increases, thereby decreasing the left atrial pressure. The left ventricular input increases, thereby increasing the left ventricular pressure. The right ventricular pressure remains unchanged. These hemodynamic changes would not, however, be expected after the closure of a VSD.

B) CORRECT:

A VSD causes left-to-right shunting of blood because the left ventricular pressure is physiologically higher than the right ventricular pressure due to the thicker ventricular wall and higher force of contraction. Closure of a VSD would, therefore, increase the amount of blood in the left ventricle and decrease the amount of blood in the right ventricle during each cardiac cycle. This results in an increase in left ventricular pressure and a decrease in right ventricular pressure as well as right ventricular output, which translates to a decrease in the amount of blood flowing into the left atrium and therefore a decrease in left atrial pressure.
Image Description:

A defect in the ventricular septum leads to a left-to-right shunt, the volume of which is dependent on the size of the defect. Blood flows from the left ventricle to the right ventricle (white arrow) along the pressure gradient (1). This leads to increased RV and LV preload (due to increased end-diastolic volume), ventricular hypertrophy and dilation (double-headed white arrows), and pulmonary hypertension resulting from excessive pulmonary blood flow (2). In end-stage disease, the pressure gradient is reversed because of Eisenmenger syndrome (shunt reversal), leading to the flow of mixed blood to the systemic circulation (white arrow) and subsequent cyanosis (3).

Blue: structures that contain deoxygenated blood; Red: structures that contain oxygenated blood; Purple: structures that contain mixed blood

C) INCORRECT:

An increase in the pressure of all the chambers of the heart would be expected following fluid resuscitation in patients with hypovolemic shock. These hemodynamic changes would not be expected after the closure of a VSD.

D) INCORRECT:

A decrease in the pressure in all the chambers of the heart would be expected following pericardiotomy for constrictive pericarditis or following aspiration of a hemopericardium. These hemodynamic changes would not be expected after the closure of a VSD.

E) INCORRECT:

Both atrial septal defect repair, which stops shunting of blood from the left atrium to the right atrium, and pulmonary stenosis repair, which removes the right ventricular outflow obstruction, would decrease right ventricular pressure and increase left atrial as well as left ventricular pressure by increasing the amount of blood in the left side of the heart. These hemodynamic changes would not, however, be expected after the closure of a VSD.
questions.hint: The newborn presented with symptoms of decreased cardiac output (poor feeding) and heart murmurs; he was found to have a ventricular septal defect (VSD), which allowed for abnormal shunting of blood from the left to the right ventricle. Successful repair of this defect will restore normal cardiac output.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician for a follow-up examination after having undergone extensive workup of a heart murmur that was detected on routine examination. Results of hemodynamic studies performed during cardiac catheterization show:



Oxygen saturation (%)
Pressure (mm Hg)



Right atrium
74
6


Right ventricle
85
40/10


Truncus pulmonalis
85
35/20


Left atrium
98
10


Left ventricle
98
110/10


Ascending aorta
98
105/65



This patient's murmur is most likely caused by which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:
