This patient's hemodynamic studies indicate a ventricular septal defect (VSD). Due to a left-to-right shunt, oxygen-rich blood flows from the left ventricle into the right ventricle during systole. This causes increased oxygen saturation and increased blood pressure in the right ventricle and truncus pulmonalis. Since the shunt is at the level of the ventricles, the right atrium maintains normal oxygenation and pressure, as seen here. The classic murmur is a harsh, holosystolic murmur that is loudest at the left lower sternal border; it is typically louder with smaller defects. Patients are often asymptomatic and spontaneous closure of small VSDs frequently occurs. Surgical interventions are rarely necessary.

In larger heart defects, long-term complications such as endocarditis, arrhythmias, aortic regurgitation, right heart failure, and Eisenmenger reaction are possible.
Image Description:

A defect in the ventricular septum leads to a left-to-right shunt, the volume of which is dependent on the size of the defect. Blood flows from the left ventricle to the right ventricle (white arrow) along the pressure gradient (1). This leads to increased RV and LV preload (due to increased end-diastolic volume), ventricular hypertrophy and dilation (double-headed white arrows), and pulmonary hypertension resulting from excessive pulmonary blood flow (2). In end-stage disease, the pressure gradient is reversed because of Eisenmenger syndrome (shunt reversal), leading to the flow of mixed blood to the systemic circulation (white arrow) and subsequent cyanosis (3).

Blue: structures that contain deoxygenated blood; Red: structures that contain oxygenated blood; Purple: structures that contain mixed blood

B) INCORRECT:

Atrial septal defects (ASD) result in blood flow from the left atrium to the right atrium. ASDs typically manifest with systolic ejection murmurs over the left second intercostal space and are usually asymptomatic during childhood and adolescence. Although an ASD would also lead to increased blood pressure in the right heart, the right atrium would be affected in addition to the right ventricle and truncus pulmonalis. Additionally, the oxygen saturation would be increased in the right atrium, right ventricle, and truncus, while the oxygen saturation in this patient's right atrium was normal.
Image Description:

An atrial septal defect causes blood to flow from the left to the right atrium (left-to-right shunt; white arrow), resulting in volume overload of the right atrium and ventricle (1). As a result, there is dilation and compensatory hypertrophy (double-headed white arrows) of the right atrium and ventricle (2). In the late stages, Eisenmenger syndrome with shunt reversal (right-to-left shunt; white arrow) and cyanosis can occur (3).

Blue: structures that contain deoxygenated blood; Red: structures that contain oxygenated blood; Purple: structures that contain mixed blood

C) INCORRECT:

Coarctation of the aorta results in higher resistance to left ventricular outflow. Patients with small defects can also be asymptomatic and present with a heart murmur in the left paravertebral region. However, the aortic outflow obstruction would increase the pressure in the left ventricle rather than in the right ventricle and truncus pulmonalis. Additionally, oxygen saturation throughout the heart would be normal, whereas this patient has an increased oxygen saturation in the right ventricle and truncus pulmonalis.
Image Description:

(1) Stenosis distal to the left subclavian artery results in hypertension (↑ BP) in the upper extremities and the head, and hypotension (↓ BP) in the lower extremities and abdomen.

(2) If coarctation involves the origin of the left subclavian artery, BP in the right arm and head will be higher than in the left arm, lower extremities, and abdomen.

D) INCORRECT:

In a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), blood shunts from the aorta to the pulmonary arteries. Patients with PDA can also be asymptomatic and present with a heart murmur, which is typically continuous (“machinery murmur”) and heard best over the left infraclavicular region. A PDA would also lead to increased oxygen saturation in the truncus pulmonalis because of the direct connection with the aorta. However, oxygen saturation of the right ventricle would be normal rather than increased. Moreover, the pressure in the truncus pulmonalis would be increased more than the right ventricular pressure, which is not the case here.
Image Description:

In patent ductus arteriosus, there is a left-to-right shunt, with blood flowing from the aorta to the pulmonary arteries during both systole and diastole (1). This shunt leads to volume overload (recirculation) of the blood within the pulmonary vessels, the left atrium, and left ventricle (2). Eventually, because of the increased blood flow to the pulmonary circulation, pulmonary hypertension may develop as well as Eisenmenger syndrome, which involves a shunt reversal. The left-to-right-shunt without cyanosis becomes a right-to-left shunt with cyanosis (3).

Blue: structures that contain deoxygenated blood; Red: structures that contain oxygenated blood; Pink: structures that contain mixed blood

E) INCORRECT:

Transposition of the great vessels (TGV) is caused by an anatomical reversal of the aorta and the pulmonary artery, which connects the right ventricle to the systemic circulation and the left ventricle to the pulmonary circulation. While the oxygen saturation in the left atrium, left ventricle, and truncus pulmonalis would be high, the aorta and entire right heart would be low in oxygen. This condition is typically evident at birth and requires immediate surgical repair; TGV is an unlikely diagnosis in an asymptomatic 3-year-old boy. Additionally, pressures would generally be higher in the right heart than in the left heart because of the connection to the systemic circulation.
Image Description:

TGV is a cyanotic congenital heart disease in which the pulmonary artery arises from the left ventricle and the aorta from the right ventricle, resulting in the formation of parallel circulatory systems. The left ventricle pumps oxygenated blood into the pulmonary circulation (red) and the right ventricle pumps deoxygenated blood into the aorta (blue), resulting in cyanosis.

TGV is fatal unless a shunt between the two circulations is present (i.e., a patent ductus arteriosus or a patent foramen ovale) or a surgical intervention is performed in the neonatal period.
questions.hint: This patient has an increased oxygen saturation and increased blood pressure in the right ventricle and truncus pulmonalis.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 24 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a routine prenatal evaluation. She has no history of major medical illness and takes no medications. Fetal ultrasonography shows a cardiac defect resulting from abnormal development of the endocardial cushions. This defect is most likely to result in which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tetralogy of Fallot is characterized by right ventricular outflow tract obstruction due to pulmonary valve stenosis, right ventricular hypertrophy, a ventricular septal defect, and an overriding aorta above the ventricular septal defect. The underlying pathology is thought to be a malpositioned infundibular septum. Abnormal development of the endocardial cushions does not cause tetralogy of Fallot.

B) CORRECT:

In normal cardiac development, the superior and inferior endocardial cushions fuse to form the atrioventricular canal and parts of the atrioventricular valves. Abnormal development of the endocardial cushions causes atrioventricular septal defects (AVSDs), the most common of which is an ostium secundum atrial septal defect. In mild cases of AVSD, patients can have septal defects with separate atria and ventricles. In severe cases, patients can have a common atrioventricular canal (i.e., combined atrial septal defect and ventricular septal defect) with a single atrioventricular valve.

C) INCORRECT:

Sinus venosus defects result from abnormal resorption of the sinus venosus during cardiac development. This causes malpositioning of the superior vena cava or inferior vena cava in relation to the right atrium and is associated with the development of abnormal connections between the pulmonary veins and the right atrium. Abnormal development of the endocardial cushions does not cause sinus venosus defects.

D) INCORRECT:

Transposition of the great vessels results from failure of the aorticopulmonary septum to undergo a spiral transformation. The aorta and pulmonary trunk are attached to the right and left ventricles, respectively, prior to spiral transformation of the septum. Following transformation, the aorta is attached to the left ventricle, and the pulmonary trunk is attached to the right ventricle. If this process fails, the pulmonary circulation and systemic circulation function as completely separate parallel circuits, and oxygenated blood cannot pass into the systemic circulation. To sustain life, oxygenated and deoxygenated blood must mix through associated cardiac defects (e.g., atrial septal defects, ventricular septal defects, patent ductus arteriosus). Abnormal development of the endocardial cushions does not cause transposition of the great vessels.

E) INCORRECT:

Dextrocardia is an abnormal orientation of the heart in which the apex is located to the right aspect of the mediastinum rather than the left. It is often associated with situs inversus and is caused by a defect in dynein (e.g., from Kartagener syndrome). Abnormal development of the endocardial cushions does not cause dextrocardia.

F) INCORRECT:

A patent foramen ovale results from failure of fusion of the septum primum and septum secundum, which typically occurs after birth. Abnormal development of the endocardial cushions does not cause a patent foramen ovale.
questions.hint: Down syndrome is associated with endocardial cushion defects.

questions.text:
A 3-month-old boy is brought to the physician for a routine follow-up examination. He was delivered at 32 weeks' gestation to a 35-year-old woman. Cardiac examination is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause for this patient's findings?
Video
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) manifests with a continuous machinery murmur best heard in the left infraclavicular area. The machinery murmur is generated as blood continuously shunts from the high-pressure aorta through the ductus arteriosus into the low-pressure pulmonary artery. It may envelop the S2 and is not usually affected by positional changes. Patients with moderate-sized PDAs may present with bounding pulses, widened pulse pressure, and symptoms of heart failure.
Image Description:

Continuous systolic and diastolic heart murmur (machinery murmur)

B) INCORRECT:

Ventricular septal defects (VSD) manifest with holosystolic, harsh sounding murmurs, best heard in the left lower sternal border. These murmurs often obliterate the S2 and are associated with a palpable thrill. Neonates present with an asymptomatic heart murmur or, in cases of moderate-to-large sized defects, with signs of heart failure. The examination findings in this patient reveal a continuous machinery murmur in the left upper sternal border, which is not suggestive of a VSD.

C) INCORRECT:

Atrial septal defects (ASD) manifest with pulmonary outflow tract murmurs heard best at the left upper sternal border and are often associated with fixed splitting of S2. ASDs are often low-velocity shunts that produce insufficient flow to be audible. Larger shunts may cause diastolic flow murmurs across the tricuspid valve owing to a large left-to-right shunt. However, the continuous machinery murmur would not be seen in patients with an ASD.

D) INCORRECT:

Mitral valve prolapse (MVP) is associated with a late systolic crescendo murmur with a midsystolic click heard best at the apex. The examination findings of a continuous machinery murmur in the left upper sternal border, such as that observed in this patient, would not be seen in patients with MVP.
Image Description:

High-frequency, mid-systolic click with a late systolic crescendo murmur.

E) INCORRECT:

Persistent truncus arteriosus results in a single conduit providing mixed venous and arterial blood to the coronary, pulmonary, and systemic circulations. Cardiac exam findings would include a single loud S2, the presence of an ejection click at the cardiac apex or left sternal border, and harsh systolic murmurs at the left sternal border, unlike the continuous machinery murmur heard in this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) is associated with a harsh crescendo-decrescendo murmur best heard along the left mid- to upper-sternal border. The murmur can decrease in intensity as the degree of right ventricular outflow tract obstruction worsens because of increased right-to-left shunting of blood. The examination findings of a continuous machinery murmur in the left upper sternal border, such as that observed in this patient, would not be seen in patients with TOF.
questions.hint: Auscultation shows a continuous murmur. This finding is associated with a condition that affects premature infants or infants with a congenital rubella infection.

questions.text:
A 2-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother for a well-child examination. Cardiac auscultation is shown. When she clenches her fist forcefully for a sustained time, the intensity of the murmur increases. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's auscultation findings?
Video

choices.text: Fusion of the right and left coronary leaflets
Asymmetric hypertrophy of the left ventricle
Failure of the ductus arteriosus to close

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Mitral valve prolapse leads to a systolic murmur heard best at the cardiac apex (5th intercostal space in the midclavicular line). This murmur is a late systolic crescendo character, and it is preceded by a click due to tensing of the chordae tendinae. Furthermore, unlike what's seen here, maneuvers that increase afterload (e.g., handgrip), decrease rather than increase the intensity of the murmur associated with mitral valve prolapse.

B) INCORRECT:

Fusion of the right and left coronary leaflets of the aortic valve is the pathologic process that underlies a bicuspid aortic valve, which can lead to a systolic murmur caused by aortic stenosis (AS). A murmur caused by AS is heard best at the right upper sternal border. In addition, this murmur has a crescendo-decrescendo character, and it decreases in intensity with maneuvers that increase left ventricular afterload (e.g., handgrip).

C) INCORRECT:

An atrial septal defect can cause a systolic murmur because of increased flow across the pulmonary valve, but the murmur is heard best at the left upper sternal border. In addition, this murmur has a midsystolic crescendo-decrescendo character, and it is accompanied by a wide, fixed split second heart sound.

D) INCORRECT:

Asymmetric left ventricular hypertrophy is seen in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, which can cause a murmur as a result of mitral regurgitation (MR) or left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction. A murmur due to MR is holosystolic, and it increases in intensity with maneuvers that increase left ventricular afterload (e.g., handgrip), but this murmur is heard best at the cardiac apex (5th intercostal space in the midclavicular line). A murmur due to LVOT obstruction is heard best at the left lower sternal border, but this murmur has a midsystolic, crescendo-decrescendo character, and it decreases in intensity with maneuvers that increase left ventricular afterload.

E) CORRECT:

A ventricular septal defect (VSD), which causes a left-to-right shunt, leads to a harsh holosystolic murmur because of turbulent blood flow across the defect. The murmur is heard best at the left lower sternal border (tricuspid area) and becomes louder with maneuvers that increase left ventricular afterload (e.g., handgrip) because of increased left-to-right shunting. The murmur is typically louder with smaller defects as blood rushes through a smaller space. Eventually, a VSD can lead to pulmonary hypertension and a reversal in blood flow (Eisenmenger syndrome), in which case the murmur may disappear or no longer become louder with increased LV afterload because of a countering right-to-left shunting.
Image Description:

Holosystolic murmur (often referred to as “pansystolic murmur” in the case of a ventricular septal defect)

F) INCORRECT:

The failure of the ductus arteriosus to close (patent ductus arteriosus) leads to a murmur heard best at the left infraclavicular region. This murmur occurs during both diastole and systole (i.e., a continuous murmur), unlike the harsh holosystolic murmur seen here.
questions.hint: The handgrip maneuver increases afterload by increasing total peripheral resistance.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his father for a well-child examination. He recently emigrated from Mexico with his family and has not seen a physician since birth. Vital signs are within normal limits. Cardiac examination shows a harsh, grade 3/6 holosystolic murmur heard best at the left lower sternal border. During deep inspiration, the second heart sound is split. If left untreated, irreversible changes would most likely be seen in which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Irreversible enlargement of the right atrium can be caused by an untreated tricuspid regurgitation (e.g., due to Ebstein anomaly), tricuspid stenosis/atresia, or atrial septal defect (ASD). Tricuspid regurgitation would cause a holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border (LLSB), as seen here, but the patient would also have features of right heart failure (e.g., increased JVP, hepatomegaly, ascites), unlike this asymptomatic patient. The murmur due to tricuspid stenosis would also be heard at the LLSB but the murmur would be a diastolic, not systolic. The murmur due to an ASD would be a systolic ejection murmur that is best heard at the upper (not lower!) left sternal border and it would be associated with a fixed split in S2, unlike this patient with a normal inspiratory split of S2. This patient most likely has an isolated VSD, which is associated with irreversible changes in a different structure.

B) INCORRECT:

Irreversible coarctation or atresia of the ascending aorta is associated with certain congenital disorders such as bicuspid aortic valve and hypoplastic left heart syndrome (HLHS). A bicuspid aortic valve can cause an asymptomatic systolic murmur due to aortic stenosis but such a murmur would be a mid-to-late systolic murmur and it would be best heard at the right upper sternal border (aortic area). Patients with HLHS can have a systolic murmur due to the atrial septal defect associated with HLHS but such a murmur would be a systolic ejection murmur that is best heard at the upper (not lower!) left sternal border and it would be associated with a fixed split in S2, unlike this patient with a normal inspiratory split of S2. Moreover, patients with HLHS would present with cyanosis and features of heart failure shortly after birth, unlike this asymptomatic patient. This patient most likely has an isolated VSD, which does not cause irreversible changes in the ascending aorta.

C) INCORRECT:

Irreversible stenosis of the superior vena cava (SVC) is a rare congenital condition that manifests with features of superior vena cava syndrome (e.g., facial plethora, edema of the face and upper extremities) at birth, not an asymptomatic murmur, as seen here. This patient most likely has a VSD, which does not cause irreversible changes in the SVC.

D) CORRECT:

A VSD is characterized by a left-to-right shunt, leading to reduced cardiac output despite increased left ventricular load and pulmonary blood flow. Oxygenated blood from the left ventricle re-enters the pulmonary system, increasing pulmonary artery and right ventricular pressure, which leads to hypertrophy in those two areas. The irreversible thickening and narrowing of the pulmonic vasculature cause pulmonary hypertension. In the late stage of the disease, due to irreversible pulmonary hypertension, the right ventricle pressure increases until it exceeds the left ventricular pressure, causing a shunt reversal (Eisenmenger reaction).
Image Description:

A defect in the ventricular septum leads to a left-to-right shunt, the volume of which is dependent on the size of the defect. Blood flows from the left ventricle to the right ventricle (white arrow) along the pressure gradient (1). This leads to increased RV and LV preload (due to increased end-diastolic volume), ventricular hypertrophy and dilation (double-headed white arrows), and pulmonary hypertension resulting from excessive pulmonary blood flow (2). In end-stage disease, the pressure gradient is reversed because of Eisenmenger syndrome (shunt reversal), leading to the flow of mixed blood to the systemic circulation (white arrow) and subsequent cyanosis (3).

Blue: structures that contain deoxygenated blood; Red: structures that contain oxygenated blood; Purple: structures that contain mixed blood

E) INCORRECT:

Irreversible fibrosis and stenosis of the mitral valve are seen in rheumatic heart disease, which is a chronic complication of rheumatic fever. Mitral regurgitation, which manifests with a holosystolic murmur, is the most common valve defect associated with rheumatic fever and this patient's migrant background is a risk factor for rheumatic fever. However, murmurs due to mitral valve disease are best heard at the cardiac apex, not at the left lower sternal border, and this child has no features to suggest rheumatic fever (e.g., fever, history of recent pharyngitis). Moreover, rheumatic fever is uncommon in children below the age of 5 years. This patient most likely has a VSD, which is not associated with irreversible changes in the mitral valve.
questions.hint: A harsh holosystolic murmur heard along the left lower sternal border with normal splitting is suggestive of a ventricular septal defect (VSD), the most common congenital heart defect.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of headaches and frequent episodes of bleeding from her nose. Over the past 2 months, she has had shortness of breath and intermittent leg pain while jogging. She has no history of previous illnesses. Her father died of myocardial infarction at the age of 52 years. She smokes one-half pack of cigarettes daily and occasionally used methamphetamines and cocaine during college, but she has not used illicit drugs for the past 5 years. She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 63 kg (140 lb); BMI is 24 kg/m2. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 168/110 mm Hg. Physical examination shows decreased femoral pulses compared to the brachial pulses. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
14.2 g/dL


Serum



 Na+

142 mEq/L


 K+

3.6 mEq/L


 Cl-

99 mEq/L


 Urea nitrogen
18 mg/dL


 Creatinine
1.1 mg/dL


An ECG shows prominent R waves in leads V5 and V6 and deep S waves in leads V1 and V2. An x-ray of the chest shows enlargement of the cardiac silhouette and erosions of the inferior aspects of the 4th through 8th ribs bilaterally. Which of the following is the most appropriate study to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cardiac catheterization is a diagnostic and/or therapeutic procedure for several cardiac conditions, including coarctation of the aorta, which this patient has. However, cardiac catheterization is an invasive procedure and is more typically reserved for cases in which a concurrent intervention is expected or evaluation for concurrent coronary artery disease is needed.

B) INCORRECT:

The ankle-brachial index would be decreased in patients with arterial insufficiency of the lower extremities but the ankle-brachial index cannot be used to determine the underlying cause of arterial insufficiency. A different diagnostic step is necessary to establish the diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Renal duplex ultrasonography is the imaging test of choice for evaluating renal artery stenosis. Although this patient's secondary hypertension is also due to a vascular source, she does not have an abdominal bruit or hypokalemia (secondary to release of renin) that are characteristic of renal artery stenosis. Moreover, renal artery stenosis does not explain her x-ray finding of rib notching.

D) CORRECT:

Doppler echocardiography is the test of choice for diagnosing aortic coarctation. In addition to echocardiography, which provides dynamic imaging of the heart and can detect concurrent anomalies, Doppler helps to localize the coarctation and estimate its severity. This patient's clinical features such as features of arterial insufficiency in the lower extremities (e.g., intermittent claudication during physical activity, decreased femoral pulses), features of brachiocephalic hypertension (e.g., headache, epistaxis), and evidence of collateral circulation (rib notching on x-ray) are consistent with the presentation of aortic coarctation in adulthood. Moreover, this patient is now experiencing sequelae of untreated aortic coarctation such as left ventricular hypertrophy (as evidenced by her ECG findings) due to left ventricular outflow tract obstruction and dyspnea due to heart failure.

E) INCORRECT:

Measurement of metanephrines in 24-hour urine is the confirmatory test of choice for pheochromocytoma. Hypertension and headaches in a young patient may be consistent with pheochromocytoma, but this type of tumor does not explain this patient's lower extremity claudication with exertion and rib notching on x-ray. Moreover, this patient does not have other characteristic symptoms of pheochromocytoma, including paroxysmal diaphoresis and palpitations.

F) INCORRECT:

Urine toxicology screening for cocaine can help in the assessment for an alternative cause of secondary hypertension, headaches, epistaxis, and heart failure. However, cocaine use would not explain this patient's lower extremity claudication with exertion and rib notching seen on x-ray.

G) INCORRECT:

Monitoring of 24-hour blood pressure can be used to diagnose hypertension. While this patient is hypertensive, blood pressure monitoring would not help identify the underlying etiology of this patient's secondary hypertension. She has a constellation of clinical features, including lower extremity claudication with exertion, rib notching on x-ray, and heart failure at a young age, that would be difficult to explain by isolated hypertension.
questions.hint: This disease is also often seen in individuals with Takayasu arteritis.

questions.text: A 3-week-old female newborn is brought to the emergency department because of a 4-day history of bluish discoloration of the feet, poor feeding, excessive sweating, and irritability. She was born at term following an uncomplicated pregnancy and spontaneous vaginal delivery. Examination following delivery showed no abnormalities and she was discharged two days later. She is exclusively breastfed. She appears ill. She is at the 70th percentile for length and 20th percentile for weight. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 168/min, and respirations are 66/min. Her blood pressure is 91/69 mm Hg in the right arm, 90/70 mm Hg in the left arm, 72/67 mm Hg in the right lower limb, and 70/68 mm Hg in the left lower limb. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98% in the right hand and 78% in the right foot. On examination, subcostal retractions are seen and the liver is palpated 4 cm below the right costal margin. Chest auscultation discloses fine crepitations in both lung fields and a grade 3/6 systolic murmur heard best at the left paravertebral interscapular area. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Caudal displacement of the tricuspid valve
Narrowing of the ascending aorta at the sinotubular junction
Narrowing of the descending aorta near the ligamentum arteriosum
Failure of the aorticopulmonary septum to form
Anterosuperior displacement of the infundibular septum
Failure of the aorticopulmonary septum to spiral

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Caudal displacement of the tricuspid valve is seen in Ebstein anomaly, which can manifest with cyanosis, heart failure, and a systolic murmur. However, the systolic murmur in Ebstein anomaly is caused by tricuspid regurgitation and is heard best at the left sternal border rather than the left paravertebral interscapular area. Moreover, blood pressure and oxygen saturation differentials between the upper and lower extremities would not be expected.

B) INCORRECT:

Narrowing of the ascending aorta at the sinotubular junction is seen in supravalvular aortic stenosis, which can manifest with a systolic murmur and heart failure. However, the systolic murmur in supravalvular aortic stenosis is heard best at the 1st right intercostal space rather than the left paravertebral interscapular area. Furthermore, blood pressure and oxygen saturation differentials would not be expected. This patient has a fixed left ventricular outflow tract obstruction that is located at the aortic isthmus.

C) CORRECT:

This patient's differential cyanosis and blood pressure differential between the upper and lower extremities, in conjunction with a systolic murmur over the left interscapular space (due to blood flow through the aortic narrowing), suggest coarctation of the aorta (CoA). In CoA, the narrowing of the thoracic segment of the descending aorta near the ligamentum arteriosum (aortic isthmus) causes an increased blood flow proximal to the narrowing and a decreased blood flow distal to the narrowing, resulting in blood pressure and oxygen saturation differentials like those seen in this patient. Newborns can remain asymptomatic until the closure of the ductus arteriosus (DA), after which there is an increase in left ventricular pressure and volume overload that results in heart failure.
Image Description:

(1) Stenosis distal to the left subclavian artery results in hypertension (↑ BP) in the upper extremities and the head, and hypotension (↓ BP) in the lower extremities and abdomen.

(2) If coarctation involves the origin of the left subclavian artery, BP in the right arm and head will be higher than in the left arm, lower extremities, and abdomen.

D) INCORRECT:

A failure of the aorticopulmonary septum to form is the cause of persistent truncus arteriosus, which manifests with cyanosis and heart failure. However, cyanosis as a result of this condition is not confined to the lower extremities and blood pressure and oxygen saturation differentials between the upper and lower extremities would not be expected.

E) INCORRECT:

Anterosuperior displacement of the infundibular septum is seen in tetralogy of Fallot (TOF), which can manifest with cyanosis and a systolic murmur. However, the systolic murmur in TOF is mainly caused by right ventricular outflow obstruction and is heard best at the left upper sternal border rather than the left paravertebral interscapular area. Furthermore, cyanosis is not confined to the lower extremities and blood pressure and oxygen saturation differentials between the upper and lower extremities would not be expected.

F) INCORRECT:

A failure of the aorticopulmonary septum to spiral is the cause of transposition of the great vessels (TGV), which manifests with cyanosis and tachypnea. However, cyanosis from TGV is typically evident in the first hours after birth unless intracardiac left-right shunting (e.g., patent ductus arteriosus, atrial septal defect) allows for oxygenated blood to enter the systemic circulation. Moreover, patients with TGV may present with reverse differential cyanosis but differential cyanosis, hypoxemia confined to the lower extremities, and blood pressure differential between the upper and lower extremities would not be expected.
questions.hint: This neonate presents with features of congestive heart failure including poor feeding, excessive diaphoresis, irritability, respiratory distress, pulmonary edema, and hepatomegaly. The underlying condition is also often seen in patients with Turner syndrome.

questions.text:
A 1-hour-old male newborn is examined in the hospital nursery. He was born at 35 weeks' gestation to a 27-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1. The mother has not had routine prenatal care. She reports having a self-limiting reddish rash that started on her face and spread to her trunk and limbs as well as joint pain in her hands, wrists, and ankles 2 weeks into the pregnancy. Cardiac examination of the newborn is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Video
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Atrial septal defects (ASD) manifest with a pulmonary flow murmur (systolic ejection murmur) heard best at the left upper sternal border and are often associated with fixed splitting of S2. ASDs are often low-velocity shunts that produce insufficient flow to be audible. Larger shunts may cause diastolic flow murmurs across the tricuspid valve owing to a large left-to-right shunt. However, the continuous machinery murmur would not be seen in patients with an ASD.

B) INCORRECT:

Persistent truncus arteriosus (PTA) results in a single conduit providing mixed venous and arterial blood to the coronary, pulmonary, and systemic circulations. Cardiac exam findings of PTA would include a single loud S2 and the presence of an ejection click at the cardiac apex or left sternal border. Accentuated and bounding peripheral pulses might also be present. However, patients with an unrepaired defect present with harsh systolic murmurs at the left sternal border, unlike the continuous machinery murmur heard in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) is associated with a harsh crescendo-decrescendo murmur best heard along the left mid- to upper-sternal border. The murmur can decrease in intensity as the degree of right ventricular outflow tract obstruction worsens because of increased right-to-left shunting of blood. The examination findings of a continuous machinery murmur in the left upper sternal border, such as that observed in this patient, would not be seen in patients with TOF.

D) CORRECT:

The murmur of a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) is generated as blood continuously shunts from the high-pressure aorta through the ductus arteriosus into the low-pressure pulmonary artery. It may envelop the S2 and is not usually affected by positional changes. Patients with moderate-sized PDAs may present with bounding pulses, widened pulse pressure, and symptoms of heart failure.

This condition affects infants who are born prematurely and/or have congenital rubella infection (CRI). CRI is likely in this newborn given that the mother had features of rubella infection (e.g., an erythematous exanthem that began on the face, polyarthritis). The most common congenital heart defects associated with CRI are PDA and pulmonary stenosis. Pulmonary stenosis causes a systolic ejection murmur at the left upper sternal border.

E) INCORRECT:

Mitral valve prolapse (MVP) is associated with a late systolic crescendo murmur with a midsystolic click heard best at the apex. The examination findings of a continuous machinery murmur in the left upper sternal border, such as that observed in this patient, would not be seen in patients with MVP.

F) INCORRECT:

Ventricular septal defects (VSDs) manifest with holosystolic, harsh-sounding murmurs, best heard in the left lower sternal border. These murmurs often obliterate the S2 and are associated with a palpable thrill. The examination findings in this patient reveal a continuous machinery murmur in the left upper sternal border, which is not suggestive of a VSD.
questions.hint: Auscultation shows a continuous murmur that is best heard at the left upper sternal border (i.e., near the left infraclavicular region) and has a machine-like quality.

questions.text:
A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother for a well-child examination. He feels well. He was born at 40 weeks' gestation and weighed 3100 g (6 lb 13 oz). There is no personal or family history of serious illness. His immunizations are up-to-date. He is at 70th percentile for height and 55th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Cardiac auscultation is shown. When he clenches his fist forcefully for a sustained time, the intensity of the murmur increases. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Video
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Aortic stenosis (AS) can lead to a systolic murmur, as seen in this patient. However, a murmur caused by AS is heard best at the right upper sternal border. In addition, this murmur has a crescendo-decrescendo character, and it decreases in intensity with maneuvers that increase left ventricular afterload (e.g., handgrip).

B) INCORRECT:

Patent ductus arteriosus leads to a murmur heard best at the left infraclavicular region. This murmur occurs during both diastole and systole (i.e., a continuous murmur), unlike the harsh holosystolic murmur seen here.

C) INCORRECT:

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy can cause a murmur as a result of mitral regurgitation (MR) or left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction. A murmur due to MR is holosystolic and increases in intensity with maneuvers that increase left ventricular afterload (e.g., handgrip) but is heard best at the cardiac apex (5th intercostal space in the midclavicular line). A murmur due to LVOT obstruction is heard best at the left lower sternal border but has a midsystolic, crescendo-decrescendo character and decreases in intensity with maneuvers that increase left ventricular afterload.

D) CORRECT:

A ventricular septal defect (VSD), which causes a left-to-right shunt, leads to a harsh holosystolic murmur because of turbulent blood flow across the defect. The murmur is heard best at the left lower sternal border (tricuspid area) and becomes louder with maneuvers that increase left ventricular afterload (e.g., handgrip) because of increased left-to-right shunting. The murmur is typically louder with smaller defects as blood rushes through a smaller space. Eventually, a VSD can lead to pulmonary hypertension and a reversal in blood flow (Eisenmenger syndrome), in which case the murmur may disappear or no longer become louder with increased LV afterload because of a countering right-to-left shunting.
Image Description:

Holosystolic murmur (often referred to as “pansystolic murmur” in the case of a ventricular septal defect)

E) INCORRECT:

Mitral valve prolapse leads to a systolic murmur that increases in intensity with maneuvers that increase afterload (e.g., handgrip), which is seen here. However, this murmur is heard best at the cardiac apex (5th intercostal space in the midclavicular line). In addition, this murmur has a late systolic crescendo character, and it is preceded by a click due to tensing of the chordae tendinae.

F) INCORRECT:

An atrial septal defect can cause a systolic murmur because of increased flow across the pulmonary valve, but the murmur is heard best at the left upper sternal border. In addition, this murmur has a midsystolic crescendo-decrescendo character, and it is accompanied by a wide, fixed split second heart sound.
questions.hint: The handgrip maneuver increases afterload by increasing total peripheral resistance.

questions.text: A 2-day-old male newborn is evaluated in the neonatal intensive care unit because of irritability and feeding difficulty. He was born at 35 weeks' gestation to a 30-year-old woman following an uncomplicated delivery. He is awake and alert. He is at the 4th percentile for length and weight. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 160/min, respirations are 55/min, and blood pressure is 85/55 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. Cardiac examination discloses a 3/6 continuous murmur best heard in the left infraclavicular region. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Laboratory studies show no abnormalities. Echocardiography shows blood flow between the pulmonary artery and descending aorta. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Nonselective cyclooxygenase inhibitors such as ibuprofen and indomethacin are the mainstay of treatment for symptomatic PDA in premature infants. Prostaglandins keep the ductus arteriosus patent, and by inhibiting cyclooxygenase, NSAIDs decrease prostaglandin production and thus promote ductal closure. NSAIDs are only effective in preterm infants.

Transcatheter or surgical closure is the treatment of choice for infants ≥ 6 kg, children, and adults. In preterm infants, procedural closure is generally only used if pharmacological treatment is unsuccessful.

B) INCORRECT:

Digoxin can be used for symptomatic management of heart failure in full-term infants with a large PDA who weigh < 5 kg. However, it would not correct the underlying cause of this patient's heart failure (PDA). In addition, this infant is preterm, and thus requires a different therapeutic approach.

C) INCORRECT:

Hydrochlorothiazide can be used in preterm infants with a large PDA for symptomatic management. Although it can provide symptomatic relief, it would not address the underlying cause of heart failure in this patient (PDA).

D) INCORRECT:

Prostaglandin E1 (PGE1) is indicated in patients with ductal-dependent congenital heart diseases (CHDs) in order to maintain ductus arteriosus patency before surgery can be performed. However, ductal-dependent CHDs typically manifest at birth with pronounced cyanosis. This patient's murmur and normal pulse oximetry reading are suggestive of an isolated PDA, which means that prostaglandins are contraindicated.

E) INCORRECT:

Furosemide is the preferred treatment for the management of heart failure in full-term infants with PDA who weigh < 5 kg. However, it would not address the underlying cause of heart failure in this patient (PDA). In addition, this infant is preterm and thus requires a different therapeutic approach.
questions.hint: Features of heart failure (e.g., irritability, poor feeding, failure to thrive) with a continuous murmur in the left infraclavicular region are highly suggestive of a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), for which premature birth is a risk factor. The echocardiography findings confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text:
Patient Information
Age: 57 years
Gender: M, self-identified
Race/Ethnicity: unspecified
Site of Care: emergency department 
History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: “I think my husband is having a stroke.”
History of Present Illness:

patient brought by his wife, who found him lying on the ground

drooping mouth and difficulty moving the right arm and speaking in grammatically correct, fluent sentences for the past hour
language understanding is unaffected and can communicate with gestures 
pain in the right leg while walking

Past Medical History:


4-year history of Crohn disease; started therapy with infliximab 11 months ago
hospitalized for acute flare with fever, abdominal pain, and malaise 2 weeks ago; treated with oral prednisolone
occasional migraines

Medications:

infliximab
acetaminophen as needed
sumatriptan as needed

Vaccinations:
up-to-date
Allergies:
no known drug allergies
Family History:

father: diagnosed with Crohn disease at age 21 years

mother: deceased at age 64 years from myocardial infarction

Psychosocial History:

has smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for 15 years

does not drink alcoholic beverages, or use nonprescribed medications or other substances

Physical Examination


Temp
Pulse

BP
O2 Sat
Ht
Wt

36.9°C(98.4°F)
90/min
16/min
145/80 mm Hg
98% on RA
185 cm(6 ft 1 in)
80 kg(176 lb)
23 kg/m2




Appearance: alert and oriented; visibly anxious and frustrated
HEENT: PERRLA; gaze dominance to the left; drooping mouth on the right; eyebrows can be lifted and eyelids can be closed completely bilaterally
Neck: no jugular venous distention; no carotid bruit
Pulmonary: clear to auscultation
Cardiac: normal S1 and S2 with no murmurs, rubs, or gallops
Abdominal: nondistended; normoactive bowel sounds; soft, nontender
Extremities: swelling, red-purple discoloration, and pain in the right lower extremity on palpation

Neurologic: right upper extremity muscle strength 2/5; right lower extremity muscle strength 3/5; left upper and lower extremity muscle strength 5/5; decreased sensation to light touch and pinprick on the right side (face, arm, and leg)

Diagnostic Studies

13.6 mg/dL

4,500/mm3



 Platelet count
210,000/mm3



Serum



 Glucose
110 mg/dL


Diffusion-weighted MRI: hyperintense lesions in the left frontal lobe and temporoparietal junction

Which of the following diagnostic studies is the most appropriate next step to determine the cause of this patient's current symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Thrombophilia screening can be considered in patients with unprovoked DVT or recurrent unexplained venous thromboembolism. A single DVT in a patient with multiple risk factors (e.g., prolonged immobility due to recent hospitalization, Crohn disease, smoking) does not warrant thrombophilia screening.

B) INCORRECT:

Transcranial Doppler can assess intracranial collateral blood flow and provide real-time bedside monitoring of acute intracranial occlusions. However, ischemic stroke has already been confirmed by diffusion-weighted MRI. Identifying the cause of ischemic stroke is the most appropriate next diagnostic step.

C) CORRECT:

Transthoracic echocardiography with agitated saline is the most appropriate next diagnostic step to evaluate for patent foramen ovale (PFO) showing a right-to-left shunt that increases with the Valsalva maneuver and coughing. PFO occurs in ∼ 25% of individuals and is typically asymptomatic until complications due to right-to-left shunting arise. Transient increases in right atrial pressures allow emboli originating from the venous system (e.g., DVT) to pass directly from the right atrium into the left atrium, and then into the systemic and cerebral arterial circulation. Management of PFO after an embolic stroke includes surgical or percutaneous closure of the defect, antiplatelet agents or anticoagulation, and evaluation for other potential causes of stroke (e.g., arrhythmia, hypercoagulability, endocarditis).

Paradoxical embolism can also be caused by a small atrial septal defect (ASD), which can be asymptomatic but typically manifests with a wide, fixed splitting of the second heart sound on auscultation. Echocardiography is also the first-line modality in the diagnosis of ASD.
Image Description:

In the presence of a patent foramen ovale, transient increases in right atrial pressure (e.g., when coughing) can allow emboli from the venous system to pass from the right atrium to the left atrium. From there, they can enter systemic arterial circulation and cause arterial embolism (e.g., stroke).

D) INCORRECT:

Carotid duplex is indicated for suspected carotid stenosis, which can lead to thrombotic occlusion of the carotid artery or embolic occlusion of the cerebral arteries, resulting in ischemic stroke. However, the absence of a carotid bruit and the presence of DVT indicate paradoxical embolism.

E) INCORRECT:

Cardiac MRI is indicated for various cardiac conditions to assess cardiac structure and function. While cardiac MRI can be considered for an embolic stroke of undetermined source to detect intracardiac thrombi and visualize PFO, a more widely available and better tolerated test is more appropriate.
questions.hint: This patient has risk factors (prolonged immobility due to recent hospitalization, Crohn disease, smoking) and features (swelling, red-purple discoloration of the right leg) of deep venous thrombosis (DVT) and ischemic stroke, suggesting a paradoxical embolism.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old man reports that an automated blood pressure (BP) device in a mall showed his BP to be high. He has no previous medical diagnoses but reports dyspnea and lower-extremity cramping on long walks; both symptoms subside with rest. He has had no palpitations, diaphoresis, weight change, fractures, headaches, snoring, daytime sleepiness, or changes in his mood. He has no known family history of hypertension and does not use tobacco, alcohol, or added salt in his diet.
On physical examination, he is afebrile, his heart rate is 80 beats per minute, his BP is 165/110 mm Hg in the right arm while he is sitting, and his BMI is 22.
Which one of the following assessments on physical examination is most likely to identify the cause of this patient’s hypertension?

choices.text: Compare blood pressure readings between the two upper and the two lower extremities
Listen for a continuous machine-like murmur
Check for displacement of the point of maximal impulse

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although renal-artery stenosis can lead to hypertension, it is unusual in a young man, is infrequently detected on auscultation, and would be unlikely to cause lower-extremity claudication symptoms. Renal-artery stenosis caused by fibromuscular dysplasia is more common in young women, specifically those who use oral contraceptives.

B) INCORRECT:

An S4 gallop is not specific for any particular cause of hypertension.

C) CORRECT:

Coarctation of the aorta is associated with heart failure, aortic dissection, intracranial hemorrhage, and premature death. Early treatment substantially improves quality of life and survival.

Indicators of an aortic coarctation include diminished and delayed pulses of the femoral arteries relative to the brachial arteries, as well as a systolic blood pressure difference of 20 mm Hg between the arms and the legs. Depending on the location of the coarctation relative to the subclavian arteries, the blood pressure may be elevated in either or both brachial arteries. Hence, it is important to compare blood pressures in both the upper and the lower extremities. Other possible physical examination findings in a patient with an aortic coarctation include a systolic murmur over the anterior chest and a bruit over the back.

Notable findings may be evident on chest radiograph (posterior rib notching) or transthoracic echocardiogram. A thoracic MRI or CT scan is typically performed to confirm the diagnosis and to delineate the anatomic characteristics of the coarctation.

Key learning point: When evaluating a patient for possible coarctation of the aorta, the most useful assessment on physical examination is to take blood pressure readings in all four extremities.

D) INCORRECT:

A patent ductus arteriosus is characterized by a machine-like murmur but is not associated with systemic hypertension.

E) INCORRECT:

Displacement of the point of maximal impulse is not specific for hypertension. It may be a sign of a dilated heart caused by either ischemic or nonischemic cardiomyopathy.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old man has an unrepaired congenital ventricular septal defect, pulmonary hypertension, and right-to-left intracardiac shunting consistent with Eisenmenger syndrome. He has declined referrals for possible cardiopulmonary transplantation and is now found to have an elevated hematocrit.
He reports persistent dyspnea on exertion after walking two blocks but states that he has no chest pain, headache, lightheadedness, dizziness, changes in vision, edema, orthopnea, numbness, tingling, or any other acute complaints. He currently takes furosemide and bosentan.
His blood pressure is 123/72 mm Hg, his heart rate is 74 beats per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 93% on 2 liters of supplemental oxygen by nasal cannula. Physical examination reveals moist mucous membranes, clear breath sounds, a right parasternal heave with a pronounced pulmonary component of the second heart sound, and mild clubbing of the fingertips. He has no jugular venous distention, cardiac murmurs, or peripheral edema.
A recent basic metabolic panel was normal. Complete blood count was notable for a hemoglobin level of 19.5 g/dL (reference range, 13.5–17.5) and a hematocrit of 60% (41–53).
Which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Increase the dose of supplemental oxygen

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Increasing supplemental oxygen is unlikely to add clinical benefit given this patient’s stable symptoms. Although many patients with cyanotic heart disease use supplemental oxygen, the effect on oxygen saturation and on symptoms is minimal and without proven benefit.

B) INCORRECT:

If a patient with CCHD has a hemoglobin level >20 g/dL and a hematocrit >65% with symptoms of hyperviscosity in the absence of volume depletion, then phlebotomy should be performed to lower the hematocrit to below 65%, with simultaneous volume replacement using intravenous fluids. This patient does not currently have these indications for phlebotomy.

C) INCORRECT:

Replacing bosentan with other drug therapies is unlikely to add clinical benefit given this patient’s stable symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

Replacing bosentan with other drug therapies is unlikely to add clinical benefit given this patient’s stable symptoms.

E) CORRECT:

Patients with cyanotic congenital heart disease (CCHD) often develop secondary erythrocytosis as a response to chronic tissue hypoxia. Unlike primary erythrocytosis from polycythemia vera, the association between an elevated hematocrit and thrombotic risk is not well established for patients with CCHD and secondary erythrocytosis, and routine therapeutic phlebotomy is not recommended. Nevertheless, a markedly elevated hematocrit increases the risk for hyperviscosity; potential symptoms include headache, visual disturbance, transient ischemic attack, paresthesias, altered mentation, and fatigue.

Key learning point: In an adult with cyanotic congenital heart disease and erythrocytosis, therapeutic phlebotomy is indicated if the hematocrit exceeds 65% with symptoms of hyperviscosity in the absence of volume depletion.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old man presents with fatigue that has been worsening for a year. He recently quit his construction job because of exertional intolerance. He also reports dyspnea on climbing two flights of stairs or walking more than half a mile. He has no ankle swelling, chest pain, or orthopnea. He has not seen a doctor since childhood and has no family history of cardiorespiratory conditions.
On examination, he is of normal weight and has no clubbing, cyanosis, or lower-extremity edema. A left parasternal heave is detected on precordial palpation. Cardiac auscultation reveals wide and fixed splitting of the second heart sound, with a soft systolic murmur at the upper-left sternal border. The lung fields are clear on auscultation.
A resting electrocardiogram shows an incomplete right bundle-branch block.
Which one of the following congenital cardiac abnormalities is this patient most likely to have?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A patent foramen ovale usually causes no cardiac symptoms or signs.

B) INCORRECT:

A ventricular septal defect would cause a holosystolic murmur loudest over the lower-left sternal border.

C) INCORRECT:

A mid-diastolic murmur at the apex, or a loud first heart sound would suggest mitral stenosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Cyanosis or a loud P2 would be characteristic of Eisenmenger syndrome (i.e., pulmonary hypertension due to a long-standing left-to-right intracardiac shunt that results eventually in shunt reversal). Severe pulmonary hypertension is likely to cause hypertrophy of the free wall of the right ventricle and lead to a high or wide R-prime or to a pattern of marked right ventricular hypertrophy on the 12-lead electrocardiogram.

E) CORRECT:

This patient has an atrial septal defect (ASD). Dyspnea and fatigue are common symptoms of an ASD characterized by substantial left-to-right intracardiac shunting. The splitting of the second heart sound is fixed, as phasic changes in venous return are accompanied by reciprocal changes in the interatrial shunt volume, thereby minimizing respiratory influence on pulmonary-valve closure timing. The systolic murmur results from increased forward flow across the pulmonary valve; flow across the ASD is inaudible. Electrocardiographic evidence of an incomplete right bundle-branch block is typical of ASD.

Key learning point: Findings of a widely fixed splitting of the second heart sound, a soft systolic murmur, and electrocardiographic evidence of an incomplete right bundle-branch block are most likely to be caused by an atrial septal defect.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old man explains that he was born with a “hole in his heart.” He has no complaints, and his exercise tolerance has always seemed normal for his age. His vital signs are normal.
His cardiac examination reveals a palpable heave at the left sternal border and a fixed, split second heart sound. A soft systolic flow murmur is detected at the base. The patient has normal jugular venous pressure, no S3 or S4 gallop, and no lower-extremity edema.
His electrocardiogram shows an incomplete right bundle-branch block with right-axis deviation.
Which one of the following congenital cardiac defects is this patient most likely to have?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A fixed, split second heart sound is nearly pathognomonic for an atrial septal defect (ASD) and does not occur with other congenital cardiac defects. With an ASD, left-to-right shunting of blood occurs, so the volume of blood flowing through the right side of the heart and lungs is increased. This leads to dilatation of the right heart chambers (i.e., right atrium and ventricle), with the latter causing the parasternal lift. Although blood flow through the ASD does not create a murmur, a soft systolic murmur (from increased flow across the pulmonic valve) is usually audible at the base. The electrocardiogram of patients with an atrial septal defect often reveals an incomplete right bundle-branch block and right-axis deviation due to right ventricular dilatation.

Key learning point: A fixed, split second heart sound is suggestive of an atrial septal defect.

B) INCORRECT:

A bicuspid aortic valve may cause a systolic ejection click and murmur but not a fixed, split second heart sound or right ventricular enlargement.

C) INCORRECT:

A patent ductus arteriosus creates a loud continuous murmur at the upper left sternal border.

D) INCORRECT:

Ebstein anomaly is associated with a holosystolic murmur caused by tricuspid regurgitation due to apical displacement of the valve. This may lead to right heart dilatation with a palpable right ventricular heave. There is usually a split first heart sound due to delayed closure of the tricuspid valve. The second heart sound can be widely split due to a right bundle-branch block, but it is not a fixed split, such as in ASD.

E) INCORRECT:

A ventricular septal defect creates a harsh systolic murmur at the lower sternal border — often with an associated thrill — and is not associated with a fixed, split second heart sound.

questions.text:
A 4-day-old infant born at 28 weeks’ gestation develops tachypnea, retractions, and a small increase in baseline oxygen requirement. She was born by vaginal delivery after preterm labor and received intranatal glucocorticoids. Her course to date has been unremarkable for an infant of her gestational age.
She now has a blood pressure of 57/29 mm Hg, a continuous murmur along the left sternal border, and prominent palmar pulses. Her renal function is normal.
A chest radiograph is obtained (figure).
What is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dexamethasone and other glucocorticoids are sometimes used in very preterm infants to promote lung maturity in the periextubation period, but they are not a treatment for PDA.

B) INCORRECT:

Treatment with prostaglandin E1 is not indicated, as this would maintain patency of the ductus and allow for continued shunting of blood across the ductus. Prostaglandin E1 is useful in treating a “ductal dependent” congenital heart disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Digoxin may be used to treat adults and some children with atrial fibrillation, atrial flutter, and congestive heart failure, but it will not treat this patient's underlying condition.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's chest radiograph shows a normal-size heart and increased lung vascular markings consistent with pulmonary edema. These findings, together with the patient’s history and examination, suggest a hemodynamically significant patent ductus arteriosus (PDA).

PDA is a common complication in very preterm infants. A small PDA may by asymptomatic, and observation alone may be appropriate. However, a large PDA often manifests with a continuous, machinery-like heart murmur, active precordium, bounding pulses, a wide pulse pressure, pulmonary congestion, and respiratory distress.

PDA in preterm infants is related to the continued availability of prostaglandins. For premature infants who have hemodynamically significant symptoms despite expectant management of a PDA, pharmacotherapy is indicated, targeting prostaglandin synthesis. Cycylooxygenase inhibitors, such as indomethacin and ibuprofen, as well as acetaminophen have been used since each inhibits prostaglandin synthetase. Pharmacologic treatments will constrict and successfully close the PDA in 60% to 80% of cases. Surgical closure of a symptomatic PDA may be indicated if medical management fails.

Key learning point: The most appropriate initial medical treatment for a very preterm infant with a hemodynamically significant patent ductus arteriosus is indomethacin.

E) INCORRECT:

Palivizumab is a monoclonal antibody used to prevent respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) infection in high-risk infants, such as those who were born preterm and those who have serious congenital heart disease; once an infant contracts RSV, palivizumab is not used for treatment purposes. In this particular case, palivizumab would not aid in the treatment of PDA.

questions.text:
A 6-month-old boy who was born full term presents for a well-child visit. He has had several upper respiratory infections during the past few months but has never required hospitalization. He is now at the 5th percentile for body weight, down from the 30th percentile during his previous visit. His mother remarks that he seems to lose his breath very easily and is often sweaty, even when drinking a bottle.
On examination, he is tachypneic and has a loud continuous murmur heard best at the left upper sternal border.
Which one of the following findings is this patient most likely to have on examination?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient’s clinical history of tachypnea and diaphoresis, together with a continuous heart murmur, is concerning for a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), an acyanotic congenital heart condition characterized by left-to-right cardiac shunting. As infants with significant PDAs get older, pulmonary resistance decreases, and more blood flows left to right through the PDA. During diastole, blood flows from the aorta through the PDA, thereby lowering diastolic pressure and widening the gap between systolic and diastolic pressure. On examination, this phenomenon manifests as bounding peripheral pulses.

Patients with a PDA and left-to-right shunting have normal oxygen saturation and are acyanotic, as there is no obstruction to the pulmonary vascular bed that prevents the blood from becoming oxygenated.

Femoral pulses are typically diminished in patients with aortic coarctation, not a PDA. Diminished or absent femoral pulses in aortic coarctation result from a reduction in blood flow through the narrow segment of the aorta. In a patient with a PDA, there is no obstruction to blood flow; therefore, blood easily distends the femoral artery, and the subsequent relaxation of the vessel wall is more pronounced because of runoff into the pulmonary bed during diastole. In addition, in patients with aortic coarctation, systolic blood pressure is lower in the lower extremities than in the upper extremities.

Acyanotic congenital heart disease may be attributed to any of a large group of lesions that share the features of increased pulmonary circulation, normal systemic perfusion, and normal oxygenation. Children with acyanotic congenital heart disease often present with tachypnea, diaphoresis, failure to thrive, and frequent respiratory infections.

Key learning point: The physical examination of an infant with significant left-to-right cardiac shunting often reveals bounding peripheral pulses.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with a PDA and left-to-right shunting have normal oxygen saturation and are acyanotic, as there is no obstruction to the pulmonary vascular bed that prevents the blood from becoming oxygenated.

C) INCORRECT:

As infants with significant PDAs get older, pulmonary resistance decreases, and more blood flows left to right through the PDA. During diastole, blood flows from the aorta through the PDA, thereby lowering diastolic pressure and widening the gap between systolic and diastolic pressure.

D) INCORRECT:

Femoral pulses are typically diminished in patients with aortic coarctation, not a PDA. Diminished or absent femoral pulses in aortic coarctation result from a reduction in blood flow through the narrow segment of the aorta. In a patient with a PDA, there is no obstruction to blood flow; therefore, blood easily distends the femoral artery, and the subsequent relaxation of the vessel wall is more pronounced because of runoff into the pulmonary bed during diastole.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with a PDA and left-to-right shunting have normal oxygen saturation and are acyanotic, as there is no obstruction to the pulmonary vascular bed that prevents the blood from becoming oxygenated.

questions.text:
An 8-month-old girl with poor weight gain is hospitalized for initiation of nasogastric feeds. She has had difficulty with feeding since birth and becomes diaphoretic when drinking a bottle.
On examination, she has tachycardia and tachypnea, with intercostal retractions. She has a loud second heart sound and a holosystolic 2/6 murmur, heard best at the left lower sternal border. The liver edge is 3.5 cm below the costal margin.
Which one of the following complications is this patient at greatest risk of developing?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nutritional deficiencies may be seen in patients with a left-to-right shunt, but with proper fortification and supplementation, they are rarely severe enough to develop into rickets.

B) CORRECT:

This patient’s history and physical examination are consistent with a left-to-right shunt through a ventricular septal defect (VSD) that was not repaired at birth. Flow through the VSD has caused significant pulmonary overcirculation, resulting in pulmonary hypertension. The patient’s murmur is not as pronounced as it might have been previously, when the level of pressure in the right ventricle would have approached the level of pressure in the left ventricle. Other examination findings suggestive of increased pulmonary and right ventricular pressures are a loud S2 (P2 component) and hepatomegaly.

Infants with a significant left-to-right shunt often become diaphoretic and tachycardic when feeding and may require caloric fortification because of insufficient oral intake and increased metabolic needs. On chest radiograph, these patients exhibit peribronchial edema and inflammation secondary to increased interstitial fluid from lymphatic channels that have been overwhelmed by increased pulmonary circulation. Although the exact mechanism is unknown, this excess fluid may contribute to the recurrent respiratory infections often seen in patients with VSD and large left-to-right shunting.

Key learning point: Infants with a large left-to-right cardiac shunt and pulmonary hypertension are at increased risk for failure to thrive and recurrent respiratory infections.

C) INCORRECT:

Cardiac shunts do not affect platelet production except in patients with long-standing cyanosis; therefore, platelet count (e.g., thrombocytosis) would not be expected in this scenario.

D) INCORRECT:

Although infants with a left-to-right shunt may experience poor weight gain, it is due to diminished nutritional intake and increased metabolic needs, not poor intestinal vascular perfusion or gastric mucosal erosion. Thus, intestinal ischemia and gastric ulcers are not typical complications of VSD or left-to-right shunting.

E) INCORRECT:

Although infants with a left-to-right shunt may experience poor weight gain, it is due to diminished nutritional intake and increased metabolic needs, not poor intestinal vascular perfusion or gastric mucosal erosion. Thus, intestinal ischemia and gastric ulcers are not typical complications of VSD or left-to-right shunting. Intestinal ischemia is typical in lesions with significant diastolic runoff such as a large patent ductus arteriosus, truncus arteriosus, or significant aortic regurgitation.

questions.text:
A 5-year-old girl presents after visiting the emergency department (ED) 2 weeks ago for an episode of respiratory distress and wheezing related to a viral illness. A chest radiograph was obtained during the ED visit (figure), and the patient was treated with supportive care. Her blood pressure at the time was elevated (132/87 mm Hg).
Today, she is in no acute distress. Her body weight is 16.7 kg, her height is 106 cm, and her heart rate is 88 beats per minute. Her blood pressure is 127/64 mm Hg in the right arm and 112/60 mm Hg in the right leg. She is acyanotic and breathing ambient air comfortably. Her lung fields are clear to auscultation. There are normal first and second heart sounds, with an aortic ejection click, and no murmur or gallop. Her abdomen is soft and nontender; the liver edge is palpable at the right costal margin. There is no extremity edema or clubbing; she has 2+ bilateral radial pulses and 1+ left and right femoral pulses.
Other than the viral illness 2 weeks ago, the patient has been healthy. She has been growing and developing normally.
For which one of the following conditions is this patient at increased risk?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient has hypertension secondary to coarctation of the aorta. The coarctation is evident from the difference in blood pressure between the lower and upper extremities, the diminished femoral pulses, and the radiographic findings of inferior rib notching.

In healthy individuals, blood pressure is higher in the lower extremities than in the upper extremities because of arterial wave amplification. In individuals with coarctation of the aorta, systolic blood pressure may be more than 20 mm Hg lower in the lower extremities than that measured in the upper extremities. This gradient may be diminished if there is significant collateralization of blood vessels, noted by the appearance of rib notching on chest radiograph.

The chest radiograph in patients with coarctation of the aorta can also reveal the “figure 3” sign, an indentation of the aortic wall at the site of coarctation with pre- and postcoarctation dilatation.

Studies using magnetic resonance angiography of the brain in patients with coarctation have shown that up to 10% of affected individuals have intracranial aneurysms — compared with 2% to 3% in the general population. The magnitude of risk for aneurysm rupture in affected patients is unclear. As such, the value of routine screening has yet to be determined. Patients who undergo surgical or stenting repair of the coarctation early in life do not appear to be at increased risk for intracranial aneurysm.

Key learning point: Coarctation of the aorta — evident in a patient presenting with hypertension, diminished femoral pulses, and radiographic evidence of rib notching — increases the risk for intracranial aneurysm.

B) INCORRECT:

Pheochromocytoma, primary or secondary hyperaldosteronism, and polycystic kidney disease are all conditions that can cause secondary hypertension. None of these conditions result in a differential blood pressure between the upper and lower extremities nor are they associated with the chest radiograph findings presented in this case.

C) INCORRECT:

Pheochromocytoma, primary or secondary hyperaldosteronism, and polycystic kidney disease are all conditions that can cause secondary hypertension. None of these conditions result in a differential blood pressure between the upper and lower extremities nor are they associated with the chest radiograph findings presented in this case.

D) INCORRECT:

Pheochromocytoma, primary or secondary hyperaldosteronism, and polycystic kidney disease are all conditions that can cause secondary hypertension. Other potentially implicated conditions include renovascular disease and diabetes. None of these conditions result in a differential blood pressure between the upper and lower extremities nor are they associated with the chest radiograph findings presented in this case.

E) INCORRECT:

Some genetic syndromes — including Turner syndrome, Williams syndrome, and Noonan syndrome — carry an increased risk for aortic coarctation; however, coarctation is not an associated finding in Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome.

questions.text:
A 9-day-old boy is brought in by his mother for concerns of poor feeding and color changes. He was born full term via cesarean section for nonreassuring fetal heart tones, and his nursery stay was unremarkable. However, since being home, he has been breastfeeding poorly, with diminished energy, and has been taking longer to feed. His mother states that he “gets blue when he cries.” She has also noticed rapid breathing and occasional grunting.
On physical examination, the patient has a heart rate of 165 beats per minute, normal blood pressure for his age, and pre- and postductal oxygen saturations of 70% and 68%, respectively, while breathing ambient air. He appears fatigued and cyanotic, and he is tachypneic with subcostal retractions. A prominent apical impulse and a thrill are detected on palpation, and auscultation reveals a click just after the first heart sound; a fixed, split second heart sound; and a 4/6 crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur, heard loudest in late systole extending into diastole, both at the left upper sternal border. The infant has normal bowel sounds, and his liver is palpable 2 cm below the costal margin.
A chest radiograph shows normal heart size and reduced pulmonary vascularity without focal consolidation. An electrocardiogram demonstrates sinus tachycardia with right axis deviation, a pure R wave in lead V1 that is >20 mm, and inverted T waves in lead V4.
Prostaglandin E1 is initiated.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Surgical placement of a systemic-to-pulmonary artery shunt
Placement of a stent in the patent ductus arteriosus
Initiation of sildenafil for pulmonary vasodilation

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This infant’s presentation is consistent with severe pulmonary valve stenosis. Milder cases of pulmonary stenosis are typically asymptomatic and often detected after a murmur is heard. In severe cases, such as this one, common presenting symptoms include lethargy, increased work of breathing, and cyanosis. The cyanosis results from a combination of right-to-left shunting across the atrial septum and, if the ductus arteriosus is small, diminished pulmonary blood flow.

Cardiac examination in patients with severe pulmonary valve stenosis often reveals a thrill and/or prominent right ventricular impulse, as the elevated pressure in the right ventricle causes hypertrophy. However, in young infants with severe stenosis, a thrill may not be palpable, and the first heart sound may be normal; occasionally, an opening click may be heard (as in this case), but often, it is absent. A systolic click is more commonly heard in mild-to-moderate stenosis, typically occurs in early systole, and represents the acoustic noise created from the stiff, stenotic valve leaflets opening. As stenosis becomes severe, the click merges with the first heart sound. The second heart sound is split, and the degree of splitting is proportional to the severity of stenosis, becoming fixed in severe stenosis. Occasionally, the second heart sound cannot be heard because of the intensity of the murmur, which will appear to extend into diastole. The systolic murmur is best heard at the left upper sternal border (third and fourth intercostal spaces) with radiation to the back. The severity of the stenosis correlates with the intensity and length of the murmur. The more severe the stenosis, the louder the murmur (usually grade 4 or more) and the later it will peak in systole.

Chest radiographs in infants with pulmonary valve stenosis typically show a prominent main pulmonary artery segment, related to poststenotic dilation. There is decreased pulmonary vascularity secondary to diminished pulmonary blood flow, but this finding varies with the size of the ductus arteriosus. The right atrium may be enlarged.

Electrocardiograms in patients with severe stenosis typically show right axis deviation (as in this case) related to right ventricular hypertrophy. There may also be a pure R wave (>20 mm) or a Q-R pattern in the right precordial leads suggesting strong right-sided forces. If there is right atrial enlargement, tall P waves may be seen in lead II.

Treatment for severe pulmonary valve stenosis involves immediate initiation of prostaglandin E1 to maintain ductal patency and thereby establish pulmonary blood flow. Balloon valvuloplasty is then recommended to relieve the obstruction.

A surgical valvotomy is a more invasive procedure than balloon valvuloplasty and requires a median sternotomy. It should be considered only if the balloon valvuloplasty is unsuccessful.

Key learning point: Treatment for an infant with severe pulmonary valve stenosis involves initiation of prostaglandin E1 followed by balloon pulmonary valvuloplasty.

B) INCORRECT:

Placement of either a systemic-to-pulmonary artery shunt or a stent in the patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) would establish immediate and more secure pulmonary blood flow after the initiation of prostaglandin E1; however, the benefit would be temporary, and intervention on the pulmonary valve would still be required. These stents can be considered if a patient remains dependent on prostaglandin E1 after balloon valvuloplasty, but neither one is recommended as an initial treatment option.

C) INCORRECT:

Diuretics such as furosemide are frequently used in congenital heart disease when there is excessive pulmonary blood flow, which can be caused by large left-to-right shunts, or in left-sided obstructive lesions causing left atrial hypertension leading to pulmonary edema. Pulmonary blood flow is limited in the setting of pulmonary stenosis, so diuretics would not be helpful.

D) INCORRECT:

Placement of either a systemic-to-pulmonary artery shunt or a stent in the patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) would establish immediate and more secure pulmonary blood flow after the initiation of prostaglandin E1; however, the benefit would be temporary, and intervention on the pulmonary valve would still be required. These stents can be considered if a patient remains dependent on prostaglandin E1 after balloon valvuloplasty, but neither one is recommended as an initial treatment option.

E) INCORRECT:
