Pulmonary vasodilatory agents such as sildenafil are used in patients with elevated pulmonary vascular resistance in order to promote pulmonary blood flow. These agents are not beneficial in the setting of a fixed obstruction, such as in pulmonary valve stenosis.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old boy presents for a preparticipation physical examination for high school basketball. He is asymptomatic and has no limitation in physical activity or abnormal growth or development. His parents are healthy; his younger brother has bicuspid aortic valve that was identified on echocardiography during workup of an innocent murmur. The patient has no other family history of heart disease, sudden cardiac death, or unexplained death.
He has a heart rate of 72 beats per minute, an oxygen saturation of 98%, and a blood pressure of 112/68 mm Hg in the right upper extremity and 128/76 mm Hg in the right lower extremity. His height is 183 cm (90th percentile), and his weight is 59 kg (41st percentile) for a BMI of 23.6.
Physical examination reveals a regular heart rate and rhythm without murmur, click, or gallop. The patient has 2+ bilateral brachial and femoral pulses without brachiofemoral delay.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Clear for all sports participation without further testing
Recommend genetic testing for ACTA2 mutations

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cardiac CT angiography could be considered if a screening echocardiogram showed evidence of aortic root dilatation or another abnormality, but it is not indicated as first-line screening in a patient who has a first-degree relative with an isolated finding of BAV.

B) CORRECT:

This patient has a first-degree relative with bicuspid aortic valve (BAV) and should be screened accordingly. BAV is the most prevalent congenital cardiac abnormality, with an estimated prevalence of 4.6 per 1000 live births, and it is 1.5 times more prevalent in males than females. Most cases of BAV are spontaneous; however, familial inheritance may occur in an autosomal dominant pattern with variable penetrance of 9%, and an abnormal aorta is seen in as many as 32% of first-degree relatives without BAV. Identification of BAV is important because this condition increases the risk for aortic dissection, coarctation, and long-term aortic valve calcification — and resulting stenosis or insufficiency. Appropriate screening includes a one-time echocardiogram in all first-degree relatives.

Key learning point: Patients who have a first-degree relative with isolated bicuspid aortic valve should undergo one-time screening with echocardiography.

C) INCORRECT:

Given the relatively high incidence of isolated BAV in the general population, testing for genetic mutations, such as in the ACTA2 or FBN1 genes, is not warranted in a family that does not have any history or examination findings consistent with syndromic aortopathies including Marfan syndrome, Loeys-Dietz syndrome, Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, or familial thoracic aortic aneurysms and dissections (TAAD) syndrome. Clinical findings that would raise concern for a genetic aortopathy syndrome include joint hypermobility, pectus excavatum or carinatum, spontaneous pneumothorax, scoliosis, flat feet, increased ratio of arm span to height, marfanoid facial features, skin striae, severe myopia, ectopia lentis, and mitral valve prolapse.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with BAV who have no significant aortic root dilatation (<40 mm or the equivalent according to body-surface area in children and adolescents) and no significant aortic stenosis or aortic regurgitation may participate in all competitive sports. An isolated finding of BAV or a family history of BAV alone would not be grounds to limit sports participation.

E) INCORRECT:

Given the relatively high incidence of isolated BAV in the general population, testing for genetic mutations, such as in the ACTA2 or FBN1 genes, is not warranted in a family that does not have any history or examination findings consistent with syndromic aortopathies including Marfan syndrome, Loeys-Dietz syndrome, Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, or familial thoracic aortic aneurysms and dissections (TAAD) syndrome. Clinical findings that would raise concern for a genetic aortopathy syndrome include joint hypermobility, pectus excavatum or carinatum, spontaneous pneumothorax, scoliosis, flat feet, increased ratio of arm span to height, marfanoid facial features, skin striae, severe myopia, ectopia lentis, and mitral valve prolapse.

questions.text:
A 2-month-old girl is brought to the emergency department with a 3-day history of increasing irritability and respiratory distress. Her mother states that she becomes extremely irritable and diaphoretic upon breastfeeding but that she has not had any fever, congestion, diarrhea, or known exposure to sick contacts. Her mother reports that she has a fussy temperament and has had some irritability with feeds since a couple weeks after birth.
The patient is afebrile and has a heart rate of 180 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 84/47 mm Hg, a respiratory rate of 67 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 93% while breathing ambient air. She is extremely fussy on examination and slightly diaphoretic. Her cardiac examination is notable for a 2/6 blowing holosystolic murmur heard loudest at the apex with radiation to the left axilla and an S3 gallop. She has intercostal and subcostal retractions with faint crackles heard at both lung bases. Her liver edge is 3 cm below the right costal margin. She is slightly cool to the touch on her distal extremities, with a capillary refill of 3 to 4 seconds.
Blood cultures and a respiratory pathogen panel are pending. Serum creatinine and aminotransferase levels are within normal limits. The leukocyte count is 9000 per mm3 (reference range, 5000–19,500), the C-reactive protein level is 18 mg/liter (0–5), and the erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 15 mm/hr (0–10). The brain natriuretic peptide level is >2500 pg/mL (<100).
A chest radiograph (figure 1) and electrocardiogram (figure 2) are obtained.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?

choices.text: Anomalous origin of the left coronary artery from the pulmonary artery

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This infant is irritable with signs and symptoms of heart failure, including tachypnea, tachycardia, diaphoresis, feeding difficulties, cardiomegaly, an S3 gallop, hepatomegaly, and poor peripheral perfusion. She has an enlarged cardiac silhouette on chest radiograph and signs of ischemia on electrocardiography. The key to correctly diagnosing the cause of the heart failure lies in the timing of symptom onset, the nature of the presentation, and the results of associated studies.

Anomalous left coronary artery from the pulmonary artery (ALCAPA) is the most likely cause of heart failure in this case. When the left coronary artery arises anomalously from the pulmonary artery, coronary perfusion depends primarily on the pressure in the pulmonary artery, which is sufficient during fetal life and the immediate newborn period. However, as pulmonary vascular resistance drops in the first several weeks of life, the forward pressure or perfusion of the left coronary artery decreases. In this case, when the patient exerts herself, there is a supply-demand mismatch, and the patient experiences coronary ischemia. Her irritability is likely caused by neonatal angina.

Patients with ALCAPA typically present with signs and symptoms of heart failure. Mitral regurgitation due to ischemia of the papillary muscles is common, particularly when the diagnosis is made after the first 4 weeks of life. Cardiomegaly is typical on chest radiograph, and affected patients may have a characteristic electrocardiogram (ECG) in which the left-directed ECG leads (I, aVL, V5, or V6) show Q waves. Q waves in leads I and aVL in this clinical setting are pathognomonic, pending additional imaging to confirm ALCAPA. ST-segment changes consistent with myocardial ischemia are also possible. However, 20% to 45% of affected patients do not have characteristic ECG findings. Therefore, a high index of suspicion is required for an ALCAPA diagnosis, as it can manifest similarly to other causes of heart failure.

The diagnosis is usually made by echocardiography but can be missed; therefore, advanced imaging with CT angiography, MRI, or cardiac catheterization may be needed. Treatment is with surgical repair.

In this patient’s ECG, there are profound ventricular forces where the QRS complexes are very tall in almost every lead. This is due to the cardiomegaly as confirmed by the chest radiograph. Very noticeable Q waves are seen in lead I but are obscured in lead aVL by the QRS complexes, which makes the diagnosis of ALCAPA. The rhythm strip in lead II demonstrates a P wave before each QRS complex, which makes tachyarrhythmia-induced cardiomyopathy unlikely.

In contrast, in a normal ECG, there is an absence of Q waves in I and aVL and almost isoelectric forces in aVL. In addition, there are no Q waves in V5 and V6.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in an afebrile infant presenting with heart failure and electrocardiographic signs of myocardial ischemia is anomalous origin of the left coronary artery from the pulmonary artery.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with viral myocarditis can present with fulminant heart failure. However, this patient’s history does not suggest a viral prodrome, and the ECG does not show diffuse ST-segment changes or low voltage to suggest myocarditis. In addition, the degree to which the patient’s inflammatory markers are elevated is nonspecific and does not suggest acute myocarditis. Still, clinicians should be aware that heart failure can result in mild elevations in inflammatory markers, as in this case.

C) INCORRECT:

Kawasaki disease is a medium-vessel vasculitis resulting in a syndrome of mucocutaneous changes with occasional coronary involvement. Significant coronary artery aneurysms and thrombi affecting myocardial perfusion can occur but not without accompanying signs and symptoms of Kawasaki disease, such as fever, lymphadenitis, oral mucocutaneous changes, or rash. This patient does not have any of these associated symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

Large ventricular septal defects (VSDs) usually lead to signs and symptoms of heart failure related to left-to-right shunting as pulmonary vascular resistance drops in the first 1 to 2 months of life. This patient’s murmur is most consistent with mitral regurgitation; furthermore, the ECG of a patient with a VSD does not typically include Q waves.

E) INCORRECT:

Tachycardia-induced cardiomyopathy can cause heart failure in neonates and infants. The most likely inciting arrhythmias are forms of supraventricular tachycardia. There is no association with myocardial ischemia.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old boy is establishing care with a new pediatrician. His mother reports normal feeding during infancy, normal growth, overall good health, and normal development; the one exception is a congenital abnormality of the child’s left thumb that he has learned to work around with little difficulty. A comprehensive review of systems is negative. Family history is notable for short arms and a pacemaker in the patient’s mother and well-controlled asthma in his father.
On physical examination, the patient has a heart rate of 110 beats per minute with normal blood pressures for his age in all four extremities. His oxygen saturation, while he breathes ambient air, is 98% in the right hand and 96% in the right foot. Cardiac examination reveals a 2/6 crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur at the left upper sternal border with a widely fixed, split S2 . There is no increased work of breathing, and lung fields are clear on auscultation. The abdomen is soft, and the liver is palpable at the right costal margin. Evaluation of the extremities shows no evidence of edema and no left thumb.
A radiograph of the patient’s left hand is shown.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient has Holt-Oram syndrome, also known as heart-hand syndrome. Holt-Oram syndrome is characterized by congenital heart defects, cardiac conduction abnormalities, and upper-extremity anomalies, with phenotypes that can vary widely even within families. Diagnosis is made when there is a preaxial radial abnormality and a personal or family history of a cardiac septal defect. Up to 70% of affected individuals have pathologic genetic variants identified in the TBX5 gene.

Approximately 75% of individuals with Holt-Oram syndrome have congenital heart disease or conduction system abnormalities. A wide range of cardiac defects have been described in affected patients, and the most common is atrial septal defect (ASD). Because there is a low-pressure gradient across the defect, a murmur caused by blood shunting from the left atrium to the right atrium is not heard. Instead, the increased blood volume in the right ventricle (because of the left-to-right shunting across the ASD) leads to a murmur of relative pulmonary stenosis. Pulmonary stenosis murmurs are best heard at the left upper sternal border and are crescendo-decrescendo in nature. The increased volume in the right ventricle also causes the widely split, fixed second heart sound.

Key learning point: Key clinical findings in patients with Holt-Oram syndrome typically include cardiac defects and radial ray anomalies.

B) INCORRECT:

VACTERL association is a nonrandom constellation of congenital anomalies:

• Vertebral anomalies
• Anorectal anomalies
• Cardiac anomalies
• Tracheoesophageal fistula
• Renal anomalies
• Limb anomalies (including radial ray anomalies)

Although this patient has two findings consistent with VACTERL, diagnosis requires at least three of the above features.

C) INCORRECT:

Most patients with trisomy 18 die at a young age, although those with mosaicism can have a more-variable disease course. Patients with trisomy 18 typically present with congenital heart disease, including ASDs and ventricular septal defects, as well as radial ray anomalies. However, other findings would also be expected in trisomy 18, including central nervous system anomalies, other skeletal anomalies (e.g., rocker-bottom feet and facial abnormalities). In addition, normal development would not be expected in a patient with trisomy 18.

D) INCORRECT:

Amniotic band syndrome includes a diverse set of clinical abnormalities, all a result of entrapment of various fetal body parts. Because the entrapment is random, each person with this syndrome has the potential for a unique defect. Limb defects are the most frequent and can include limb amputation or constriction. Amniotic band syndrome has no association with systemic defects such as congenital heart disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Thrombocytopenia-absent radius (TAR) syndrome is defined by fetal thrombocytopenia and absent radii bilaterally; despite these radial defects, the thumbs are typically present. Congenital cardiac anomalies occur in about 15% of individuals with TAR syndrome.

questions.text:
A 3-day-old male infant is brought in for a well-newborn examination. He was born at 39 weeks’ gestation after an uncomplicated pregnancy, including unremarkable prenatal care. The delivery was uneventful, his oxygen saturation in the newborn nursery was normal, and he was discharged at 24 hours of life without any clinical concerns.
His parents report that he was initially doing well at home, with normal newborn behavior and no feeding difficulty. However, during the past 24 hours, he has become fussy and has been feeding slowly and less vigorously, with reduced urine output. His parents have tried both bottle feeding with formula and breastfeeding, but he struggles similarly with both and has had two episodes of emesis after attempted feedings.
In clinic, his weight is down 13% from his birth weight, and he has a temperature of 37.2°C, a heart rate of 173 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 57 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 97% while breathing ambient air. Blood pressure is measured at 95/55 mm Hg in the right arm and 70/33 mm Hg in the right leg. On examination, the infant is acyanotic and nondysmorphic, and he appears fatigued. Both lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiovascular examination reveals a normal S1 and S2 with no murmur. The brachial pulses are 2+ and the femoral pulses 1+. The abdomen is soft, and the liver edge is palpable 1 cm below the right costal margin.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Recommend transitioning to exclusive formula feeding
Order an upper gastrointestinal contrast study
Recommend lactation consultation with outpatient follow-up within 24 hours

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Transitioning this infant to an exclusive formula diet would not address the primary pathology. The emesis he is experiencing stems from hypoperfusion and ischemia rather than intolerance of breast milk.

B) CORRECT:

Coarctation of the aorta (CoA) is the most commonly missed fetal congenital heart disease diagnosis, and it remains the most commonly missed postnatal critical congenital heart disease diagnosis despite routine newborn pulse oximetry screening. CoA is defined as a focal narrowing of the aortic lumen, often occurring opposite the insertion of the ductus arteriosus. It accounts for approximately 5% to 8% of all congenital heart disease and occurs with a male predominance. Associated cardiovascular lesions may include bicuspid aortic valve, aortic arch hypoplasia, subaortic stenosis, mitral valve abnormalities, ventricular and atrial septal defects, and patent ductus arteriosus (PDA).

This infant presents with hypoperfusion of the lower body, as evident from a blood-pressure gradient between the upper and lower extremities, and reduced lower-extremity pulses. The narrowed aortic lumen in CoA limits blood flow to the areas distal to the narrowing, as demonstrated by the lower blood pressure and reduced pulses distal to the narrowing. The onset of symptoms of severe CoA can occur as the PDA closes postnatally and blood flow beyond the coarctation is restricted by the narrowing. It is believed that, in some cases, the oxygen-sensitive PDA tissue does not fully migrate during embryologic development and becomes incorporated into the lumen of the aorta. Additional clinical findings in some patients may include delayed femoral pulses or a murmur of associated bicuspid aortic valve or accelerated blood flow across the aortic narrowing.

Choosing Appropriate Care for This Patient

This infant has clinically significant CoA, and the priority is to restore perfusion to the lower body by reopening the PDA with prostaglandin E1 (PGE) infusion. This intervention should be initiated without delay and does not require imaging confirmation first. The patient should then have a transthoracic echocardiogram to confirm the diagnosis and should remain hospitalized on PGE infusion until surgical repair can be arranged.

Key learning point: The most appropriate initial care for a neonate with clinically significant coarctation of the aorta is prompt initiation of prostaglandin E1 infusion.

C) INCORRECT:

Supplemental oxygen is not required in this infant given the absence of hypoxemia.

D) INCORRECT:

An upper gastrointestinal series would not reveal the etiology of the infant’s condition and would delay diagnosis and ultimate treatment.

E) INCORRECT:

This infant’s feeding difficulty stems from lower-body hypoperfusion (rather than a primary feeding difficulty), likely the result of poor perfusion and gastrointestinal ischemia with resultant abdominal pain. Neither alternative feeding techniques nor lactation consultation would be beneficial, and taking the time to try either would delay definitive therapy to restore lower-body perfusion. Such a delay would lead to additional clinical instability.

questions.text: A 3-week-old female newborn is brought to the emergency department because of a 4-day history of bluish discoloration of the feet, poor feeding, excessive sweating, and irritability. Examination following delivery showed no abnormalities. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse rate is 168/min, respirations are 66/min, and blood pressure is 90/70 mm Hg in the upper extremities, and 70/68 mm Hg in the lower extremities. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98% in the right hand and 78% in the right foot. On examination, subcostal retractions are seen and the liver is palpated 4 cm below the right costal margin. Chest auscultation discloses fine crepitations in both lung fields and a grade 3/6 systolic murmur heard best at the left paravertebral interscapular area. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Narrowing of the ascending aorta at the sinotubular junction
Narrowing of the descending aorta near the ligamentum arteriosum
Failure of the aorticopulmonary septum to form
Anterosuperior displacement of the infundibular septum
Failure of the aorticopulmonary septum to spiral

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Narrowing of the ascending aorta at the sinotubular junction is seen in supravalvular aortic stenosis, which can manifest with a systolic murmur and heart failure. However, the systolic murmur in supravalvular aortic stenosis is heard best at the 1st right intercostal space rather than the left paravertebral interscapular area. Furthermore, blood pressure and oxygen saturation differentials would not be expected. This patient has a fixed left ventricular outflow tract obstruction that is located at the aortic isthmus.

B) CORRECT:

This patient's differential cyanosis and blood pressure differential between the upper and lower extremities, in conjunction with a systolic murmur over the left interscapular space (due to blood flow through the aortic narrowing), suggest coarctation of the aorta (CoA). In CoA, the narrowing of the thoracic segment of the descending aorta near the ligamentum arteriosum (aortic isthmus) causes an increased blood flow proximal to the narrowing and a decreased blood flow distal to the narrowing, resulting in blood pressure and oxygen saturation differentials like those seen in this patient. Newborns can remain asymptomatic until the closure of the ductus arteriosus (DA), after which there is an increase in left ventricular pressure and volume overload that results in heart failure.
Image Description:

(1) Stenosis distal to the left subclavian artery results in hypertension (↑ BP) in the upper extremities and the head, and hypotension (↓ BP) in the lower extremities and abdomen.

(2) If coarctation involves the origin of the left subclavian artery, BP in the right arm and head will be higher than in the left arm, lower extremities, and abdomen.

C) INCORRECT:

A failure of the aorticopulmonary septum to form is the cause of persistent truncus arteriosus, which manifests with cyanosis and heart failure. However, cyanosis as a result of this condition is not confined to the lower extremities and blood pressure and oxygen saturation differentials between the upper and lower extremities would not be expected.

D) INCORRECT:

Anterosuperior displacement of the infundibular septum is seen in tetralogy of Fallot (TOF), which can manifest with cyanosis and a systolic murmur. However, the systolic murmur in TOF is mainly caused by right ventricular outflow obstruction and is heard best at the left upper sternal border rather than the left paravertebral interscapular area. Furthermore, cyanosis is not confined to the lower extremities and blood pressure and oxygen saturation differentials between the upper and lower extremities would not be expected.

E) INCORRECT:

A failure of the aorticopulmonary septum to spiral is the cause of transposition of the great vessels (TGV), which manifests with cyanosis and tachypnea. However, cyanosis from TGV is typically evident in the first hours after birth unless intracardiac left-right shunting (e.g., patent ductus arteriosus, atrial septal defect) allows for oxygenated blood to enter the systemic circulation. Moreover, patients with TGV may present with reverse differential cyanosis but differential cyanosis, hypoxemia confined to the lower extremities, and blood pressure differential between the upper and lower extremities would not be expected.
questions.hint: This neonate presents with features of congestive heart failure including poor feeding, excessive diaphoresis, irritability, respiratory distress, pulmonary edema, and hepatomegaly. The underlying condition is also often seen in patients with Turner syndrome.

questions.text: An otherwise healthy 15-year-old boy comes to the office for a routine health maintenance examination. He feels well and is doing well in school. He has no history of serious illness. Vital signs are within normal limits. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac auscultation shows no murmur, but a wide-split S2 that does not change with respiration. If left untreated, this patient is at increased risk for which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) typically manifests with a systolic ejection murmur caused by left ventricular outflow tract obstruction (LVOT). Hypertrophic myocardium, fibrosis, and disarrangement of cardiac myocytes predispose to potentially lethal ventricular arrhythmias, which can lead to sudden cardiac death, usually during or after physical activity. If severe enough (and then likely symptomatic), HCM can also lead to the paradoxical splitting of S2, in which the aortic valve closes later than the pulmonary valve (P2, then A2). In an otherwise healthy patient, there is a more likely anatomic cause that explains the fixed, wide splitting of S2 in which the pulmonary valve closes later than the aortic valve (A2, then P2).

B) INCORRECT:

Cerebral aneurysms are associated with coarctation of the aorta. Coarctation can manifest with a systolic ejection murmur over the left paravertebral area due to blood flowing through the aortic narrowing and/or a continuous murmur from collateral vessels heard between the shoulder blades. It does not manifest with a fixed, wide splitting of S2. Coarctation of the aorta may also be accompanied by other symptoms, such as hypertension, lower extremity cyanosis, lower extremity claudication, cold feet, dyspnea on exertion, or chest pain.

C) INCORRECT:

Left ventricular hypertrophy is a common consequence of volume overload or increased pressures in the left ventricle (e.g., aortic regurgitation, aortic stenosis). ASD (seen here), PFO, and VSD increase the volume in the right ventricle and subsequently lead to right ventricular hypertrophy. In the case of large septal defects, untreated chronic volume overload in the right heart leads to severe hypertrophy and pressure reversal (Eisenmenger syndrome), which then shunts deoxygenated blood to the left ventricle, leading to cyanosis.

D) CORRECT:

Paradoxical embolism is associated with ASDs, patent foramen ovale, and ventricular septal defects (VSD), which allows right-sided thromboemboli to enter the left-sided circulation by bypassing the pulmonary circulation. An ASD causes wide splitting of S2 that is fixed (does not change with respiration) due to increased volume within the pulmonary circulation. A VSD can manifest with a holosystolic murmur.
Image Description:

In the presence of a patent foramen ovale, transient increases in right atrial pressure (e.g., when coughing) can allow emboli from the venous system to pass from the right atrium to the left atrium. From there, they can enter systemic arterial circulation and cause arterial embolism (e.g., stroke).

E) INCORRECT:

Congenital heart defects (e.g., ventricular septal defect, pulmonary stenosis) and predamaged heart valves (e.g., aortic stenosis, mitral valve regurgitation) can predispose to infective endocarditis. However, this risk is negligible in ASDs and PFOs.
questions.hint: This patient's auscultation findings are likely caused by an atrial septal defect (ASD).

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the office for a well-child examination. He was born at 38 weeks' gestation and weighed 2766 g (6 lb 2 oz). He now weighs 14 kg (31 lb). He is at 60th percentile for height and 55th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. The lungs are clear to auscultation. A grade 3/6 systolic ejection murmur is heard at the left upper sternal border and a grade 2/6 mid-diastolic murmur is heard at the left lower sternal border. S2 is widely split and does not vary with respiration. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A patent ductus arteriosus is often discovered incidentally in asymptomatic children. However, cardiac auscultation would usually show a loud continuous machine-like murmur (due to the constant left-to-right shunt) that is best heard in the left infraclavicular region.

B) CORRECT:

This child presents with typical auscultation findings of an atrial septal defect (ASD) with the fixed (no change with respiration), widely split S2 being the most specific. Right ventricular volume overload due to the left-to-right shunt across the ASD causes a delayed closure of the pulmonary valve relative to the aortic valve. Since the right and left sides of the heart communicate, the pressure difference that normally exists during respiration evens out; therefore, the duration of the split does not change with inspiration or expiration. The increased blood flow through the right side of the heart also causes a pulmonary flow murmur, which explains the patient's systolic ejection murmur at the left upper sternal border. Some patients with ASD can also have a soft, mid-diastolic murmur at the left lower sternal border secondary to increased flow across the tricuspid valve.

C) INCORRECT:

While a mid-diastolic murmur may be appreciated in patients with a ventricular septal defect (VSD) as a result of increased flow through the mitral valve, this murmur would usually be best heard at the cardiac apex (mitral area) rather than the left lower sternal border (tricuspid area). The classic auscultatory finding at the left lower sternal border in patients with a VSD would be a harsh holosystolic murmur.

D) INCORRECT:

Isolated pulmonary valve stenosis can cause a systolic ejection murmur at the left upper sternal border and a wide S2 split but would not explain the mid-diastolic murmur at the left lower sternal border or the fixed split in S2 (i.e., no variation with respiration).

E) INCORRECT:

Coarctation of the aorta usually presents a systolic ejection murmur in the paravertebral region due to blood flow through the aortic narrowing. It would not explain the fixed split in S2 or the mid-diastolic murmur at the left lower sternal border.
questions.hint: This patient presents with a congenital heart defect that may lead to paradoxical embolism and stroke if not surgically corrected.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the office because of recurrent nosebleeds and fatigue for the past 2 months. He also frequently complains his head hurts. The patient has met all motoric milestones for his age but does not like to run because his legs start to hurt if he does. He is at the 40th percentile for both height and weight. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse rate is 125/min, respirations are 32/min, and blood pressure in the right arm is 130/85 mm Hg. A grade 2/6 systolic murmur is heard in the left paravertebral region. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Jugular venous distention (JVD) indicates elevated central venous pressure and can be seen in congenital heart defects affecting right-sided heart function, such as tricuspid valve abnormalities or severe pulmonary stenosis. These conditions can lead to right-sided heart failure and venous congestion. However, JVD is not typically associated with coarctation of the aorta.

B) INCORRECT:

Interarm differences in tissue oxygenation and blood pressure can be a finding of coarctation of the aorta in the rare case that the narrowing is proximal to the left subclavian artery. In such patients, blood pressure in the right arm would be markedly higher than in the left arm and oxygen saturation would be lower in the left arm. However, coarctation of the aorta most commonly presents with differences in blood pressure between the upper and the lower extremities.

C) INCORRECT:

Congenital pulmonary valve stenosis is a characteristic feature of tetralogy of Fallot. A systolic ejection murmur can be present and is usually best heard at the left sternal border, rather than the left paravertebral region. Patients usually present with (mild) cyanosis and intermittent hypoxic episodes that improve with squatting, none of which are seen here. Coarctation of the aorta is characterized by an outflow obstruction of the left ventricle.

D) INCORRECT:

Left-axis deviation and increased R wave amplitude in V5–V6 on ECG are signs of left ventricular hypertrophy. While myocardial hypertrophy is one of the compensatory mechanisms to counter the aortic narrowing in patients with coarctation of the aorta, such as this 3-year-old boy, the changes in ECG vary with age and degree of stenosis, and it usually takes several years before the hypertrophy becomes apparent. In older children and adults, ECG may show signs of left ventricular hypertrophy in the left precordial leads (e.g., positive Sokolow-Lyon criteria).

E) CORRECT:

In patients with CoA, delayed or even absent lower extremity pulses are expected distal to the stenotic portion of the aorta. Since the post-stenotic blood supply is limited, the resulting lower-extremity hypoxia becomes evident, especially during exertion, which is a strong sign of intermittent claudication, as in this patient.

Doppler echocardiography is the confirmatory test of choice and can identify the location and extent of the stenosis.
Image Description:

(1) Stenosis distal to the left subclavian artery results in hypertension (↑ BP) in the upper extremities and the head, and hypotension (↓ BP) in the lower extremities and abdomen.

(2) If coarctation involves the origin of the left subclavian artery, BP in the right arm and head will be higher than in the left arm, lower extremities, and abdomen.
questions.hint: This patient's general fatigue, hypertension, low-grade systolic ejection murmur, lower-extremity claudication, headaches, and recurrent epistaxis together suggest coarctation of the aorta (CoA).

questions.text: A 7-day-old male newborn is brought to the office because of a 3-day history of feeding difficulty. The mother says that he sweats a lot and is uncomfortable during feeds. He was born at 36 weeks' gestation following a spontaneous vaginal delivery. He currently weighs 2900 g (6 lb 6 oz) and is 49 cm (19 in) in length. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse rate is 170/min, respirations are 55/min, and blood pressure is 80/50 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 99%. Cardiopulmonary examination shows a loud machinery murmur along the upper left sternal border. After confirming the diagnosis via echocardiography, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Outpatient observation is an option for small, asymptomatic PDA without evidence of sequelae (e.g., ventricular hypertrophy). This patient shows signs of heart failure and consequent failure to thrive; correction of the PDA is, therefore, necessary.

B) INCORRECT:

Prostaglandins maintain ductus arteriosus patency and are indicated as temporary therapy in ductal-dependent congenital heart diseases. Ductal-dependent lesions typically manifest at birth with pronounced cyanosis. This patient's murmur and normal pulse oximetry reading are suggestive of an isolated PDA; prostaglandins would worsen his condition.

C) INCORRECT:

Transcatheter or surgical closure is the treatment of choice for infants ≥ 6 kg, children, and adults. In preterm infants, procedural closure is generally only used if pharmacological treatment is unsuccessful.

D) CORRECT:

Nonselective cyclooxygenase inhibitors such as ibuprofen and indomethacin are the mainstay of treatment for symptomatic PDA in premature infants. Prostaglandins keep the ductus arteriosus patent, and by inhibiting cyclooxygenase, NSAIDs decrease prostaglandin production and thus promote ductal closure. NSAIDs are only effective in preterm infants.

Transcatheter or surgical closure is the treatment of choice for infants ≥ 6 kg, children, and adults. In preterm infants, procedural closure is generally only used if pharmacological treatment is unsuccessful.
Image Description:

In patent ductus arteriosus, there is a left-to-right shunt, with blood flowing from the aorta to the pulmonary arteries during both systole and diastole (1). This shunt leads to volume overload (recirculation) of the blood within the pulmonary vessels, the left atrium, and left ventricle (2). Eventually, because of the increased blood flow to the pulmonary circulation, pulmonary hypertension may develop as well as Eisenmenger syndrome, which involves a shunt reversal. The left-to-right-shunt without cyanosis becomes a right-to-left shunt with cyanosis (3).

Blue: structures that contain deoxygenated blood; Red: structures that contain oxygenated blood; Pink: structures that contain mixed blood

E) INCORRECT:

Although chest x-ray may show signs of PDA (prominent main pulmonary artery and aortic knob, along with signs of heart failure), it would not be needed in addition to echocardiography (the imaging test of choice), which is more sensitive and specific, for confirming the diagnosis.
questions.hint: Features of heart failure (e.g., poor feeding, sweating, failure to thrive) with a loud continuous (machinery) murmur near the left infraclavicular region are highly suggestive of a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), for which premature birth is a risk factor. Doppler echocardiography showing blood flow from the aorta into the pulmonary artery confirms the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 6-week-old boy with trisomy 21 is brought in by his mother for reduced feeding frequency, intermittent diaphoresis, and an increased respiratory rate. He was born at full term after an uncomplicated pregnancy. Routine screening at the time, including measurement of oxygen saturation to screen for cyanotic congenital heart disease, was normal. His current temperature is 37.6°C (99.6°F), respirations are 68/min, pulse is 140/min, blood pressure is 70/40 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 94% while he breathes ambient air. Both lungs are clear to auscultation, but he appears to be in moderate respiratory distress, with intermittent nasal flaring and intercostal retractions. There is a 2/6 systolic ejection murmur at the left upper sternal border with a wide, fixed split second heart sound and an active precordium. Central capillary refill is approximately 3 to 4 seconds. Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Transposition of the great vessels is a cyanotic congenital heart defect that manifests with significant hypoxemia in the immediate newborn period.

B) INCORRECT:

Although the timing of clinical presentation varies according to the degree of obstruction of pulmonary blood flow, infants with severe right ventricular outflow tract obstruction related to tetralogy of Fallot or isolated pulmonary valve abnormalities typically present with respiratory distress, cyanosis, and hemodynamic instability in the early newborn period after closure of the ductus arteriosus.

C) INCORRECT:

Infants with a large patent ductus arteriosus also may have heart failure symptoms. However, clinical examination generally reveals a continuous machinery murmur, bounding pulses, and widened pulse pressure.

D) CORRECT:

Children with trisomy 21 are at increased risk for congenital heart defects — most commonly, atrioventricular septal defects. Given this increased risk, newborns with trisomy 21 should not only undergo routine screening with pre- and postductal saturations; they should also undergo echocardiography between birth and discharge so that they can be managed proactively.

Infants with atrioventricular septal defects typically present similarly to the infant in the vignette — i.e., with clinical signs and symptoms of heart failure, such as tachypnea, diaphoresis, pallor, and poor feeding. Complete atrioventricular canal defect, which is caused by failed fusion between the superior and inferior endocardial cushions, is characterized by a contiguous atrial and ventricular septal defect and a common atrioventricular valve (tricuspid and mitral valves). It manifests with early and severe heart failure.

A chest radiograph and an electrocardiogram (ECG) are generally part of the initial evaluation of heart failure. Chest radiography often reveals cardiomegaly and increased pulmonary vascular markings. ECG may show various nonspecific findings consistent with the underlying structural and anatomic abnormalities.

Key learning point: Forty to fifty percent of children with trisomy 21 have a congenital heart defect, most commonly an atrioventricular septal defect.

E) INCORRECT:

Hypoplastic left heart syndrome is uniformly fatal in the first few days of life if undiagnosed or left untreated; a child with this diagnosis would not have survived to a 6-week visit.
questions.hint: Down syndrome is associated with endocardial cushion defects.

questions.text: A 2-week-old male newborn is brought to the office for a follow-up examination. He was born at term and the pregnancy was uncomplicated. He has been feeding well and passing adequate amounts of urine. He appears healthy. He is at the 60th percentile for length and 40th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. A grade 5/6 holosystolic murmur is heard over the left lower sternal border and a thrill is present at the same location. Echocardiography shows a 2-mm membranous ventricular septal defect. There is no evidence of ventricular enlargement and Doppler assessment of pulmonary artery pressure shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Surgical closure of VSDs before the age of 2 years is indicated for patients who have persistent heart failure symptoms or develop certain echocardiographic findings (e.g., left ventricular dilation, reversible pulmonary hypertension). This patient is asymptomatic and has no signs of complications. The patients who are most likely to develop complications and therefore require early surgical closure have medium or large VSDs; these VSDs manifest with softer murmurs and are typically not associated with a cardiac thrill.

B) INCORRECT:

Prostaglandin E1 (PGE1) therapy is used to maintain a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) and is indicated for duct-dependent CHDs (e.g., pulmonary atresia, transposition of the great vessels, hypoplastic left heart syndrome). Patients with duct-dependent CHDs typically present with cyanosis and/or shock within 24 hours of birth, in contrast to this asymptomatic neonate. This patient has a VSD, which causes a left-to-right shunt, as would a PDA. Treatment with PGE1 could actually worsen this patient's shunting and cause heart failure.

C) CORRECT:

Small VSDs typically close spontaneously without complication, so asymptomatic patients should be reevaluated at 6 months of age for spontaneous closure. If the patient remains asymptomatic at a 6-month follow-up but their murmur persists, reevaluation at 1 year of age is indicated. Asymptomatic patients should subsequently be reevaluated every 2 years.

If symptoms of heart failure (e.g., tachypnea, distress during feeding, failure to thrive) arise, patients should be referred for evaluation and medical therapy (diuretics, immunoprophylaxis, nutritional support). Surgical closure is indicated for patients who remain symptomatic despite medical therapy or develop certain echocardiographic findings (e.g., left ventricular dilation, reversible pulmonary hypertension).

D) INCORRECT:

Indomethacin is used to induce closure of a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), which can be asymptomatic but would manifest with a characteristic machine-like continuous murmur on cardiac auscultation. This patient's auscultatory and echocardiographic findings indicate a different diagnosis, for which indomethacin therapy is not indicated.

E) INCORRECT:

Closure of the VSD with an Amplatzer® device via cardiac catheterization is generally reserved for patients with a residual VSD after surgical closure, patients with contraindications for surgical closure (e.g., swiss-cheese septum, poorly accessible muscular VSDs), and for older children with small, restrictive muscular VSDs with significant left-to-right flow. Transcatheter closure is contraindicated in patients with membranous VSDs (which are the most common type of VSDs) because of the high risk of heart block after the procedure.
questions.hint: Echocardiography confirms the diagnosis of a small ventricular septal defect (VSD), which is the most common congenital heart defect (CHD) and causes a holosystolic murmur best heard over the left lower sternal border. Small VSDs (diameter ≤ 3 mm) cause less left-to-right shunting but result in louder murmurs when compared to medium or large VSDs.

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl is brought to the office for a follow-up visit after an abnormal heart sound was noted during a routine examination. Her parents report that she frequently becomes tired during meals and has had multiple respiratory infections over the past year. She is at the 30th percentile for height and 15th percentile for weight. Echocardiography shows a defect in the membranous portion of the interventricular septum and a moderately decreased left ventricular ejection fraction. Physical examination is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Holosystolic murmur that increases with hand clenching
Wide, fixed splitting of the second heart sound
Systolic ejection murmur that increases with forced exhalation against a closed glottis
Diastolic murmur preceded by opening snap
Continuous murmur that is loudest at the second heart sound

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Hand clenching increases systemic vascular resistance and afterload, which causes left-to-right shunting of blood and makes the holosystolic murmur in VSD more audible. Small VSDs may cause a loud holosystolic murmur with palpable thrill due to the large pressure differential between the left and right ventricles, while larger VSDs are typically less obvious on auscultation. If left untreated, VSDs can lead to pulmonary hypertension and heart failure.
Image Description:

Holosystolic murmur (often referred to as “pansystolic murmur” in the case of a ventricular septal defect)

B) INCORRECT:

A wide, fixed (i.e., does not change with respiration) splitting of the second heart sound is characteristic of atrial septal defect (ASD). It occurs due to right ventricular overload and subsequent delay in pulmonary valve closure. Fixed splitting of the second heart sound is not a common feature of VSD.

C) INCORRECT:

A systolic ejection murmur that increases with forced exhalation against a closed glottis (Valsalva maneuver) is characteristic of hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM). The Valsalva maneuver reduces both preload and left ventricular afterload, which would exacerbate the subaortic stenosis in HOCM but reduce the left-to-right shunt of blood in VSD. The Valsalva maneuver would therefore decrease this patient's murmur intensity.

D) INCORRECT:

A diastolic murmur preceded by an opening snap at the apex is characteristic of mitral stenosis (MS). The opening snap occurs when leaflet motion suddenly stops during diastole after the stenosed valve has opened fully. While a short, mid-diastolic murmur can sometimes be heard in VSD due to increased blood flow across the mitral valve, an opening snap would not be expected.

E) INCORRECT:

A continuous murmur that becomes louder at the second heart sound is characteristic of patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). The murmur is best appreciated in the left infraclavicular region and results from the constant flow of blood from the high pressure aorta to the low pressure pulmonary artery. VSD is characterized by a different finding on auscultation.
questions.hint: Auscultation findings for a symptomatic ventricular septal defect (VSD) in a patient this age will reflect shunting of blood from the left to right ventricle.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the office for a well-child examination. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. He is at 70th percentile for height and 55th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a harsh, holosystolic murmur over the left lower sternal border. When he clenches his fist forcefully for a sustained time, the intensity of the murmur increases. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patent ductus arteriosus leads to a murmur heard best at the left infraclavicular region. This murmur occurs during both diastole and systole (i.e., a continuous murmur), unlike the harsh holosystolic murmur seen here.

B) INCORRECT:

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy can cause a murmur as a result of mitral regurgitation (MR) or left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction. A murmur due to MR is holosystolic and increases in intensity with maneuvers that increase left ventricular afterload (e.g., handgrip) but is heard best at the cardiac apex (5th intercostal space in the midclavicular line). A murmur due to LVOT obstruction is heard best at the left lower sternal border but has a midsystolic, crescendo-decrescendo character and decreases in intensity with maneuvers that increase left ventricular afterload.

C) CORRECT:

A ventricular septal defect (VSD), which causes a left-to-right shunt, leads to a harsh holosystolic murmur because of turbulent blood flow across the defect. The murmur is heard best at the left lower sternal border (tricuspid area) and becomes louder with maneuvers that increase left ventricular afterload (e.g., handgrip) because of increased left-to-right shunting. The murmur is typically louder with smaller defects because of the large pressure difference between the left and right ventricles.

D) INCORRECT:

Mitral valve prolapse leads to a systolic murmur that increases in intensity with maneuvers that increase afterload (e.g., handgrip), which is seen here. However, this murmur is heard best at the cardiac apex (5th intercostal space in the midclavicular line). In addition, this murmur has a late systolic crescendo character, and it is preceded by a click due to tensing of the chordae tendinae.

E) INCORRECT:

An atrial septal defect can cause a systolic murmur because of increased flow across the pulmonary valve, but the murmur is heard best at the left upper sternal border. In addition, this murmur has a midsystolic crescendo-decrescendo character, and it is accompanied by a wide, fixed split second heart sound.
questions.hint: The handgrip maneuver increases afterload by increasing total peripheral resistance.

questions.text: A 3-month-old boy is brought to the office for a routine follow-up examination. He was delivered at 32 weeks' gestation to a 35-year-old woman. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a grade 4/6 continuous murmur heard best in the left infraclavicular region. Which of the following is the most likely cause for this patient's findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) manifests with a continuous machinery murmur best heard in the left infraclavicular area. The machinery murmur is generated as blood continuously shunts from the high-pressure aorta through the ductus arteriosus into the low-pressure pulmonary artery. It may envelop the S2 and is not usually affected by positional changes. Patients with moderate-sized PDAs may present with bounding pulses, widened pulse pressure, and symptoms of heart failure.

Key learning point: A continuous, machinery-like murmur best heard at the left infraclavicular area is characteristic of a patent ductus arteriosus, commonly seen in premature infants.
Image Description:

Continuous systolic and diastolic heart murmur (machinery murmur)

B) INCORRECT:

Ventricular septal defects (VSD) manifest with holosystolic, harsh sounding murmurs, best heard in the left lower sternal border. These murmurs often obliterate the S2 and are associated with a palpable thrill. Neonates present with an asymptomatic heart murmur or, in cases of moderate-to-large sized defects, with signs of heart failure. The examination findings in this patient reveal a continuous murmur, which is not suggestive of a VSD.

C) INCORRECT:

Atrial septal defects (ASD) manifest with pulmonary outflow tract murmurs heard best at the left upper sternal border and are often associated with fixed splitting of S2. ASDs are often low-velocity shunts that produce insufficient flow to be audible. Larger shunts may cause diastolic flow murmurs across the tricuspid valve owing to a large left-to-right shunt. However, a continuous murmur would not be seen in patients with an ASD.

D) INCORRECT:

Persistent truncus arteriosus results in a single conduit providing mixed venous and arterial blood to the coronary, pulmonary, and systemic circulations. Cardiac examination findings would include a single loud S2, the presence of an ejection click at the cardiac apex or left sternal border, and harsh systolic murmurs at the left sternal border, unlike the continuous murmur heard in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) is associated with a harsh crescendo-decrescendo murmur best heard along the left mid- to upper-sternal border. The murmur can decrease in intensity as the degree of right ventricular outflow tract obstruction worsens because of increased right-to-left shunting of blood. The examination findings of a continuous murmur would not be seen in patients with TOF.
questions.hint: This patient's condition typically affects premature infants or infants with a congenital rubella infection.

questions.text:
An 8-month-old boy is brought to the Pediatrician due to difficulty feeding, excessive sweating, and poor weight gain over the past three months. Examination reveals a harsh, loud holosystolic murmur best heard at the lower left sternal border, with a palpable thrill in the same area. Peripheral pulses are normal.
Which of the following conditions best explains these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Mitral regurgitation also presents with a holosystolic murmur, but it is best heard at the cardiac apex and radiates to the axilla. The murmur's location and the presence of a palpable thrill at the lower left sternal border suggest a central defect rather than mitral valve pathology. Additionally, the infant's symptoms align more with congenital defects causing volume overload.

B) INCORRECT:

Tricuspid regurgitation can produce a holosystolic murmur at the lower left sternal border, but it is less common in infants and typically involves additional structural abnormalities. The palpable thrill and the infant's symptoms suggest a congenital defect with significant volume overload rather than isolated tricuspid valve insufficiency.

C) INCORRECT:

An atrial septal defect (ASD) typically produces a soft systolic ejection murmur and is associated with fixed splitting of the second heart sound. ASDs are often asymptomatic in infancy and do not usually present with a harsh holosystolic murmur or a palpable thrill. The infant's symptoms and auscultatory findings suggest a more hemodynamically significant defect.

D) CORRECT:

A ventricular septal defect (VSD) manifests with a harsh, loud holosystolic murmur best heard at the lower left sternal border due to turbulent blood flow from the left to the right ventricle. The palpable thrill indicates significant turbulence through a small defect. In infants, a VSD can lead to volume overload, resulting in symptoms such as feeding difficulties, excessive sweating, and poor weight gain. These clinical features reflect the hemodynamic impact of the defect, which is characteristic of a VSD.

Key learning point: A loud pan-systolic murmur at the lower left sternal border is characteristic of a ventricular septal defect (VSD).

questions.text:
A 2-month-old infant is brought to the clinic with difficulty feeding, poor weight gain, and frequent sweating during feeds for the past two weeks. The mother reports periods of rapid breathing, especially when the infant is crying. Examination shows mild cyanosis, subcostal retractions, and mild hepatomegaly. Cardiac auscultation reveals a harsh pansystolic murmur best heard at the lower left sternal border. Pulses are normal.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Atrial septal defect typically produces a soft systolic ejection murmur and fixed splitting of the second heart sound, not a harsh pansystolic murmur. Infants with atrial septal defect are often asymptomatic or have mild symptoms later in life. Marked signs of heart failure, such as difficulty feeding and hepatomegaly, are uncommon.

B) CORRECT:

Ventricular septal defect involves an abnormal opening in the interventricular septum, allowing blood to flow from the left to the right ventricle during systole. This left-to-right shunt increases pulmonary blood flow, leading to volume overload and respiratory distress in infants. Clinical features such as difficulty feeding, poor weight gain, and diaphoresis during feeding result from the increased metabolic demand to maintain oxygenation. The harsh, pansystolic murmur at the lower left sternal border is characteristic of turbulent flow across the defect. Subcostal retractions and mild hepatomegaly indicate developing congestive heart failure.

Key learning point: In infants presenting with respiratory distress, poor feeding, and poor weight gain, a pansystolic murmur at the lower left sternal edge is suggestive of a ventricular septal defect, which can lead to congestive heart failure symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

Patent ductus arteriosus is associated with a continuous, machinery-like murmur best heard in the infraclavicular area, not a pansystolic murmur. It often results in bounding peripheral pulses and wide pulse pressure, which are absent here. The murmur's description and normal pulses do not align with patent ductus arteriosus.

D) INCORRECT:

Tetralogy of Fallot is a cyanotic congenital heart defect, but the infant's symptoms suggest congestive heart failure due to volume overload, typical of a left-to-right shunt. The harsh pansystolic murmur aligns with holosystolic defects, not the systolic ejection murmur from pulmonary stenosis in Tetralogy of Fallot.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old woman presents with exertional dyspnea and occasional palpitations. Physical examination reveals a harsh, ejection systolic murmur best heard in the left second intercostal space that becomes louder with inspiration. Her jugular venous pressure is elevated. She denies chest pain (see report).

Oxygen saturation
98% at rest

ECG: Right ventricular hypertrophy
Which of the following is the most likely explanation of these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tricuspid regurgitation is associated with a holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border, increasing with inspiration. The described harsh, ejection systolic murmur at the left second intercostal space suggests pulmonary valve involvement. Right ventricular hypertrophy indicates pressure overload, typical of obstructive lesions like pulmonary stenosis, not volume overload from tricuspid regurgitation.

B) INCORRECT:

An atrial septal defect (ASD) causes a soft systolic ejection murmur at the left upper sternal border with fixed splitting of the second heart sound. The harsh murmur and elevated jugular venous pressure suggest significant right ventricular pressure overload, not the volume overload seen in ASD. Right ventricular hypertrophy from pressure overload is inconsistent with ASD.

C) CORRECT:

Congenital pulmonary stenosis involves narrowing of the pulmonary valve, causing turbulent blood flow and a harsh, ejection systolic murmur best heard at the left second intercostal space. The murmur's intensity increases with inspiration due to augmented right ventricular filling. This condition leads to elevated right ventricular pressures, resulting in right ventricular hypertrophy, as seen on electrocardiogram. Additionally, increased right ventricular workload can elevate right atrial and systemic venous pressures, manifesting as elevated jugular venous pressure. These findings collectively indicate congenital pulmonary stenosis.

Key learning point: An ejection systolic murmur at the left second intercostal space that increases with inspiration, along with elevated JVP and right ventricular hypertrophy, is indicative of congenital pulmonary stenosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Aortic stenosis typically presents with a murmur best heard at the right upper sternal border, radiating to the carotids, and is associated with left ventricular hypertrophy. The murmur does not change with inspiration, unlike the right-sided murmur described. The patient's findings, including right ventricular hypertrophy and elevated jugular venous pressure, do not align with aortic stenosis.

questions.text:
A 9-month-old infant is brought to a routine visit. The infant has no feeding difficulties and normal activity level. Weight and height are at the 50th percentile. Examination reveals a harsh holosystolic murmur best heard at the left lower sternal border. There are no signs of heart failure (see report).
Echocardiography: Small muscular defect in the interventricular septum with normal chamber sizes and function
What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Continue to observe with periodic follow-up

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Small muscular ventricular septal defects (VSDs) in infants often have a benign course, as indicated by the absence of heart failure signs and normal growth. The harsh holosystolic murmur reflects turbulent flow through the defect, but normal chamber sizes and function on echocardiography suggest a hemodynamically insignificant shunt. These defects frequently close spontaneously or remain small without adverse effects. Periodic follow-up allows for monitoring any changes in the defect's impact or the child's clinical status, ensuring timely intervention if necessary.

Key learning point: Small muscular VSDs in asymptomatic children often close spontaneously, and watchful waiting is the appropriate management strategy.

B) INCORRECT:

Surgical repair is indicated for large VSDs or those causing hemodynamic compromise, such as heart failure or chamber enlargement. This infant has a small defect with normal chamber sizes and function, and is asymptomatic with normal growth, making surgical intervention unnecessary.

C) INCORRECT:

Transcatheter closure is reserved for larger or symptomatic VSDs causing significant hemodynamic compromise. This infant's small defect, normal chamber sizes, and absence of heart failure signs suggest a conservative approach, as small muscular VSDs often close spontaneously.

D) INCORRECT:

Diuretics are used to manage heart failure symptoms, such as volume overload and pulmonary congestion, seen in larger VSDs. This infant has a small defect without signs of heart failure, normal growth, and no respiratory distress, so diuretics are not indicated.

questions.text:
An 8-week-old infant with Down syndrome presents with poor feeding, frequent sweating during feeds, and slow weight gain. Examination reveals a widely fixed splitting of S2 and a holosystolic murmur at the lower left sternal border (see reports).

Chest radiography: Cardiomegaly with increased pulmonary vascular markings
Echocardiography: Pending result

Which congenital heart lesion is most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) presents with a continuous 'machinery' murmur, not a holosystolic murmur. While PDA can cause volume overload and cardiomegaly, the auscultatory findings and widely fixed splitting of S2 are not typical of PDA. Down syndrome is more commonly associated with endocardial cushion defects.

B) CORRECT:

In infants with Down syndrome, atrioventricular septal defect (AVSD) is a common congenital heart defect. It results from abnormal endocardial cushion development, leading to a common atrioventricular junction and defects in the atrial and ventricular septa. The holosystolic murmur at the lower left sternal border and widely fixed splitting of S2 indicate increased pulmonary blood flow and right ventricular volume overload. Chest radiography showing cardiomegaly and increased pulmonary vascular markings supports a significant left-to-right shunt, characteristic of AVSD. The symptoms of poor feeding, sweating during feeds, and failure to thrive reflect the hemodynamic burden of this defect.

Key learning point: In infants with Down syndrome, atrioventricular septal defect is a common congenital heart defect, characterized by fixed splitting of S2, biventricular hypertrophy, and significant left-to-right shunt.

C) INCORRECT:

Tetralogy of Fallot is a cyanotic defect with right ventricular outflow tract obstruction, producing a harsh systolic ejection murmur. It is associated with decreased pulmonary vascular markings, not the increased markings seen here. The widely fixed splitting of S2 and holosystolic murmur suggest a left-to-right shunt, not typical of Tetralogy of Fallot.

D) INCORRECT:

Ostium secundum atrial septal defect (ASD) is associated with widely fixed splitting of S2 due to a left-to-right shunt. However, it typically presents with a soft systolic ejection murmur, not a holosystolic murmur. The significant heart failure symptoms and radiographic findings suggest a larger shunt, more consistent with defects like a ventricular septal defect.

questions.text:
An 18-day-old infant is brought to the clinic for evaluation due to difficulty feeding for the past week. He often stops feeding after a few minutes, appears tachypneic, and has episodes of sweating. On examination, a harsh holosystolic murmur is noted at the left lower sternal border, and peripheral pulses are slightly diminished. His weight is below the 5th percentile.

Heart rate
170/min

Which of the following factors best explains this infant’s feeding difficulties?

choices.text: Excessive energy expenditure from impaired cardiac function

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Insufficient breast milk intake might cause poor weight gain but would not account for the cardiac findings such as a harsh holosystolic murmur, tachypnea, and diminished peripheral pulses. These signs suggest a cardiac issue rather than a nutritional deficit.

B) INCORRECT:

While immature oropharyngeal swallowing mechanisms can cause feeding difficulties in preterm infants, this 18-day-old infant should have developed adequate coordination. The presence of tachypnea, tachycardia, diaphoresis, and a cardiac murmur suggests a cardiac anomaly rather than a neuromuscular issue.

C) INCORRECT:

Gastroesophageal reflux can cause feeding difficulties but does not explain the systemic signs such as tachypnea, diaphoresis, and a harsh holosystolic murmur. These findings indicate a cardiac pathology, not reflux.

D) CORRECT:

In infants with congenital heart disease, impaired cardiac function leads to increased metabolic demands due to the heart's need to work harder to maintain circulation. This results in excessive energy expenditure, especially during activities like feeding, causing early fatigue. Signs such as tachypnea, tachycardia, and diaphoresis during feeding reflect the cardiovascular strain. The combination of these symptoms with a harsh holosystolic murmur and diminished peripheral pulses suggests heart failure, explaining the feeding difficulties and poor weight gain.

Key learning point: In neonates with congenital heart defects, difficulty feeding is a common symptom due to increased metabolic demands and decreased cardiac output.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old boy is brought to the clinic for recurring headaches and leg discomfort with prolonged walking. He occasionally experiences mild chest pain during physical activity. Pulse examination reveals diminished femoral pulses compared to brachial pulses. A harsh systolic murmur is best heard along the back.

Blood pressure

140/85 mm Hg in the arms and 100/60 mm Hg in the legs

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patent ductus arteriosus presents with a continuous, machine-like murmur best heard in the left infraclavicular area, along with wide pulse pressure and bounding pulses. The described harsh systolic murmur along the back and diminished femoral pulses suggest an obstructive process, not a shunting lesion.

B) INCORRECT:

Tetralogy of Fallot is a cyanotic heart defect with features like ventricular septal defect and right ventricular outflow tract obstruction. It presents with cyanosis and hypoxic spells, not differential blood pressure between the upper and lower body, which is more indicative of coarctation of the aorta.

C) CORRECT:

Coarctation of the aorta is characterized by a congenital narrowing of the aorta, typically distal to the left subclavian artery. This narrowing results in elevated blood pressure in the upper extremities and reduced pressure in the lower extremities, as evidenced by the higher arm blood pressure and diminished femoral pulses. The leg discomfort during exertion is due to impaired perfusion to the lower limbs, while proximal hypertension can cause headaches and exertional chest pain. The harsh systolic murmur heard along the back is due to turbulent blood flow across the narrowed segment and collateral circulation development.

Key learning point: Coarctation of the aorta is characterized by hypertension in the upper limbs and delayed or weaker pulses in the lower limbs due to narrowing of the aorta, typically distal to the left subclavian artery.

D) INCORRECT:

Aortic stenosis, often due to a congenital bicuspid aortic valve, presents with an ejection systolic murmur best heard at the right upper sternal border, radiating to the neck. It does not typically cause a significant blood pressure gradient between the upper and lower extremities or diminished femoral pulses, which are indicative of coarctation of the aorta.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old boy is brought to the clinic for a routine examination. He has no significant complaints. Peripheral pulses are strong in the upper limbs but markedly diminished in the femoral region. A soft murmur is best heard over the back.

Blood pressure

140/85 mm Hg in the right arm and 100/70 mm Hg in the lower extremities

Which of the following is the most likely explanation for these findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Coarctation of the aorta manifests with elevated blood pressure in the upper extremities and diminished femoral pulses due to a narrowing of the aorta, typically distal to the left subclavian artery. This narrowing creates a pressure gradient, leading to collateral circulation through intercostal arteries, producing a soft murmur over the back. The differential blood pressures between the upper and lower limbs and the murmur's location are characteristic of this condition. Diagnostic imaging, such as echocardiography or MRI, is used to confirm the diagnosis and assess the severity of the narrowing.

Key learning point: Coarctation of the aorta should be suspected in children with hypertension and a discrepancy in pulse strength between the upper and lower extremities, characterized by strong radial pulses and weak femoral pulses.

B) INCORRECT:

Aortic regurgitation presents with a diastolic murmur and wide pulse pressure, not the differential blood pressures and diminished femoral pulses seen here. The murmur over the back suggests collateral flow due to aortic obstruction, not valve dysfunction.

C) INCORRECT:

Patent ductus arteriosus presents with a continuous murmur in the left infraclavicular area and wide pulse pressure. The differential blood pressure and diminished femoral pulses indicate aortic obstruction, not a communication between the aorta and pulmonary artery.

D) INCORRECT:

Renal artery stenosis causes systemic hypertension via the renin-angiotensin system and may present with an abdominal bruit. It does not cause the differential blood pressure between the upper and lower extremities or diminished femoral pulses, which suggest aortic obstruction.

questions.text: A 2-month-old boy presents with poor feeding, tachypnea, and a harsh holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border. Which congenital cardiac anomaly is most likely?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Atrial septal defect typically presents with a fixed splitting of the second heart sound and a soft systolic ejection murmur due to increased pulmonary flow, not a harsh holosystolic murmur. Infants with atrial septal defects usually tolerate the shunt well, without early symptoms like poor feeding and tachypnea.

B) INCORRECT:

Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) presents with a continuous 'machine-like' murmur best heard in the left infraclavicular area. The harsh holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border described here is not consistent with PDA, which involves continuous flow throughout systole and diastole.

C) INCORRECT:

Tetralogy of Fallot includes a ventricular septal defect but is characterized by significant pulmonary stenosis, producing a systolic ejection murmur at the left upper sternal border. It typically presents with cyanosis or 'tet spells,' not the volume overload symptoms like poor feeding and tachypnea seen here.

D) CORRECT:

Ventricular septal defect (VSD) is the most common congenital cardiac anomaly. It involves a defect in the interventricular septum, allowing blood to shunt from the left to the right ventricle. This results in increased pulmonary blood flow, manifesting as tachypnea and poor feeding due to volume overload. The harsh holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border is characteristic of VSD. The murmur's intensity often inversely correlates with the defect size, with smaller defects producing louder murmurs. Echocardiography assesses the defect's size, location, and hemodynamic impact, guiding management to prevent complications like heart failure.

Key learning point: Ventricular septal defect (VSD) is the most common congenital heart defect.

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl with a grade II murmur has echocardiographic findings of a large secundum defect. She has no cyanosis or heart failure. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Observation is suitable for small, hemodynamically insignificant defects that may close spontaneously. However, a large secundum atrial septal defect suggests significant left-to-right shunting, risking right-sided volume overload and complications like arrhythmias. Delaying intervention until late adolescence allows time for these changes, making early closure preferable in children with large defects.

B) INCORRECT:

Open surgical repair is used for atrial septal defects when percutaneous closure is not feasible due to unfavorable anatomy or additional cardiac anomalies. In this patient, the absence of cyanosis or heart failure suggests a stable state with likely favorable anatomy for percutaneous closure. The less invasive transcatheter approach is generally preferred to avoid the risks of open surgery, such as sternotomy and cardiopulmonary bypass, which have greater perioperative morbidity and longer recovery periods.

C) CORRECT:

A large secundum atrial septal defect (ASD) in a child can lead to significant left-to-right shunting, resulting in right ventricular volume overload and potential complications like arrhythmias or pulmonary vascular changes. Even without symptoms such as cyanosis or heart failure, early intervention is crucial to prevent these sequelae. Percutaneous device closure is preferred when anatomical features, such as sufficient surrounding rims, are favorable. This minimally invasive approach reduces recovery time and procedural morbidity compared to open surgery, effectively sealing the defect and optimizing long-term cardiac outcomes.

Key learning point: Significant atrial septal defects (ASDs) are typically treated between the ages of 3-5 years to prevent complications, and secundum ASDs can often be closed percutaneously rather than surgically.

D) INCORRECT:

Chronic diuretic therapy is used for managing symptoms of congestive heart failure in patients with volume overload. This patient, however, does not exhibit cyanosis or heart failure, indicating no need for symptomatic relief with diuretics. In asymptomatic patients with an isolated atrial septal defect, diuretics do not address the underlying defect or alter its natural history.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman at 33 weeks’ gestation receives indomethacin for acute preterm labor. Which fetal complication is most likely associated with this therapy?

choices.text: Premature closure of the ductus arteriosus

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Neural tube defects occur during early embryogenesis, typically between the third and fourth weeks of gestation, and are linked to maternal folate deficiency or teratogenic exposure. At 33 weeks’ gestation, the neural tube has long closed, making neural tube defects an implausible complication of indomethacin use.

B) CORRECT:

Indomethacin, a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID), inhibits cyclooxygenase enzymes, reducing prostaglandin synthesis. Prostaglandins, particularly PGE2, maintain ductus arteriosus patency in fetal circulation. Reduced prostaglandin levels can lead to premature ductus arteriosus closure, increasing pulmonary vascular resistance and right ventricular workload. This understanding is crucial when using indomethacin as a tocolytic in preterm labor.

Key learning point: Indomethacin, an NSAID used as a tocolytic, can cause premature closure of the ductus arteriosus in the fetus when used in the third trimester of pregnancy.

C) INCORRECT:

Fetal macrosomia, characterized by excessive fetal growth, is often associated with maternal diabetes and fetal hyperinsulinemia. Indomethacin's inhibition of prostaglandin synthesis does not influence fetal growth patterns, and it is not linked to fetal macrosomia.

D) INCORRECT:

Congenital ear malformations arise during the first trimester and are not associated with indomethacin, which affects prostaglandin synthesis. Indomethacin's fetal effects include premature ductus arteriosus closure and oligohydramnios, not ear malformations.

questions.text: You are seeing a 4-week-old male newborn for a well-child examination. He was born at 40 weeks' gestation with a birth weight of 3300 g. He now weighs 4300 g. There is no family history of serious illness. His length and weight are at the 50th percentile. Vital signs are normal.
