On examination, you hear a grade 3/6 harsh holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border and a soft mid-diastolic murmur over the cardiac apex. The lungs are clear to auscultation. The remainder of the examination is normal. Which one of the following is the most likely explanation for these clinical findings?

choices.text: Right-to-left shunt through the atrial septum.
Right-to-left shunt through the ventricular septum.
Left-to-right shunt through the atrial septum.
Left-to-right shunt through the ventricular septum.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A right-to-left shunt through the atrial septum can be seen in patients with tricuspid valve atresia (TVA) and total anomalous pulmonary venous return (TAPVR). In both conditions, a right-to-left shunt through an atrial septal defect (ASD) is necessary to pump blood to the left side of the heart and, consequently, the systemic circulation. Patients with TVA or TAPVR present with cyanosis in the first few days of life. This patient's lack of cyanosis rules out both of these diagnoses.

A right-to-left shunt through the atrial septum can also be seen in patients with Eisenmenger syndrome secondary to an isolated ASD. However, Eisenmenger syndrome develops only after an extended amount of time (usually a few years) and manifests with cyanosis and features of heart failure.

B) INCORRECT:

A right-to-left shunt through the ventricular septum can occur in patients with tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) who have severe right ventricular outflow tract obstruction (RVOTO). In such a scenario, the path of least resistance is through the ventricular septal defect (VSD), and not through the pulmonary valve. Patients with RVOTO would have a systolic ejection murmur at the left upper sternal border and it would be unlikely for a patient with TOF to present without a history of cyanotic spells.

A right-to-left shunt through the ventricular septum can also be seen in patients with Eisenmenger syndrome secondary to an isolated VSD. However, Eisenmenger syndrome develops only after an extended amount of time (usually a few years) and manifests with cyanosis and features of heart failure.

C) INCORRECT:

A left-to-right shunt through the atrial septum can be seen in patients with an atrial septal defect (ASD). Patients with ASD are typically asymptomatic for years and diagnosed when an incidental systolic murmur is heard. However, an ASD typically causes a systolic ejection murmur that is best heard at the left upper sternal border (due to increased pulmonary flow) and a widely split and fixed second heart sound.

D) CORRECT:

A ventricular septal defect (VSD) causes a left-to-right shunt through the ventricular septum. Most VSDs manifest in infancy as a holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border. The size of the defect is inversely proportional to the intensity of the murmur (i.e., small defects are associated with louder murmurs, while large defects may not have an associated murmur). A mid-diastolic murmur can also sometimes be heard with moderate or large VSDs due to increased flow across the mitral valve secondary to the left-to-right shunt.

After a few years, a VSD can lead to pulmonary hypertension and a shunt reversal (Eisenmenger syndrome) resulting in heart failure with cyanosis. With shunt reversal, the murmur of the VSD may disappear.

Key learning point: A ventricular septal defect causes a left-to-right shunt, producing a harsh holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border and can lead to increased pulmonary blood flow.
Image Description:

A defect in the ventricular septum leads to a left-to-right shunt, the volume of which is dependent on the size of the defect. Blood flows from the left ventricle to the right ventricle (white arrow) along the pressure gradient (1). This leads to increased RV and LV preload (due to increased end-diastolic volume), ventricular hypertrophy and dilation (double-headed white arrows), and pulmonary hypertension resulting from excessive pulmonary blood flow (2). In end-stage disease, the pressure gradient is reversed because of Eisenmenger syndrome (shunt reversal), leading to the flow of mixed blood to the systemic circulation (white arrow) and subsequent cyanosis (3).

Blue: structures that contain deoxygenated blood; Red: structures that contain oxygenated blood; Purple: structures that contain mixed blood

E) INCORRECT:

Right ventricular outflow tract obstruction (RVOTO) secondary to pulmonary infundibular stenosis can be seen in patients with tetralogy of Fallot (TOF). Patients with RVOTO would have a systolic ejection murmur at the left upper sternal border and it would be unlikely for a patient with TOF to present without a history of cyanotic spells.
questions.hint: This child's heart murmurs point to the most commonly diagnosed congenital heart defect in newborns.

questions.text: You are seeing a 3-year-old boy in the emergency department who presents with a 2-day history of increasing shortness of breath. He is at the 30th percentile for height and 25th percentile for weight. His temperature is 37.1°C, pulse is 144/min, respirations are 40/min, and blood pressure is 80/44 mm Hg. On examination, there are bilateral crackles at the lung bases. Cardiac examination reveals a grade 3/6 holosystolic murmur best heard at the left lower sternal border and a grade 1/6 middiastolic murmur at the apex. Without treatment, which one of the following is this patient at greatest risk of developing?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Congenital heart defects associated with an increased risk of myocardial ischemia are typically those that involve coronary artery abnormalities (e.g., anomalous course or origin, involving fistulas) or result in decreased coronary perfusion (e.g., in a large PDA, the retrograde blood flow to the left ventricle can decrease diastolic pressure in the proximal aorta and thereby decrease coronary perfusion). Even though a long-standing, uncorrected VSD can also lead to decreased blood pressure, there are no reports of this increasing the risk of myocardial ischemia.

B) INCORRECT:

The left-to-right shunting of blood in VSD can, over time, lead to pulmonary vascular remodeling and increased vascular resistance, resulting in pulmonary rather than systemic hypertension.

C) CORRECT:

A VSD is an acyanotic congenital heart defect that initially has a left-to-right shunt. However, as blood flows through the defect into the right ventricle, blood flow through the pulmonary vasculature increases as well and over time results in increased pulmonary resistance and, ultimately, Eisenmenger reaction (shunt reversal). In this event, the defect becomes cyanotic and the peripheral oxygen saturation decreases. The body responds to chronic hypoxemia by increased erythropoietin production and a subsequent increase in red blood cells, i.e. polycythemia.

Key learning point: Untreated ventricular septal defect can lead to Eisenmenger syndrome, causing chronic hypoxemia and compensatory polycythemia due to right-to-left shunt reversal.

D) INCORRECT:

The congenital heart defect most likely to cause cerebral aneurysms is coarctation of the aorta. This defect would cause a systolic ejection murmur over the left paravertebral region and/or a continuous murmur below the left clavicula and between the shoulder blades.

E) INCORRECT:

A long-standing, uncorrected VSD will eventually result in an Eisenmenger reaction (shunt reversal), in which case, thrombocytopenia, not thrombocytosis, may occur. The cause for thrombocytopenia is unknown, but it is possibly because megakaryocytes bypass pulmonary vasculature, where they would normally be fragmented into platelets.
questions.hint: A holosystolic murmur (indicating flow through the defect) and the middiastolic murmur (increased flow through the mitral valve during diastole) suggests ventricular septal defect (VSD), the most common type of congenital heart defect.

questions.text:
You are examining a male newborn who is 1 hour old and was born at 35 weeks' gestation to a 27-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1. The mother did not receive routine prenatal care. Early in her pregnancy, she experienced a self-limited reddish rash that began on her face and spread to her trunk and limbs, along with joint pain in her hands, wrists, and ankles. Cardiac examination findings for the newborn are provided. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Video
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Persistent truncus arteriosus (PTA) results in a single conduit providing mixed venous and arterial blood to the coronary, pulmonary, and systemic circulations. Cardiac exam findings of PTA would include a single loud S2 and the presence of an ejection click at the cardiac apex or left sternal border. Accentuated and bounding peripheral pulses might also be present. However, patients with an unrepaired defect present with harsh systolic murmurs at the left sternal border, unlike the continuous machinery murmur heard in this patient.

B) CORRECT:

The murmur of a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) is generated as blood continuously shunts from the high-pressure aorta through the ductus arteriosus into the low-pressure pulmonary artery. It may envelop the S2 and is not usually affected by positional changes. Patients with moderate-sized PDAs may present with bounding pulses, widened pulse pressure, and symptoms of heart failure.

This condition affects infants who are born prematurely and/or have congenital rubella infection (CRI). CRI is likely in this newborn given that the mother had features of rubella infection (e.g., an erythematous exanthem that began on the face, polyarthritis). The most common congenital heart defects associated with CRI are PDA and pulmonary stenosis. Pulmonary stenosis causes a systolic ejection murmur at the left upper sternal border.

Key learning point: Patent ductus arteriosus presents with a continuous "machinery" murmur and is commonly associated with prematurity and congenital rubella infection.

C) INCORRECT:

Atrial septal defects (ASD) manifest with a pulmonary flow murmur (systolic ejection murmur) heard best at the left upper sternal border and are often associated with fixed splitting of S2. ASDs are often low-velocity shunts that produce insufficient flow to be audible. Larger shunts may cause diastolic flow murmurs across the tricuspid valve owing to a large left-to-right shunt. However, the continuous machinery murmur would not be seen in patients with an ASD.

D) INCORRECT:

Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) is associated with a harsh crescendo-decrescendo murmur best heard along the left mid- to upper-sternal border. The murmur can decrease in intensity as the degree of right ventricular outflow tract obstruction worsens because of increased right-to-left shunting of blood. The examination findings of a continuous machinery murmur in the left upper sternal border, such as that observed in this patient, would not be seen in patients with TOF.

E) INCORRECT:

Ventricular septal defects (VSDs) manifest with holosystolic, harsh-sounding murmurs, best heard in the left lower sternal border. These murmurs often obliterate the S2 and are associated with a palpable thrill. The examination findings in this patient reveal a continuous machinery murmur in the left upper sternal border, which is not suggestive of a VSD.
questions.hint: Auscultation shows a continuous murmur that is best heard at the left upper sternal border (i.e., near the left infraclavicular region) and has a machine-like quality.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy comes to your clinic for a routine health maintenance examination. He reports feeling well and is doing well in school. He has no history of serious illness. Vital signs are normal. Lung examination is normal. Cardiac auscultation reveals no murmur, but there is a wide-split S2 that does not change with respiration. If left untreated, this patient is at increased risk for which one of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cerebral aneurysms are associated with coarctation of the aorta. Coarctation can manifest with a systolic ejection murmur over the left paravertebral area due to blood flowing through the aortic narrowing and/or a continuous murmur from collateral vessels heard between the shoulder blades. It does not manifest with a fixed, wide splitting of S2. Coarctation of the aorta may also be accompanied by other symptoms, such as hypertension, lower extremity cyanosis, lower extremity claudication, cold feet, dyspnea on exertion, or chest pain.

B) INCORRECT:

Congenital heart defects (e.g., ventricular septal defect, pulmonary stenosis) and predamaged heart valves (e.g., aortic stenosis, mitral valve regurgitation) can predispose to infective endocarditis. However, this risk is negligible in ASDs and PFOs.

C) INCORRECT:

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) typically manifests with a systolic ejection murmur caused by left ventricular outflow tract obstruction (LVOT). Hypertrophic myocardium, fibrosis, and disarrangement of cardiac myocytes predispose to potentially lethal ventricular arrhythmias, which can lead to sudden cardiac death, usually during or after physical activity. If severe enough (and then likely symptomatic), HCM can also lead to the paradoxical splitting of S2, in which the aortic valve closes later than the pulmonary valve (P2, then A2). In an otherwise healthy patient, there is a more likely anatomic cause that explains the fixed, wide splitting of S2 in which the pulmonary valve closes later than the aortic valve (A2, then P2).

D) CORRECT:

Paradoxical embolism is associated with ASDs, patent foramen ovale, and ventricular septal defects (VSD), which allows right-sided thromboemboli to enter the left-sided circulation by bypassing the pulmonary circulation. An ASD causes wide splitting of S2 that is fixed (does not change with respiration) due to increased volume within the pulmonary circulation. A VSD can manifest with a holosystolic murmur.

Key learning point: Atrial septal defect increases the risk of paradoxical embolism due to abnormal communication between the right and left atria, allowing venous clots to enter systemic circulation.
Image Description:

In the presence of a patent foramen ovale, transient increases in right atrial pressure (e.g., when coughing) can allow emboli from the venous system to pass from the right atrium to the left atrium. From there, they can enter systemic arterial circulation and cause arterial embolism (e.g., stroke).

E) INCORRECT:

Left ventricular hypertrophy is a common consequence of volume overload or increased pressures in the left ventricle (e.g., aortic regurgitation, aortic stenosis). ASD (seen here), PFO, and VSD increase the volume in the right ventricle and subsequently lead to right ventricular hypertrophy. In the case of large septal defects, untreated chronic volume overload in the right heart leads to severe hypertrophy and pressure reversal (Eisenmenger syndrome), which then shunts deoxygenated blood to the left ventricle, leading to cyanosis.
questions.hint: This patient's auscultation findings are likely caused by an atrial septal defect (ASD).

questions.text: You are seeing a 3-year-old boy in your clinic for a well-child examination. He was born at 38 weeks' gestation with a birth weight of 2766 g. He now weighs 14 kg. His height is at the 60th percentile and his weight is at the 55th percentile. Vital signs are normal. On examination, his lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination reveals a grade 3/6 systolic ejection murmur at the left upper sternal border and a grade 2/6 mid-diastolic murmur at the left lower sternal border. S2 is widely split and does not vary with respiration. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This child presents with typical auscultation findings of an atrial septal defect (ASD) with the fixed (no change with respiration), widely split S2 being the most specific. Right ventricular volume overload due to the left-to-right shunt across the ASD causes a delayed closure of the pulmonary valve relative to the aortic valve. Since the right and left sides of the heart communicate, the pressure difference that normally exists during respiration evens out; therefore, the duration of the split does not change with inspiration or expiration. The increased blood flow through the right side of the heart also causes a pulmonary flow murmur, which explains the patient's systolic ejection murmur at the left upper sternal border. Some patients with ASD can also have a soft, mid-diastolic murmur at the left lower sternal border secondary to increased flow across the tricuspid valve.

Key learning point: Atrial septal defect is characterized by a fixed, widely split S2 and a systolic ejection murmur at the left upper sternal border due to increased right heart blood flow.

B) INCORRECT:

A patent ductus arteriosus is often discovered incidentally in asymptomatic children. However, cardiac auscultation would usually show a loud continuous machine-like murmur (due to the constant left-to-right shunt) that is best heard in the left infraclavicular region.

C) INCORRECT:

Isolated pulmonary valve stenosis can cause a systolic ejection murmur at the left upper sternal border and a wide S2 split but would not explain the mid-diastolic murmur at the left lower sternal border or the fixed split in S2 (i.e., no variation with respiration).

D) INCORRECT:

Coarctation of the aorta usually presents a systolic ejection murmur in the paravertebral region due to blood flow through the aortic narrowing. It would not explain the fixed split in S2 or the mid-diastolic murmur at the left lower sternal border.

E) INCORRECT:

While a mid-diastolic murmur may be appreciated in patients with a ventricular septal defect (VSD) as a result of increased flow through the mitral valve, this murmur would usually be best heard at the cardiac apex (mitral area) rather than the left lower sternal border (tricuspid area). The classic auscultatory finding at the left lower sternal border in patients with a VSD would be a harsh holosystolic murmur.
questions.hint: This patient presents with a congenital heart defect that may lead to paradoxical embolism and stroke if not surgically corrected.

questions.text: You are seeing a 3-year-old boy in your clinic who has had recurrent nosebleeds and fatigue over the past 2 months. He often complains of headaches. He has achieved all motor milestones for his age but avoids running because his legs hurt when he does. His height and weight are both at the 40th percentile. His temperature is 37.0°C, pulse is 125/min, respirations are 32/min, and blood pressure measured in the right arm is 130/85 mm Hg. On examination, you hear a grade 2/6 systolic murmur in the left paravertebral region. Further evaluation is most likely to show which one of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Left-axis deviation and increased R wave amplitude in V5–V6 on ECG are signs of left ventricular hypertrophy. While myocardial hypertrophy is one of the compensatory mechanisms to counter the aortic narrowing in patients with coarctation of the aorta, such as this 3-year-old boy, the changes in ECG vary with age and degree of stenosis, and it usually takes several years before the hypertrophy becomes apparent. In older children and adults, ECG may show signs of left ventricular hypertrophy in the left precordial leads (e.g., positive Sokolow-Lyon criteria).

B) INCORRECT:

Interarm differences in tissue oxygenation and blood pressure can be a finding of coarctation of the aorta in the rare case that the narrowing is proximal to the left subclavian artery. In such patients, blood pressure in the right arm would be markedly higher than in the left arm and oxygen saturation would be lower in the left arm. However, coarctation of the aorta most commonly presents with differences in blood pressure between the upper and the lower extremities.

C) INCORRECT:

Congenital pulmonary valve stenosis is a characteristic feature of tetralogy of Fallot. A systolic ejection murmur can be present and is usually best heard at the left sternal border, rather than the left paravertebral region. Patients usually present with (mild) cyanosis and intermittent hypoxic episodes that improve with squatting, none of which are seen here. Coarctation of the aorta is characterized by an outflow obstruction of the left ventricle.

D) CORRECT:

In patients with CoA, delayed or even absent lower extremity pulses are expected distal to the stenotic portion of the aorta. Since the post-stenotic blood supply is limited, the resulting lower-extremity hypoxia becomes evident, especially during exertion, which is a strong sign of intermittent claudication, as in this patient.

Doppler echocardiography is the confirmatory test of choice and can identify the location and extent of the stenosis.

Key learning point: Coarctation of the aorta typically presents with hypertension in the upper extremities and delayed or diminished pulses in the lower extremities due to aortic narrowing.
Image Description:

(1) Stenosis distal to the left subclavian artery results in hypertension (↑ BP) in the upper extremities and the head, and hypotension (↓ BP) in the lower extremities and abdomen.

(2) If coarctation involves the origin of the left subclavian artery, BP in the right arm and head will be higher than in the left arm, lower extremities, and abdomen.

E) INCORRECT:

Jugular venous distention (JVD) indicates elevated central venous pressure and can be seen in congenital heart defects affecting right-sided heart function, such as tricuspid valve abnormalities or severe pulmonary stenosis. These conditions can lead to right-sided heart failure and venous congestion. However, JVD is not typically associated with coarctation of the aorta.
questions.hint: This patient's general fatigue, hypertension, low-grade systolic ejection murmur, lower-extremity claudication, headaches, and recurrent epistaxis together suggest coarctation of the aorta (CoA).

questions.text: You are seeing a 7-day-old male newborn who is brought to your clinic because of a 3-day history of feeding difficulty. His mother reports that he sweats excessively and appears uncomfortable during feeds. He was born at 36 weeks' gestation by spontaneous vaginal delivery. He currently weighs 2900 g and is 49 cm in length. His temperature is 37.1°C, pulse rate is 170/min, respirations are 55/min, and blood pressure is 80/50 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 99%. On cardiopulmonary examination, there is a loud machinery murmur along the upper left sternal border. After confirming the diagnosis via echocardiography, which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Outpatient observation is an option for small, asymptomatic PDA without evidence of sequelae (e.g., ventricular hypertrophy). This patient shows signs of heart failure and consequent failure to thrive; correction of the PDA is, therefore, necessary.

B) INCORRECT:

Although chest x-ray may show signs of PDA (prominent main pulmonary artery and aortic knob, along with signs of heart failure), it would not be needed in addition to echocardiography (the imaging test of choice), which is more sensitive and specific, for confirming the diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Transcatheter or surgical closure is the treatment of choice for infants ≥ 6 kg, children, and adults. In preterm infants, procedural closure is generally only used if pharmacological treatment is unsuccessful.

D) INCORRECT:

Prostaglandins maintain ductus arteriosus patency and are indicated as temporary therapy in ductal-dependent congenital heart diseases. Ductal-dependent lesions typically manifest at birth with pronounced cyanosis. This patient's murmur and normal pulse oximetry reading are suggestive of an isolated PDA; prostaglandins would worsen his condition.

E) CORRECT:

Nonselective cyclooxygenase inhibitors such as ibuprofen and indomethacin are the mainstay of treatment for symptomatic PDA in premature infants. Prostaglandins keep the ductus arteriosus patent, and by inhibiting cyclooxygenase, NSAIDs decrease prostaglandin production and thus promote ductal closure. NSAIDs are only effective in preterm infants.

Transcatheter or surgical closure is the treatment of choice for infants ≥ 6 kg, children, and adults. In preterm infants, procedural closure is generally only used if pharmacological treatment is unsuccessful.

Key learning point: Indomethacin or other NSAIDs are first-line therapy to promote closure of symptomatic patent ductus arteriosus in premature infants by inhibiting prostaglandin synthesis.
Image Description:

In patent ductus arteriosus, there is a left-to-right shunt, with blood flowing from the aorta to the pulmonary arteries during both systole and diastole (1). This shunt leads to volume overload (recirculation) of the blood within the pulmonary vessels, the left atrium, and left ventricle (2). Eventually, because of the increased blood flow to the pulmonary circulation, pulmonary hypertension may develop as well as Eisenmenger syndrome, which involves a shunt reversal. The left-to-right-shunt without cyanosis becomes a right-to-left shunt with cyanosis (3).

Blue: structures that contain deoxygenated blood; Red: structures that contain oxygenated blood; Pink: structures that contain mixed blood
questions.hint: Features of heart failure (e.g., poor feeding, sweating, failure to thrive) with a loud continuous (machinery) murmur near the left infraclavicular region are highly suggestive of a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), for which premature birth is a risk factor. Doppler echocardiography showing blood flow from the aorta into the pulmonary artery confirms the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 2-week-old male newborn is brought to your clinic for follow-up. He was born at term after an uncomplicated pregnancy. He has been feeding well and passing adequate amounts of urine. He is at the 60th percentile for length and 40th percentile for weight. Vital signs are normal. On examination, a grade 5/6 holosystolic murmur is heard over the left lower sternal border with a thrill at the same location. Echocardiography reveals a 2-mm membranous ventricular septal defect. There is no evidence of ventricular enlargement, and Doppler assessment of pulmonary artery pressure is normal. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Surgical closure of VSDs before the age of 2 years is indicated for patients who have persistent heart failure symptoms or develop certain echocardiographic findings (e.g., left ventricular dilation, reversible pulmonary hypertension). This patient is asymptomatic and has no signs of complications. The patients who are most likely to develop complications and therefore require early surgical closure have medium or large VSDs; these VSDs manifest with softer murmurs and are typically not associated with a cardiac thrill.

B) CORRECT:

Small VSDs typically close spontaneously without complication, so asymptomatic patients should be reevaluated at 6 months of age for spontaneous closure. If the patient remains asymptomatic at a 6-month follow-up but their murmur persists, reevaluation at 1 year of age is indicated. Asymptomatic patients should subsequently be reevaluated every 2 years.

If symptoms of heart failure (e.g., tachypnea, distress during feeding, failure to thrive) arise, patients should be referred for evaluation and medical therapy (diuretics, immunoprophylaxis, nutritional support). Surgical closure is indicated for patients who remain symptomatic despite medical therapy or develop certain echocardiographic findings (e.g., left ventricular dilation, reversible pulmonary hypertension).

Key learning point: Small, asymptomatic ventricular septal defects usually close spontaneously and require only periodic outpatient follow-up without immediate intervention.

C) INCORRECT:

Closure of the VSD with an Amplatzer® device via cardiac catheterization is generally reserved for patients with a residual VSD after surgical closure, patients with contraindications for surgical closure (e.g., swiss-cheese septum, poorly accessible muscular VSDs), and for older children with small, restrictive muscular VSDs with significant left-to-right flow. Transcatheter closure is contraindicated in patients with membranous VSDs (which are the most common type of VSDs) because of the high risk of heart block after the procedure.

D) INCORRECT:

Indomethacin is used to induce closure of a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), which can be asymptomatic but would manifest with a characteristic machine-like continuous murmur on cardiac auscultation. This patient's auscultatory and echocardiographic findings indicate a different diagnosis, for which indomethacin therapy is not indicated.

E) INCORRECT:

Prostaglandin E1 (PGE1) therapy is used to maintain a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) and is indicated for duct-dependent CHDs (e.g., pulmonary atresia, transposition of the great vessels, hypoplastic left heart syndrome). Patients with duct-dependent CHDs typically present with cyanosis and/or shock within 24 hours of birth, in contrast to this asymptomatic neonate. This patient has a VSD, which causes a left-to-right shunt, as would a PDA. Treatment with PGE1 could actually worsen this patient's shunting and cause heart failure.
questions.hint: Echocardiography confirms the diagnosis of a small ventricular septal defect (VSD), which is the most common congenital heart defect (CHD) and causes a holosystolic murmur best heard over the left lower sternal border. Small VSDs (diameter ≤ 3 mm) cause less left-to-right shunting but result in louder murmurs when compared to medium or large VSDs.

questions.text: You are seeing a 3-year-old girl in your clinic for follow-up after an abnormal heart sound was detected during a routine examination. Her parents report that she often becomes tired while eating and has had several respiratory infections in the past year. She is at the 30th percentile for height and 15th percentile for weight. Echocardiography reveals a defect in the membranous portion of the interventricular septum and a moderately decreased left ventricular ejection fraction. On physical examination, which one of the following findings is most likely to be present?

choices.text: Systolic ejection murmur that increases with forced exhalation against a closed glottis.
Holosystolic murmur that increases with hand clenching.
Continuous murmur that is loudest at the second heart sound.
Wide, fixed splitting of the second heart sound.
Diastolic murmur preceded by opening snap.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A systolic ejection murmur that increases with forced exhalation against a closed glottis (Valsalva maneuver) is characteristic of hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM). The Valsalva maneuver reduces both preload and left ventricular afterload, which would exacerbate the subaortic stenosis in HOCM but reduce the left-to-right shunt of blood in VSD. The Valsalva maneuver would therefore decrease this patient's murmur intensity.

B) CORRECT:

Hand clenching increases systemic vascular resistance and afterload, which causes left-to-right shunting of blood and makes the holosystolic murmur in VSD more audible. Small VSDs may cause a loud holosystolic murmur with palpable thrill due to the large pressure differential between the left and right ventricles, while larger VSDs are typically less obvious on auscultation. If left untreated, VSDs can lead to pulmonary hypertension and heart failure.

Key learning point: A ventricular septal defect produces a holosystolic murmur that becomes louder with increased afterload, such as during hand clenching, due to enhanced left-to-right shunting.
Image Description:

Holosystolic murmur (often referred to as “pansystolic murmur” in the case of a ventricular septal defect)

C) INCORRECT:

A continuous murmur that becomes louder at the second heart sound is characteristic of patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). The murmur is best appreciated in the left infraclavicular region and results from the constant flow of blood from the high pressure aorta to the low pressure pulmonary artery. VSD is characterized by a different finding on auscultation.

D) INCORRECT:

A wide, fixed (i.e., does not change with respiration) splitting of the second heart sound is characteristic of atrial septal defect (ASD). It occurs due to right ventricular overload and subsequent delay in pulmonary valve closure. Fixed splitting of the second heart sound is not a common feature of VSD.

E) INCORRECT:

A diastolic murmur preceded by an opening snap at the apex is characteristic of mitral stenosis (MS). The opening snap occurs when leaflet motion suddenly stops during diastole after the stenosed valve has opened fully. While a short, mid-diastolic murmur can sometimes be heard in VSD due to increased blood flow across the mitral valve, an opening snap would not be expected.
questions.hint: Auscultation findings for a symptomatic ventricular septal defect (VSD) in a patient this age will reflect shunting of blood from the left to right ventricle.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to your clinic for a well-child examination. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. His height is at the 70th percentile and his weight is at the 55th percentile. Vital signs are normal. On examination, you hear a harsh, holosystolic murmur over the left lower sternal border. The intensity of the murmur increases when he clenches his fist forcefully for a sustained period. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patent ductus arteriosus leads to a murmur heard best at the left infraclavicular region. This murmur occurs during both diastole and systole (i.e., a continuous murmur), unlike the harsh holosystolic murmur seen here.

B) INCORRECT:

An atrial septal defect can cause a systolic murmur because of increased flow across the pulmonary valve, but the murmur is heard best at the left upper sternal border. In addition, this murmur has a midsystolic crescendo-decrescendo character, and it is accompanied by a wide, fixed split second heart sound.

C) INCORRECT:

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy can cause a murmur as a result of mitral regurgitation (MR) or left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction. A murmur due to MR is holosystolic and increases in intensity with maneuvers that increase left ventricular afterload (e.g., handgrip) but is heard best at the cardiac apex (5th intercostal space in the midclavicular line). A murmur due to LVOT obstruction is heard best at the left lower sternal border but has a midsystolic, crescendo-decrescendo character and decreases in intensity with maneuvers that increase left ventricular afterload.

D) INCORRECT:

Mitral valve prolapse leads to a systolic murmur that increases in intensity with maneuvers that increase afterload (e.g., handgrip), which is seen here. However, this murmur is heard best at the cardiac apex (5th intercostal space in the midclavicular line). In addition, this murmur has a late systolic crescendo character, and it is preceded by a click due to tensing of the chordae tendinae.

E) CORRECT:

A ventricular septal defect (VSD), which causes a left-to-right shunt, leads to a harsh holosystolic murmur because of turbulent blood flow across the defect. The murmur is heard best at the left lower sternal border (tricuspid area) and becomes louder with maneuvers that increase left ventricular afterload (e.g., handgrip) because of increased left-to-right shunting. The murmur is typically louder with smaller defects because of the large pressure difference between the left and right ventricles.

Key learning point: A harsh holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border that increases with handgrip is characteristic of a ventricular septal defect.
questions.hint: The handgrip maneuver increases afterload by increasing total peripheral resistance.

questions.text: You are seeing a 3-month-old boy in your clinic for a routine follow-up. He was born at 32 weeks' gestation to a 35-year-old woman. Vital signs are normal. On examination, you hear a grade 4/6 continuous murmur best at the left infraclavicular region. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Persistent truncus arteriosus results in a single conduit providing mixed venous and arterial blood to the coronary, pulmonary, and systemic circulations. Cardiac examination findings would include a single loud S2, the presence of an ejection click at the cardiac apex or left sternal border, and harsh systolic murmurs at the left sternal border, unlike the continuous murmur heard in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) is associated with a harsh crescendo-decrescendo murmur best heard along the left mid- to upper-sternal border. The murmur can decrease in intensity as the degree of right ventricular outflow tract obstruction worsens because of increased right-to-left shunting of blood. The examination findings of a continuous murmur would not be seen in patients with TOF.

C) CORRECT:

A patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) manifests with a continuous machinery murmur best heard in the left infraclavicular area. The machinery murmur is generated as blood continuously shunts from the high-pressure aorta through the ductus arteriosus into the low-pressure pulmonary artery. It may envelop the S2 and is not usually affected by positional changes. Patients with moderate-sized PDAs may present with bounding pulses, widened pulse pressure, and symptoms of heart failure.

Key learning point: A continuous "machinery" murmur best heard at the left infraclavicular area is characteristic of a patent ductus arteriosus.
Image Description:

Continuous systolic and diastolic heart murmur (machinery murmur)

D) INCORRECT:

Atrial septal defects (ASD) manifest with pulmonary outflow tract murmurs heard best at the left upper sternal border and are often associated with fixed splitting of S2. ASDs are often low-velocity shunts that produce insufficient flow to be audible. Larger shunts may cause diastolic flow murmurs across the tricuspid valve owing to a large left-to-right shunt. However, a continuous murmur would not be seen in patients with an ASD.

E) INCORRECT:

Ventricular septal defects (VSD) manifest with holosystolic, harsh sounding murmurs, best heard in the left lower sternal border. These murmurs often obliterate the S2 and are associated with a palpable thrill. Neonates present with an asymptomatic heart murmur or, in cases of moderate-to-large sized defects, with signs of heart failure. The examination findings in this patient reveal a continuous murmur, which is not suggestive of a VSD.
questions.hint: This patient's condition typically affects premature infants or infants with a congenital rubella infection.

questions.text: A 4-month-old infant presents with poor feeding and failure to thrive. Physical examination shows tachypnea, hepatomegaly, and a systolic murmur at the left sternal border. These findings are most consistent with which condition?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct – Ventricular septal defect is the most common congenital heart defect. This condition frequently manifests with failure to thrive, feeding difficulties, tachypnea, and hepatomegaly due to left-to-right shunting causing heart failure. The systolic murmur at the left sternal border is characteristic of this defect.

B) INCORRECT:

Atrial septal defect most commonly manifests later in childhood or adulthood, and is asymptomatic in infancy. When symptomatic, it rarely causes failure to thrive in the first months of life, and the murmur is typically heard at the second left intercostal space.

C) INCORRECT:

Patent ductus arteriosus classically presents with a continuous murmur rather than an isolated systolic murmur. While it can cause heart failure symptoms, the murmur characteristics described are not typical of this condition.

D) INCORRECT:

Coarctation of the aorta typically manifests with differential blood pressures between upper and lower extremities and may cause heart failure, but the murmur is usually heard best at the back between the scapulae rather than at the left sternal border.

E) INCORRECT:

A patent foramen ovale is generally asymptomatic in infants and does not cause failure to thrive or symptoms of heart failure. While complications can occur, they typically manifest as paradoxical embolic events in adulthood.

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant presents to the emergency department with poor feeding and increased work of breathing. The infant was born at term without complications but has had progressive symptoms over the past month. Physical examination reveals tachypnea, a harsh holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border, pink skin and mucous membranes, and no digital clubbing. Pulse oximetry shows 98% oxygen saturation on room air. Based on these clinical findings, what type of congenital heart defect is most likely?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tetralogy of Fallot is a cyanotic congenital heart defect characterized by right-to-left shunting. Patients typically present with central cyanosis and low oxygen saturation, which are not seen here.

B) INCORRECT:

Transposition of great arteries is a cyanotic congenital heart defect that manifests with central cyanosis and hypoxemia in the neonatal period. This patient's normal oxygen saturation and absence of cyanosis exclude this diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Hypoplastic left heart syndrome is a cyanotic congenital heart defect that typically manifests in the immediate neonatal period with severe cyanosis and requires urgent intervention. This patient's normal oxygen saturation and later presentation exclude this diagnosis.

D) CORRECT:

Ventricular septal defect is an acyanotic congenital heart defect characterized by left-to-right shunting. This patient's clinical presentation of heart failure symptoms (poor feeding, tachypnea) with normal oxygen saturation and absence of cyanosis is consistent with an acyanotic left-to-right shunt lesion.

E) INCORRECT:

Total anomalous pulmonary venous return is a cyanotic congenital heart defect that manifests with central cyanosis and low oxygen saturation. This patient's normal oxygen saturation and pink skin color are inconsistent with this diagnosis.

questions.text: A 4-month-old infant presents to the emergency department with poor feeding and diaphoresis during feeds. Physical examination shows a grade 4/6 harsh systolic murmur at the left lower sternal border with a palpable thrill and no other significant abnormalities. Vital signs are heart rate, 140/minute; BP 85/40; oxygen saturation, 98% on room air. The parents report that the murmur was first detected at the 2-month well-child visit. Which congenital heart defect is most likely?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Atrial septal defect (ASD) typically manifests with a mid-systolic ejection murmur at the 2nd left intercostal space with fixed splitting of S2. This patient's harsh holosystolic murmur with thrill at the left lower sternal border is not characteristic for ASD. Most ASDs remain asymptomatic in infancy, with symptoms usually appearing in adulthood.

B) INCORRECT:

The classic manifestation of patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) is a continuous "machinery" murmur that is loudest at S2, heard best in the left infraclavicular region. This patient's murmur is systolic only, not continuous, making PDA unlikely. Additionally, PDA typically causes a wide pulse pressure due to left-to-right shunting.

C) INCORRECT:

Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) typically manifests with cyanosis and a harsh systolic ejection murmur at the left upper sternal border, not the lower border. This patient's normal oxygen saturation, lack of cyanosis, and murmur location are inconsistent with TOF.

D) INCORRECT:

Atrioventricular septal defect (AVSD) most commonly occurs in individuals with Down syndrome and involves defects in both the atrial and ventricular septa along with abnormal atrioventricular valves. Complete AVSD typically produces multiple murmurs, including both systolic and diastolic components due to the complex anatomy, rather than the isolated harsh holosystolic murmur seen here.

E) CORRECT:

Correct – Ventricular septal defect (VSD) is the most common congenital heart defect and characteristically manifests with a harsh holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border, often with a palpable thrill. The timing of this patient's symptom onset (after birth, as pulmonary vascular resistance decreases) and the feeding difficulties with diaphoresis are typical of moderate to large VSDs causing heart failure in infancy.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents with palpitations and episodes of presyncope during aerobic dance classes over the past month. She reports no chest pain or dyspnea at rest. Vital signs are normal. Physical examination reveals a soft systolic murmur over the left upper sternal border and a widely split second heart sound that does not change with respiration. This constellation of findings is most consistent with which diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct – The fixed splitting of S2 (widely split second heart sound that does not change with respiration) is pathognomonic for atrial septal defect (ASD). The soft systolic murmur at the left upper sternal border represents relative pulmonary stenosis due to increased stroke volume from the left-to-right shunt. This combination of fixed split S2 and systolic murmur at the left upper sternal border is characteristic of ASD.

B) INCORRECT:

Mitral valve prolapse (MVP) commonly causes palpitations and presyncope in young adults, but it typically manifests with a mid-systolic click followed by a late systolic murmur that moves earlier with decreased preload. MVP does not cause fixed splitting of the second heart sound or a murmur specifically at the left upper sternal border.

C) INCORRECT:

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) can cause presyncope with exertion in young adults and manifests with a systolic murmur, but the murmur is typically heard best at the left lower sternal border or apex and increases with decreased preload. HCM does not cause fixed splitting of S2.

D) INCORRECT:

Bicuspid aortic valve commonly manifests in young adults and can cause presyncope with exertion, but patients typically present with a systolic murmur at the right upper sternal border or apex, often with an ejection click. Bicuspid aortic valve does not cause fixed splitting of S2 or a murmur specifically at the left upper sternal border.

E) INCORRECT:

Coarctation of the aorta can remain undiagnosed until adulthood and cause exercise intolerance, but it typically manifests with upper extremity hypertension and a systolic murmur heard over the back or left sternal border. Coarctation does not cause fixed splitting of S2 or the specific murmur location seen here.

questions.text: A 6-hour-old neonate is brought to the emergency department by parents who report difficulty feeding and rapid breathing. The patient appears pale and has weak peripheral pulses in the lower extremities. Vital signs are BP, 90/65 in the right arm and 50/35 in the left leg. The patient becomes increasingly irritable and develops mottled skin on the lower extremities. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While respiratory support may eventually be needed, the immediate priority is addressing the ductal-dependent circulation. Intubation and positive pressure ventilation could worsen hemodynamics in this preload-dependent condition without first ensuring adequate ductal patency.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- The differential blood pressures between upper and lower extremities with signs of lower extremity hypoperfusion in a neonate strongly suggest a ductal-dependent systemic circulation anomaly such as coarctation of the aorta or critical aortic stenosis. Prostaglandin E1 infusion is the most appropriate immediate intervention to maintain ductal patency and preserve systemic perfusion until definitive repair can be performed.

C) INCORRECT:

While fluid resuscitation may be considered in shock, the differential blood pressures and lower extremity findings suggest a ductal-dependent lesion. Fluid bolus would not address the underlying pathophysiology of impaired systemic perfusion distal to an obstruction.

D) INCORRECT:

Inotropic support may be helpful for heart failure management but does not address the underlying problem of ductal-dependent systemic circulation. The priority is maintaining ductal patency to ensure adequate perfusion to the lower body.

E) INCORRECT:

Although echocardiography will be needed to define the anatomy, the clinical presentation of differential blood pressures and lower extremity hypoperfusion in a neonate suggests a ductal-dependent systemic circulation anomaly requiring immediate intervention to maintain ductal patency.

questions.text: A 4-day-old full-term neonate presents with progressive tachypnea and feeding difficulty that began 8 hours ago. The patient was feeding well until today. Physical examination shows a crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur heard best at the left sternal border, and wide splitting of S2. The neonate appears lethargic with poor peripheral perfusion, weak peripheral pulses, and cool extremities. Vital signs P, 180; BP, 65/40. An echocardiogram shows severe pulmonary valve stenosis with a peak gradient of 80 mm Hg. What is the most appropriate immediate management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Inotropic support addresses cardiac contractility but does not resolve the fundamental problem of inadequate pulmonary blood flow due to critical pulmonary stenosis, which is a ductal-dependent condition. Maintaining patency of the ductus arteriosus is the priority to ensure adequate pulmonary circulation.

B) INCORRECT:

Balloon valvuloplasty is the definitive treatment for critical pulmonary stenosis, but it cannot be performed in an unstable neonate. Maintaining patency of the ductus arteriosus is essential to stabilize the patient and ensure adequate pulmonary blood flow.

C) CORRECT:

Correct – This neonate has critical pulmonary valve stenosis, a ductal-dependent congenital heart defect in which pulmonary blood flow becomes dependent on the patent ductus arteriosus. When the ductus begins to close naturally after birth, shock can develop due to severely reduced pulmonary circulation. Prostaglandin E1 infusion prevents ductal closure and maintains pulmonary blood flow until definitive surgical or catheter-based intervention can be performed.

D) INCORRECT:

While respiratory support may be needed as part of comprehensive management, it does not address the underlying ductal-dependent circulation. The primary issue is critical pulmonary valve stenosis that requires maintaining patency of the ductus arteriosus to ensure adequate pulmonary blood flow.

E) INCORRECT:

Diuretics are contraindicated in this patient as they would worsen the already compromised cardiac output and potentially lead to further hemodynamic instability. The priority is maintaining patency of the ductus arteriosus to ensure adequate pulmonary blood flow.

questions.text: A 6-week-old female infant presents to the ED with poor feeding and increased work of breathing for the past week. She was born at 35 weeks' gestation. Vital signs are P, 160; BP, 85/45; T, 37.2°C (99.0°F); R, 60, oxygen saturation, 94% on room air. The patient has bounding peripheral pulses and a wide pulse pressure. Auscultation reveals a continuous rough murmur heard best at the left infraclavicular region. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Start broad-spectrum antibiotics and obtain blood cultures

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Four-extremity blood pressures are appropriate for suspected coarctation of the aorta, which typically manifests with diminished femoral pulses and upper extremity hypertension. This patient's continuous murmur and bounding pulses are not consistent with coarctation.

B) INCORRECT:

Cardiac catheterization is premature without first confirming the diagnosis with echocardiography and attempting medical management. While cardiac catheterization might eventually be considered for complex congenital heart disease, initial management should focus on medical therapy and cardiology consultation.

C) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient's clinical presentation (prematurity, poor feeding, bounding pulses, wide pulse pressure, and continuous murmur in the left infraclavicular region) is consistent with patent ductus arteriosus. Echocardiography is the confirmatory test to assess shunt volume and pulmonary artery pressure and should be obtained to confirm the diagnosis before further management decisions.

D) INCORRECT:

Infective endocarditis can cause a continuous murmur, but it is rare in neonates and infants without other confirmed underlying structural heart disease or invasive procedures. Furthermore, this patient has no fever, petechiae, or other systemic signs of infection. Starting antibiotics without clear evidence of infection is inappropriate. Prematurity, bounding pulses, wide pulse pressure, and a characteristic continuous murmur in the left infraclavicular region strongly suggest patent ductus arteriosus.

E) INCORRECT:

This premature infant likely has patent ductus arteriosus based on the clinical findings of a continuous murmur, bounding pulses, and wide pulse pressure, but indomethacin should not be administered without first confirming the diagnosis with echocardiography and ruling out additional ductal-dependent congenital heart disease.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl presents with exertional dyspnea and recurrent headaches. She has a history of primary amenorrhea and is in the 5th percentile for height. Physical examination shows blood pressure of 170/90 mm Hg in the right arm and 110/75 mm Hg in the left arm. Femoral pulses are diminished bilaterally. A continuous murmur is audible over the left posterior thorax. What is the most likely genetic syndrome associated with this patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Trisomy 21 (Down syndrome) is associated with atrioventricular septal defects, ventricular septal defects, atrial septal defects, and patent ductus arteriosus. These defects do not typically cause differential arm blood pressures or the constellation of findings seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Trisomy 18 (Edwards syndrome) is associated with ventricular septal defects and other cardiac anomalies, but not with coarctation of the aorta. A differential blood pressure pattern is not expected in trisomy 18. Classic clinical features of trisomy 18 are also absent in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Noonan syndrome is associated with pulmonary valve stenosis and other cardiac defects, but not with coarctation of the aorta. Pulmonary stenosis does not produce the differential arm blood pressure pattern or the posterior thoracic murmur seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Holt-Oram syndrome is associated with atrial septal defects and upper limb abnormalities. This patient's clinical findings of differential blood pressures, diminished femoral pulses, and posterior thoracic murmur are not consistent with atrial septal defect pathophysiology.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- Turner syndrome is associated with coarctation of the aorta in 5–15% of female patients. This patient's clinical presentation of differential arm blood pressures, diminished femoral pulses, and continuous murmur over the posterior thorax, combined with classic features of Turner syndrome (short stature, primary amenorrhea), strongly supports this diagnosis. Coarctation causes increased blood pressure proximal to the narrowing and decreased flow distally.

questions.text: A 32-year-old healthy woman presents to the emergency department with acute, sudden onset, left-sided weakness and facial droop. Her medical history is unremarkable, with no prior unexplained thrombotic or embolic symptoms. She is afebrile and takes only oral contraceptive pills. A stroke protocol CT/CTA of the head shows an acute infarction in the right middle cerebral artery territory and patent carotid and vertebral arteries. ECG and initial laboratory studies are normal. Which of the following should be considered as a potential underlying cause of her clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) with left ventricular outflow tract obstruction can cause syncope and sudden cardiac death through dynamic obstruction of blood flow, but it is not associated with embolic strokes. This young woman taking OCPs has no evidence of carotid disease or arrhythmia and is at low risk of other hypercoagulable states affecting the arterial circulation. Therefore, paradoxical embolism must be investigated. HCM involves ventricular wall thickening that obstructs outflow, but it does not create right-to-left shunting pathways that would allow a venous clot to enter the systemic circulation.

B) INCORRECT:

Bicuspid aortic valve can predispose to endocarditis, which frequently causes embolic stroke through septic emboli. Endocarditis is unlikely in this afebrile patient with no risk factors for infective endocarditis. This young woman taking OCPs has no evidence of carotid disease or arrhythmia and is at low risk of other hypercoagulable states affecting the arterial circulation. Therefore, paradoxical embolism must be investigated. A bicuspid aortic valve does not cause intracardiac communication that would allow venous clots to reach arterial circulation.

C) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary valve stenosis rarely causes embolic complications unless it is associated with endocarditis. Infectious causes are unlikely in this abefrile patient with no risk factors for infective endocarditis. This young woman taking OCPs has no evidence of carotid disease or arrhythmia and is at low risk of other hypercoagulable states affecting the arterial circulation. Therefore, paradoxical embolism must be investigated. Pulmonary valve stenosis maintains normal venous-arterial separation and does not create conditions in which venous thrombi can bypass pulmonary filtration and cause systemic circulation strokes.

D) INCORRECT:

Tricuspid regurgitation may be associated with tricuspid valve endocarditis, particularly in individuals who use IV drugs, but it typically causes pulmonary rather than systemic emboli. Infectious causes are unlikely in this abefrile patient with no risk factors for infective endocarditis. This young woman taking OCPs has no evidence of carotid disease or arrhythmia and is at low risk of other hypercoagulable states affecting the arterial circulation. Therefore, paradoxical embolism must be investigated. Tricuspid valve disease alone is not associated with right-to-left shunting, which is required for venous clots to enter the systemic circulation.

E) CORRECT:

Correct – Patent foramen ovale (PFO) creates persistent right-to-left atrial communication, which affects 25% of adults. Paradoxical embolism must be investigated in this young patient taking oral contraceptive pills because infectious causes are unlikely (afebrile, no risk factors for infective endocarditis) and standard stroke causes have been ruled out (by normal carotid duplex, telemetry, and hypercoagulability studies). PFO allows venous thrombi to bypass pulmonary circulation and directly enter systemic arteries during increased right atrial pressure. Patients with other acyanotic congenital heart diseases that are typically associated with left-to-right shunts (e.g., ASD, VSD) are also at risk of paradoxical embolism if they develop Eisenmenger syndrome, a long-term complication associated with shunt reversal.

questions.text: A 4-month-old infant presents with poor feeding, increased work of breathing, and failure to thrive over 2 weeks. Physical examination shows tachypnea, a harsh holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border, and normal skin tone. Pulse oximetry shows 97% oxygen saturation. Chest radiograph demonstrates cardiomegaly with enhanced pulmonary vascular markings. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Arterial blood gas analysis would not provide additional diagnostic information in this stable patient with normal oxygen saturation. Gas exchange is typically preserved in left-to-right shunts until late complications develop.

B) INCORRECT:

Chest CT angiography is not routinely used for initial evaluation of suspected congenital heart defects in infants. CT angiography may be considered for preprocedural anatomical guidance but only after echocardiographic diagnosis is established.

C) INCORRECT:

Prostaglandin E1 infusion is used for ductal-dependent lesions in critically ill neonates, typically presenting in the first days to weeks of life. This intervention is not indicated in this stable 4-month-old.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- Echocardiography is the confirmatory diagnostic test for suspected acyanotic congenital heart defects. The clinical presentation of heart failure symptoms with normal oxygen saturation and harsh holosystolic murmur suggests a left-to-right shunt, most likely ventricular septal defect. Echocardiography will definitively visualize the defect, assess shunt volume, and guide further management decisions.

E) INCORRECT:

Cardiac catheterization is reserved for cases with equivocal echocardiographic findings, suspected coronary artery disease, or when pulmonary vascular disease assessment is needed. Noninvasive imaging should be performed first in stable patients.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presents for a pre-employment physical. He reports mild exertional dyspnea but is otherwise healthy. His medical history is unremarkable. On cardiac examination, a systolic ejection click is noted, followed by a harsh crescendo-decrescendo murmur best heard at the left upper sternal border. There is a palpable right ventricular heave. Which of the following is most likely to be observed during auscultation of this patient's heart?

choices.text: A holosystolic murmur that obscures S2
Decreased intensity of the murmur with squatting
Radiation of the murmur to the carotid arteries
Increased intensity of the murmur with inspiration
A fixed, widely split second heart sound

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A holosystolic (pansystolic) murmur is uniform in intensity throughout systole and is characteristic of regurgitant lesions, such as mitral regurgitation, tricuspid regurgitation, or a ventricular septal defect. The murmur described in this patient is a crescendo-decrescendo ejection murmur, which peaks in mid-systole as flow across the valve is maximal.

B) INCORRECT:

Squatting increases systemic vascular resistance and venous return to the heart. The increased venous return would augment blood flow across the pulmonic valve, thereby increasing the intensity of a pulmonic stenosis murmur. A decrease in murmur intensity with squatting is characteristic of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and mitral valve prolapse.

C) INCORRECT:

Radiation of a systolic ejection murmur to the carotid arteries is a classic finding of aortic stenosis, not pulmonic stenosis. The turbulent jet of blood from the left ventricle is directed superiorly into the aorta and its branches. The murmur of pulmonic stenosis is typically localized to the left upper sternal border and may radiate to the left clavicle or back.

D) CORRECT:

The clinical findings of a systolic ejection click, a crescendo-decrescendo murmur at the left upper sternal border, and a right ventricular heave are typical for pulmonic stenosis. During inspiration, intrathoracic pressure decreases, which increases venous return to the right side of the heart. This augmented blood volume flowing from the right ventricle across the stenotic pulmonic valve leads to greater turbulence and thus a louder murmur. This phenomenon is a hallmark of right-sided heart murmurs. In severe pulmonic stenosis, the increased right ventricular emptying time also causes a widely split S2 that widens further with inspiration due to a delayed pulmonic valve closure (P2).

E) INCORRECT:

A fixed, widely split second heart sound, where the split between A2 and P2 does not vary with respiration, is the pathognomonic auscultatory finding for an atrial septal defect (ASD). Pulmonic stenosis causes a delayed P2, leading to a widely split S2, but the split is not fixed and still demonstrates normal physiologic variation with breathing.
questions.hint: Murmurs can often be distinguished by how they respond to physiologic maneuvers that alter preload or afterload.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is evaluated for progressive exertional dyspnea. He reports being unable to keep up with his teammates during soccer practice over the past few months. He has no other medical history. On physical examination, there is a palpable parasternal lift and a prominent jugular venous 'a' wave. Which of the following is the most likely finding on cardiac auscultation?

choices.text: A harsh systolic murmur at the left upper sternal border
A holosystolic murmur at the cardiac apex that radiates to the axilla
A harsh systolic murmur at the right upper sternal border that radiates to the carotids
A fixed, widely split second heart sound
A holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation suggests congenital pulmonic stenosis. The obstruction to right ventricular outflow leads to right ventricular hypertrophy, causing the palpable parasternal lift. The stiff, hypertrophied ventricle requires forceful right atrial contraction for filling, which produces the prominent 'a' wave in the jugular venous pulse. The turbulent flow across the stenotic pulmonic valve generates a harsh, crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur best heard at the left upper sternal border (pulmonic area).

B) INCORRECT:

This is the classic description of mitral regurgitation, which is a left-sided valvular lesion. This patient's physical examination findings, including the parasternal lift and prominent 'a' wave, are specific to right-sided heart pathology.

C) INCORRECT:

This describes the murmur of aortic stenosis. Although aortic stenosis can cause exertional dyspnea, it is a left-sided heart lesion and would not typically cause a parasternal lift or a prominent jugular 'a' wave, which are signs of right-sided heart strain.

D) INCORRECT:

This is the pathognomonic finding for an atrial septal defect (ASD). Although an ASD can cause a parasternal lift due to right ventricular volume overload, its hallmark auscultatory finding is the fixed split S2. A prominent 'a' wave is not a typical feature of an uncomplicated ASD.

E) INCORRECT:

This murmur is characteristic of tricuspid regurgitation or a ventricular septal defect. Although tricuspid regurgitation is a right-sided lesion, it typically causes a prominent 'v' wave, not an 'a' wave. This patient's prominent 'a' wave more specifically suggests an outflow obstruction.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl has exertional dyspnea and a widely fixed split S2 on auscultation. Which ECG finding is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Left axis deviation is more commonly associated with ostium primum atrial septal defects, where abnormal development of the atrioventricular septum and conduction tissue involvement can occur. The clinical presentation of exertional dyspnea and a widely fixed split S2 suggests an ostium secundum ASD, which typically leads to right heart volume overload and right-axis deviation, not left axis deviation.

B) INCORRECT:

Diffuse ST-segment elevations are typically seen in acute pericarditis, characterized by chest pain and friction rub. The clinical presentation of exertional dyspnea and a widely fixed split S2 suggests an atrial septal defect, where ECG changes are due to right ventricular volume overload, not diffuse myocardial inflammation.

C) CORRECT:

Ostium secundum atrial septal defects (ASDs) result in a left-to-right shunt, increasing blood flow through the right heart and causing volume overload of the right atrium and right ventricle. This overload can delay right ventricular depolarization, manifesting as an rSR’ pattern in the right precordial leads, especially V1, without significant QRS prolongation. This pattern is characteristic of an incomplete right bundle branch block and reflects the electrophysiologic changes due to increased volume load, commonly observed in patients with this type of ASD.

Key learning point: Right bundle branch block is a common ECG finding in patients with ostium secundum atrial septal defect due to right ventricular volume overload.

D) INCORRECT:

A prolonged PR interval indicates a delay in atrioventricular nodal conduction, characteristic of first-degree heart block. Atrial septal defects, particularly of the ostium secundum type, typically cause right ventricular volume overload and conduction delays in the right ventricular outflow tract, not AV nodal conduction delays.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man with Down syndrome is brought to the physician by his mother for the evaluation of fatigue. Physical examination shows bluish-colored lips and digital clubbing that were not present at his most recent examination. Right heart catheterization shows a right atrial pressure of 32 mmHg. Which of the following is most likely involved in the pathogenesis of this patient's current condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Aortic valve regurgitation is most commonly seen in connective tissue disorders such as Marfan syndrome. Backflow of blood from the aorta into the left ventricle would result in left ventricular hypertrophy and increased left atrial pressure rather than increased right atrial pressure. In addition, aortic valve regurgitation presents with fatigue but not with clubbing and cyanosis. This patient's history of Down syndrome makes a different mechanism more likely.

B) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary hypertension is a manifestation of acyanotic heart defects, which are the result of a left-to-right shunt. The increased volume of the shunted blood causes a remodeling of the pulmonary vasculature, leading to pulmonary hypertension. This patient most likely has pulmonary hypertension but this is an irreversible process, not reversible.

C) INCORRECT:

Intrapulmonary shunting occurs in situations where parts of the lungs are perfused but not ventilated, resulting in a ventilation-perfusion mismatch. Some common conditions that can cause intrapulmonary shunt include pulmonary AVM, hepatopulmonary syndrome, severe cases of pulmonary edema, and lobar atelectasis. This patient's history of Down syndrome makes an underlying congenital heart defect a more likely cause of his condition, rather than a pulmonary condition.

D) CORRECT:

Central cyanosis, weakness, and clubbing in a patient with a history of Down syndrome are highly suggestive of Eisenmenger syndrome due to a congenital heart defect, most likely an endocardial or atrioventricular cushion defect. Both of these defects initially cause a left-to-right blood shunt (i.e., acyanotic heart defect) due to higher pressures within the left heart. Over time, the increased blood flow within the right heart and the pulmonary vasculature results in permanent remodeling of pulmonary vessels and right ventricular hypertrophy. The right ventricular pressure eventually becomes higher (normal 5–10 mmHg) than the left ventricular pressure, causing a reversal of the shunt and cyanosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Asymmetric septal hypertrophy is seen in hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM), a hereditary condition that can manifest with fatigue and an increased atrial pressure. However, HOCM would not manifest with central cyanosis, digital clubbing, and increased right atrial pressure (the left side is more commonly involved). This patient's history of Down syndrome makes a different etiology more likely.
questions.hint: Congenital heart defects associated with Down syndrome include atrioventricular, ventricular, and atrial septal defects.
